## Scroll I. Attica

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.1.1">

Belonging to the Greek
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnikē</span>\] mainland
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ēpeiros</span>\], facing the
Cyclades Islands and the Aegean Sea, is the headland
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akrā</span>\] named Sounion,
jutting out from the land of Attica. When one[^1] has rounded the
headland \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akrā</span>\] there
is a harbor and a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Athena
of-Sounion \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Souniás</span>\] on
the summit \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koruphē</span>\] of
the headland \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akrā</span>\].
Farther on is Laurion, where once the Athenians had silver mines, and a
small uninhabited island called the Island of Patroklos.
I-say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] a fortification
was built on it and a palisade constructed by Patroklos, who was admiral
in command of the Egyptian trireme ships sent by Ptolemy, son of
Ptolemy, son of Lagos, to help the Athenians, when Antigonos, son of
Demetrios, was ravaging their country, which he had invaded with an
army, and at the same time was blockading them by sea with a fleet.[^2]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.1.2">

The \[harbor city\] Peiraieus was a deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] from early
times, though it was not a seaport
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-neion</span>\] before
Themistocles became an archon
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn</span>\] of the
Athenians.[^3] Their seaport
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-neion</span>\] had been
Phaleron, for at this place the sea comes nearest to Athens, and from
here it is said that Menestheus sailed off with his fleet for Troy, and
before him Theseus, when he went off to give compensation to Minos for
the death of Androgeōs. But when Themistocles became archon
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn</span>\], since he
thought that the \[harbor city\] Peiraieus was more conveniently
situated for those who sail, and had three harbors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">limenes</span>\] as against
one at Phaleron, he made it \[= Peiraieus\] the Athenian seaport
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-neion</span>\]. Even up to
my time there were ship-sheds
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">neōs oikoi</span>\] there, and
near the largest harbor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">limēn</span>\] is the tomb of
Themistocles. For it is said that the Athenians repented of their
treatment of Themistocles, and that his relatives took up his bones and
brought them from Magnesia. And the children of Themistocles certainly
returned \[to Athens\] and set up in the Parthenon a painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] in which \[the
figure\] of Themistocles has been painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphesthai</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.1.3">

Worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] in the Peiraieus
is a precinct \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\]
of Athena and Zeus. Both their statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] are of
bronze; Zeus holds a scepter and a Nike, Athena a spear. Here is \[a
painting of\] Leosthenes and \[of\] his sons, painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] by
Arkesilaos. This Leosthenes at the head of the Athenians and the united
Greeks \[Hellēnes\] defeated the Macedonians in Boeotia and again
outside Thermopylae forced them into Lamia over against Oitē, and hemmed
them in there.[^4] It \[= the painting\] is in the long portico
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\], where is
located a marketplace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agorā</span>\] for those
living near the sea—those farther away from the harbor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">limēn</span>\] have
another—but behind the portico near the sea stand a Zeus and a
\[personified\] Dēmos, the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] of Leokhares.
And by the sea Konon[^5] built a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Aphrodite,
after he had crushed the Lacedaemonian warships off Knidos in the Carian
peninsula.[^6] I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] the people of
Knidos honor \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\]
Aphrodite greatly, and they have sanctuaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] of the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]; the
oldest is to her as Doritis \[‘Bountiful’\], the next in age as Akraia
\[‘of the Headland’\], while the newest is to the Aphrodite called ‘of
Knidos’ by people generally, but Euploia \[‘Good Sailing’\] by the
people of Knidos themselves.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.1.4">

The Athenians have also another harbor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">limēn</span>\], at Mounukhia,
with a temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Artemis of Mounukhia, and yet another at Phaleron, as I have already
stated, and near it is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Demeter.
Here there is also a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Athena
Skiras, and one of Zeus some distance away, and altars of the gods named
Unknown \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Agnōstoi</span>\], and
of heroes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\], and
of the children of Theseus and Phaleros; for this Phaleros is said by
the Athenians to have sailed with Jason to Kolkhis. There is also an
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of
Androgeōs, son of Minos, though it is called that of Hērōs; those,
however, who pay special attention to the study of their
local-antiquities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enkhōria</span>\] know that it
belongs to Androgeōs.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.1.5">

Twenty stadium-lengths away is the headland
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akrā</span>\] called Kōlias;
to this place, when the Persian fleet was destroyed, the wreckage was
carried down by the waves. There is here a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the
Aphrodite surnamed Kōlias, together with goddesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] called
Genetyllides \[presiding-over-childbirth\]. And I am of opinion that the
goddesses \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] of
the people of Phokaia in Ionia, whom they call Gennaides, are the same
as those at Kōlias. On the way from Phaleron to Athens there is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Hērā with
neither doors nor roof. It is said that Mardonios, son of Gobryas,
burned it. But the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] there today
is, as report goes, the work of Alkamenes.[^7] So that this, at any
rate, cannot have been desecrated by the Persians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.2.1">

As one enters the city, there is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\][^8] of Antiope
the Amazon. This Antiope, Pindar says, was abducted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazein</span>\] by
Peirithoös and Theseus, but Hegias of Troizen has created-poetically
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] about her such
things as I will now tell. Hēraklēs was besieging Themiskyra at \[the
river\] Thermodon, and could not take it, but Antiope,
having-conceived-a-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erastheisa</span>\] for
Theseus, who was aiding Hēraklēs in his campaign, surrendered the
stronghold. These things has Hegias created-poetically
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]. But the
Athenians assert that when the Amazons came \[to attack Athens\],
Antiope was shot by Molpadia \[the Amazon\], while Molpadia was killed
by Theseus. The Athenians have a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\][^9] of Molpadia
as well.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.2.2">

As one goes up from the Peiraieus there are ruins of the walls that
Konon restored after the naval battle offshore from \[the island of\]
Knidos. I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] those \[walls\]
that had been built by Themistocles after the retreat of the Persians
were destroyed during the rule
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] of the
so-called Thirty.[^10] Along the road are some very well-known tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\]: that of
Menander, son of Diopeithes, and a cenotaph
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma kenon</span> ‘empty
tomb’\] of Euripides. He \[= Euripides\] himself went to King Arkhelaos
\[of Macedonia\] and lies buried in Macedonia; as for the way
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropos</span>\] he died—many
have narrated it—let it be as they say.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.2.3">

I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] even in his time
\[= the era of Euripides\] poets
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiētai</span>\] could live in
the company of kings, as earlier still Anacreon resided in the company
of Polycrates, tyrant of Samos; also, Aeschylus and Simonides were sent
to Hieron at Syracuse. Residing in the company of Dionysius, tyrant in
Sicily at a later period, was Philoxenos, and, residing in the company
of Antigonos,[^11] ruler of Macedonia, were Antagoras of Rhodes and
Aratos of Soloi. As for Hesiod and Homer, they either did not have the
good fortune of residing in the company of kings or else purposely
neglected doing so, Hesiod because of his countryside ways
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agroikiā</span>\] and
reluctance to travel, while Homer, having traveled very far and wide,
considered the aid provided by the powerful in the acquisition of wealth
to be less important than his fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] among the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hoi polloi</span>. And yet
Homer, too, in what he composed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\], makes
Demodokos live in the compnay of Alkinoos, and \[he makes\] Agamemnon
leave behind \[when the king departed for Troy\] a poet
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiētēs</span>\] to attend his
wife. Not far from the gates is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\], on which is
positioned a soldier
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratiōtēs</span>\] standing
by a horse. Who it is I do not know, but both horse and soldier were
carved by Praxiteles.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.2.4">

On entering the city there is a building for the preparation of the
processions \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pompai</span>\],
which are arranged
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pempein</span>\] in some cases
every year, in other cases at longer intervals. Close by is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Demeter, with
statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of
her and of her daughter, and of Iakkhos holding a torch. On the wall, in
Attic letters, is written that they are works of Praxiteles. Not far
from the temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]
is Poseidon on horseback, hurling a spear against the giant
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gigas</span>\] Polubōtēs,
concerning whom is prevalent among the people of Kos the myth
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mūthos</span>\] about the
promontory \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akrā</span>\] of
Khelōnē. But the inscription of our time assigns the likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] to another, and
not to Poseidon. Extending from the gate to the Kerameikos there are
porticoes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoai</span>\], and
in front of them bronze likenesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\] of such as
had some title to fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\], both men and
women.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.2.5">

One of the porticoes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoai</span>\] contains
shrines \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] of
gods, and a gymnasium named after Hermes. In it is the house
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikiā</span>\] of Poulutiōn,
at which it is said that a mystical-rite
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teletē</span>\] was once
performed \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\] by
Athenians of considerable fame, corresponding to the mystical-rite
performed at Eleusis. But in my time it was devoted to the worship of
Dionysus. This Dionysus they call Melpomenos \[from
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">melpesthai</span> ‘sing and
dance’\], on the same principle as they call Apollo Mousēgētēs ‘Leader
of the Muses’. Here there are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Athena
Paiōniā), of Zeus, of Mnemosyne \[‘Memory’\] and of the Muses, an
Apollo, the votive-offering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēma</span>\] and work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] of Euboulides,
and Akratos, a superhuman force
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimōn</span>\] who is one of
the attendants of Dionysus \[Jones mistakenly says “Apollo” here\]; it
is only a face
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prosōpon</span>\] of him,
worked-into
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">en-oikodomeîn</span>\] the
wall \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toikhos</span>\].
Situated beyond the precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] of Apollo is
a building \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikēma</span>\]
that contains terracotta statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\]: Amphiktyon,
king of Athens, in the act of celebrating-at-a-feast
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hestiân</span>\] Dionysus and
other gods. Here also is Pēgasos of Eleutherai, who introduced the god
to the Athenians. Participating-in-the-action
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-lambanesthai</span>\] was
the oracle \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteion</span>\]
at Delphi, which called-to-mind
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-mnē-sai</span>\] that the
god once dwelled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-dēmeîn</span>\] in Athens
in the days of Ikarios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.2.6">

Amphiktyon acquired the kingdom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileiā</span>\] thus. It is
said that Aktaios was the first to become-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\] of what is
now Attica. When Aktaios died, Kekrops received-by-relay
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ek-dekhesthai</span>\] the
rulership \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\],
housed-together
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-oikeîn</span>\] as he was
with the daughter of Aktaios, and there were born to him daughters,
Hersē, Aglauros and Pandrosos, and a son Erysikhthon. This son did not
become king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\] of the
Athenians, but happened to die while his father lived, and the one who
inherited-by-relay
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ek-dekhesthai</span>\] the
kingdom of Kekrops was Kranaos, who surpassed at the time the other
Athenians with his power. They say that Kranaos had daughters, and among
them Atthis; and from her they call the region Attica, which before was
named Aktaia. And Amphiktyon, leading an insurrection against Kranaos,
although he had his daughter as wife, deposed him from rulership
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\]. Afterwards he
himself was deposed as the result of an insurrection organized by
Erikhthonios and his followers. They say that Erikhthonios was not born
of humans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\],
but that his parents were Hephaistos and Earth \[Gē\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.3.1">

The locale \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrion</span>\]
known as the Kerameikos has its name from the hero Keramos, and they say
that he too was son of Dionysus and Ariadne. First on the right is what
is called the Royal Portico
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Sto</span><span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ā
Basileios</span>\], where is seated the archon-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn</span>
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] when holding
the yearly rulership
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] that is named
after the <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn
basileus</span>. On the tiling
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">keramos</span>\] of this
portico \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\] are
statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] made
of terracotta, Theseus throwing Skiron into the sea and Day \[Hēmerā\]
carrying away Kephalos, who they say was most beautiful and was abducted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazein</span>\] by Day, who
conceived-a-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erasthēnai</span>\] for him.
His son was Phaethon, afterwards abducted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazein</span>\] by
Aphrodite) \[…\] and he was made a guardian
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phulax</span>\] of her temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]. That is what is
said by Hesiod, among others, in his verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epos</span> plural\] having to
do with women.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.3.2">

Near the portico \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\]
stand \[the statues of\] Konon, Timotheus his son, and Euagoras,[^12]
King of Cyprus, who exacted a gift of Phoenician trireme ships to be
given to Konon by King Artaxerxes. This he did as an Athenian whose
ancestry connected him with Salamis, for he traced-his-lineage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">geneālogeîn</span>\] back to
Teukros as also to the daughter of Kinyras. Here stand \[the statue of\]
Zeus, called Zeus Eleutherios \[‘of Freedom’\], and \[the statue of\]
‘King’ \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\]
Hadrian, who made-public-displays
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-deiknusthai</span>\] of
his benefactions to all the populations that he ruled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhein</span>\]—and
especially to the city of the Athenians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.3.3">

Another portico \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\]
is built behind \[the one I just talked about\], and this one has
paintings \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] of
the gods called the Twelve. On the wall opposite are painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphesthai</span>\] Theseus,
\[personified\] Democracy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Dēmokratiā</span>\], and
\[personified\] <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Dēmos</span>.
The painting \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\]
represents Theseus as the one who established for the Athenians a system
of governance
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">politeuesthai</span>\]
on-an-equal-footing \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ex
isou</span>\]. In other ways as well did the story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phēmē</span>\] spread among
the people—the story that Theseus bestowed upon them the management of
their own affairs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pragmata</span>\], and that
from his time onward the people continued to have-a-democratic
government
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmokrateîsthai</span>\],
until the emergence of Peisistratos, who became-tyrant
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turanneîn</span>\].[^13]
Granted, the majority of people tell and are told many other things as
well—things that are not true
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">alēthē</span>\], since people
are ignorant of scientific-research
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">historiā</span>\] and consider
trustworthy whatever they have heard, from childhood onward, in choruses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khoroi</span>\] and tragedies
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tragōidiai</span>\]. There are
stories like that also concerning Theseus, who himself became king, and
afterwards, when Menestheus died, the descendants of Theseus remained
rulers even to the fourth generation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">geneā</span>\]. But if I cared
about tracing-lineages
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">geneālogeîn</span>\] I should
have included in the counting, besides these, the kings starting from
Melanthos extending all the way to Kleidikos the son of Aisimides.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.3.4">

Also painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphesthai</span>\] here is
the exploit, near Mantineia, of the Athenians who were sent to help the
Lacedaemonians.[^14] Xenophon among others has written a history of the
whole war—the taking of the Kadmeia, the defeat of the Lacedaemonians at
Leuktra, how the Boeotians invaded the Peloponnesus, and the contingent
sent to the Lacedaemonians from the Athenians. The painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] shows a
cavalry battle, in which the most famous men are, among the Athenians,
Grylos the son of Xenophon, and, in the Boeotian cavalry, Epameinondas
the Theban. These paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] were painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] for the
Athenians by Euphranor, and he also did the Apollo surnamed Patrōos
\[‘Ancestral’\] in the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] close by. In
front of the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] is an Apollo
that Leokhares made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]; \[also in
front is\] another Apollo, called Alexikakos \[‘averter of evil’\], made
by Kalamis. They say that the god received this name because, by way of
an oracular pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteion</span>\] from Delphi,
he stopped the pestilential disease
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nosos</span>\] that afflicted
the Athenians at the time of the Peloponnesian War.[^15]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.3.5">

Here is built also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the Mother
of the gods; she \[= her statue\] is by Pheidias. Close by is the
council-chamber
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleutērion</span>\] of those
called the Five Hundred, who for a term of a year act-as-councilors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleuein</span>\] on behalf
of the Athenians. In it are a wooden-statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\] of Zeus
Boulaios and an Apollo, the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\] of Peisias,
and a \[personified\] Dēmos, a work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] by Lyson. As
for the lawgivers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thesmothetai</span>\], they
were painted \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\]
by Protogenes[^16] of Kaunos, and Olbiades painted Kallippos, who led
the Athenians to Thermopylae to stop the incursion of the Gauls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Galatai</span>\] into Greece
\[Hellas\].[^17]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.4.1">

These Gauls \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Galatai</span>\]
inhabit the most remote portions of Europe, near a great sea that is not
navigable all the way to its extremities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">perata</span>\], and has tides
and fauna quite unlike those of other seas. Through their territory
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrā</span>\] flows the river
Ēridanos, on the banks of which the Daughters of Hēlios \[‘Sun’\] are
customarily thought to be lamenting the experience
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pathos</span>\] of their
brother Phaethon. It was late before the name
<span custom-style="chs_foreign">Gauls</span>
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Galatai</span>\] prevailed;
for in ancient times they were called Celts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Keltoi</span>\] both among
themselves and by others. An army of them gathered and turned towards
the Ionian Sea. They dispossessed the Illyrian people and all who
dwelled as far away as Macedonia, along with the Macedonians themselves.
Then they overran Thessaly. And when they drew near to Thermopylae, the
Greeks \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] in
general made no move to prevent the incursion of the barbarians, since
previously they had been severely defeated by Alexander and Philip.
Further, Antipatros and Kassandros[^18] afterwards crushed the Greek
side \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò Hellēnikon</span>\],
so that, because of their weakness, each state thought it was not
shameful to take no part in the defense.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.4.2">

But the Athenians, although they were more exhausted than any of the
other Greeks \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]
by the long Macedonian war, and had been generally unsuccessful in their
battles, nevertheless set forth to Thermopylae with such Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] as joined
them, having made the Kallippos I mentioned their general. Occupying the
pass where it was narrowest, they tried to keep the barbarians from
entering Greece \[Hellas\]; but the Celts, having discovered the path by
which Ephialtes of Trakhis once led the Persians,[^19] overwhelmed the
men of Phokis stationed there and crossed Oitē unperceived by the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.4.3">

Then it was that the Athenians put the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] under the
greatest obligation, and although outflanked offered resistance to the
barbarians on two sides. But the Athenians in the fleet suffered most,
for the Lamian gulf is a swamp near Thermopylae—the reason being, I
think, the hot water that here runs into the sea. These then were more
distressed, and the reason is this: taking the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] on board,
they were forced to sail through the mud, weighed downas they were by
arms and men.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.4.4">

So, they tried to save the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] in the way
described, but the Gauls, now south of the Gates \[= Thermopylae\],
cared not at all to capture the other towns, but were very eager to
plunder Delphi and the treasures of the god. They were opposed by the
people of Delphi themselves and by the men of Phokis who originated from
the cities around Mount Parnassus; a force of Aetolians also joined the
defenders, for the Aetolians at this time were preeminent for their
vigorous resistance. When the forces engaged, not only were thunderbolts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">keraunoi</span>\] and rocks
broken off from Parnassus hurled against the Gauls, but
terrifying-shapes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">deimata</span>\] that looked
like armed warriors appeared to the barbarians. They say that two of
these apparitions, Hyperokhos and Amadokos, came from the Hyperboreans,
and that the third was Pyrrhos son of Achilles. Because of this help in
battle the Delphians sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enagizein</span>\] to Pyrrhos
\[as to a hero\], although formerly they held even his tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] in dishonor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">atīmiā</span>\], as being that
of an enemy.[^20]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.4.5">

The greater number of the Gauls crossed over to Asia \[Minor\] by ship
and plundered its coasts. Some time after, the inhabitants of Pergamon,
which was called in ancient times Teuthrania, drove the Gauls into this
region, away from the sea. Now this population occupied the country on
the farther side of the river Sangarios, capturing Ankyra, a city of the
Phrygians, which Midas son of Gordios had founded in former time. And
the anchor \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ankura</span>\],
which Midas found, was even as late as my time in the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Zeus, as
well as a spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\] called the
Spring of Midas, water from which they say Midas mixed with wine to
capture Silenos. Well then, the Pergamenes took Ankyra and Pessinos
which is situated under Mount Agdistis, where they say that Attis lies
buried.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.4.6">

They \[= the Pergamenes\] have spoils-of-war \[captured\] from the
Gauls, and a painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] that portrays
their deed \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\]
against them. The land they dwell in was, they say, in ancient times
sacred \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierā</span>\] to the
Kabeiroi, and they claim that they are themselves Arcadians, being
descended from those who crossed into Asia \[Minor\] with Telephos. Of
the wars that they have waged no story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phēmē</span>\] has been made
public to the world-at-large, except that they have accomplished three
most notable achievements: the subjection of the coastal region of Asia
\[Minor\], the expulsion of the Gauls from there, and the exploit of
Telephos against the followers of Agamemnon, at a time when the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], after
failing to reach Troy, were plundering the plain called Mēion, thinking
it Trojan territory. Now I will return from my digression.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.5.1">

Near to the council-chamber
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleutērion</span>\] of the
Five Hundred is what is called Tholos \[‘Round House’\]; here the
presidents \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prutaneis</span>\]
sacrifice \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\], and
there are a few small statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] made of
silver. Farther up stand statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\] of heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\], from whom
afterwards the Athenian subdivisions
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phūlai</span>\] received their
names. Who the man was who established ten
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phūlai</span> instead of four,
and changed their old names to new ones—all this is told by Herodotus
\[5.69\].[^21]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.5.2">

The heroes known as the eponymous ones
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\] are \[1\]
Hippothoön son of Poseidon and of Alope daughter of Kerkyon, \[2\]
Antiokhos, whose father was Hēraklēs and whose mother was Meda daughter
of Phylas, thirdly, \[3\] Ajax son of Telamon, and, among the Athenians,
\[4\] Leōs, who is said to have given up \[as human sacrifice\] his
daughters in accordance with what was-said-in-an-oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrē</span>-\] by the god
\[Apollo\] in order to achieve a salvation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōtēriā</span>\] that was to
be communal \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koinē</span>\] for
all; also among the eponymous-heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\] is \[5\]
Erekhtheus, who conquered the Eleusinians in battle, and killed their
general, Immarados the son of Eumolpos; there is also \[6\] Aigeus, and
\[7\] Oineus the bastard son of Pandion, and \[8\] Akamas, one of the
children of Theseus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.5.3">

I saw also among the eponymous-heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\] the
likenesses \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\] of
\[9\] Kekrops and \[10\] Pandion, but I do not know who among those who
have these names are given the honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\] \[of being
venerated as an eponymous hero. I say this because there was an earlier
Kekrops who was-ruler
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhein</span>\]—his wife was
the daughter of Aktaios—and there was also a later Kekrops—the one who
led-a-colonizing-expedition
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">met-oikeîn</span>\] to Euboea.
This one was son of Erekhtheus son of Pandion son of Erikhthonios. And
there was a king Pandion who was son of Erikhthonios, and another who
was son of Kekrops the second. This man \[Pandion\] was deposed from his
rule \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] by the
Mētionidai, and when he fled to Megara—for he had as wife the daughter
of Pylas king of Megara—his children were banished with him. And Pandion
is said to have fallen ill there \[in Megara\] and died, and on the
coast of the region of Megara is his tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\],[^22] situated
on the cliff called the rock of Athena the Aithuia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.5.4">

But his sons \[= the sons of Pandion\] expelled the Mētionidai, and
returned from their exile at Megara. Then Aigeus, as the eldest, became
king of the Athenians. As for his daughters \[by contrast with his
sons\], on the other hand, there was no benevolent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agathos</span>\]
superhuman-force
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimōn</span>\] to help him
raise them, nor did they \[= these daughters\] leave him with any sons
who could avenge him \[the same way that his sons avenged him against
the Mētionidai\]. And yet it was for the sake of \[his own\] power
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dunamis</span>\] that he
\[Pandion\] had made a marriage-alliance
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kēdos</span>\] with the man
from Thrace \[= Tereus, king of Thrace\]. Well, there is no way
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poros</span>\] for a mortal to
evade what is sent by a god as a thing that the god deems to be fitting
to send. They say that Tereus, though he was married to Procne, violated
Philomela. Thus, \[Thracian that he was,\] he transgressed the custom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomos</span>\] of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]. And, on top
of that, he mutilated the body
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōma</span>\] of the daughter
\[of Pandion,\] \[cutting out her tongue\]. By doing so, his action led
the women \[= the daughters of Pandion\] to resort to \[what was for
them\] the necessity of retribution
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikē</span>\]. There is also
another statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andrias</span>\] of Pandion on
the Acropolis, and it is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.5.5">

These are the Athenian eponymous-heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\] who belong
to the ancients
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhaioi</span>\].[^23] And of
later date than these they have subdivisions
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phūlai</span>\] named after
the following: Attalos[^24] the Mysian[^25] and Ptolemy the
Egyptian,[^26] and within my own time\*[^27] ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\]Hadrian
,[^28] who was most observant in giving honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\] to divinity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò theion</span>\] and who
contributed very much to the happiness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eudaimoniā</span>\] of those
whom he ruled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhein</span>\]. He never
voluntarily entered upon a war, but he reduced the Hebrews
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hebraioi</span>\] who lived
beyond Syria; they had rebelled.[^29] As for the sanctuaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] of the gods
that in some cases he built from the beginning, in others adorned
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-kosmeîn</span>\] them with
offerings \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēmata</span>\]
and furnishings, and the gifts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dōreai</span>\] he gave to
cities that are Greek
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnides</span>\], and
sometimes even to barbarians who asked him, all these acts are inscribed
in his honor in the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] at Athens that
is common \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koinon</span>\] to
all the gods.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.1">

But as for what pertains to Attalos and Ptolemy, it is more ancient in
point of time, so that the story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phēmē</span>\] no longer
remains, and those who attended these kings for the writing-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun=graphē</span>\] of their
deeds fell into neglect even before \[= before the story failed\]. So,
it occurred to me to highlight
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēloûn</span>\] their deeds
also, and how the rule
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] of Egypt, of
the Mysians, and of the neighboring peoples fell into the hands of the
ancestors \[of these rulers\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.2">

[^30] The Macedonians consider Ptolemy to be the son of Philip, the son
of Amyntas, though putatively the son of Lagos, asserting that his
mother was pregnant when she was married off to Lagos by Philip. And
among the distinguished acts of Ptolemy in Asia they mention that it was
he who, of all the companions of Alexander, was foremost in helping him
when in danger among the Oxydrakai. After the death of Alexander,[^31]
by withstanding those who would have conferred all his empire
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] upon Aridaios,
the son of Philip, he became chiefly responsible for the division of the
various nations \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ethnē</span>\]
into the kingdoms
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileiai</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.3">

He crossed over to Egypt in person, and killed Kleomenes, whom Alexander
had appointed satrap of that country, considering him a friend of
Perdikkas, and therefore not faithful to himself; and the Macedonians
who had been entrusted with the task of carrying the corpse
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nekros</span>\] of Alexander
to Aigai, he persuaded to hand it over to him. And he proceeded to
entomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaptein</span>\] it,
in the ritual-way
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomos</span>\] of the
Macedonians, in Memphis, but, knowing that Perdikkas would make war, he
kept Egypt garrisoned. And Perdikkas took Aridaios, son of Philip, and
the boy Alexander, whom Rōxanē, daughter of Oxyartes, had borne to
Alexander, to create some decorum for the military campaign, but really
he was plotting to take from Ptolemy his kingdom in Egypt. But being
expelled from Egypt, and having lost his reputation as a soldier, and
being in other respects unpopular with the Macedonians, he was killed by
his bodyguards.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.4">

The death of Perdikkas immediately raised Ptolemy to power, who both
reduced the Syrians and Phoenicia, and also welcomed Seleukos, son of
Antiokhos, who was in exile, having been expelled by Antigonos; he
further himself prepared to attack Antigonos. He prevailed on
Kassandros, son of Antipatros, and Lysimakhos, who was king in Thrace,
to join in the war, on the grounds that Seleukos was in exile and that
the growth of the power of Antigonos was dangerous to them all.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.5">

For a time Antigonos prepared for war, and was by no means confident of
the issue; but on learning that the revolt of Cyrene had called Ptolemy
to Libya, he immediately reduced the Syrians and Phoenicians by a sudden
attack, handed them over to Demetrios, his son, a man who for all his
youth had already a reputation for good sense, and went down to the
Hellespont. But he led his army back without crossing, on hearing that
Demetrios had been overcome by Ptolemy in battle. But Demetrios had not
altogether evacuated the country before Ptolemy, and having surprised a
force of Egyptians, killed a few of them. Then on the arrival of
Antigonos Ptolemy did not wait for him but returned to Egypt.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.6">

When the winter was over, Demetrios sailed to Cyprus and overcame in a
naval action Menelaos,[^32] the satrap of Ptolemy, and afterwards
Ptolemy himself, who had crossed over to bring help. Ptolemy fled to
Egypt, where he was besieged by Antigonos on land and by Demetrios with
a fleet. In spite of his extreme peril Ptolemy saved his empire
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] by making a
stand with an army at Pēlousion while offering resistance with warships
from the river. Antigonos now abandoned all hope of reducing Egypt,
under the circumstances, and dispatched Demetrios against the Rhodians
with a fleet and a large army, hoping, if the island were won, to use it
as a base against the Egyptians. But the Rhodians displayed daring and
ingenuity in the face of the besiegers, while Ptolemy helped them with
all the forces he could muster.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.7">

Antigonos thus failed to reduce Egypt or, later, Rhodes, and shortly
afterwards he offered battle to Lysimakhos, and to Kassandros and the
army of Seleukos, but he lost most of his forces, and was himself
killed, having suffered most by reason of the length of the war with
Eumenes. Of the kings who put down Antigonos I hold that the most unholy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hosios</span>\] was
Kassandros, who although he had recovered the throne of Macedonia with
the aid of Antigonos, nevertheless came to fight against a benefactor.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.6.8">

After the death of Antigonos, Ptolemy again reduced the Syrians and
Cyprus, and also restored Pyrrhos to Thesprotia on the mainland. Cyrene
rebelled; but Magas, the son of Berenikē (who was at this time married
to Ptolemy) captured Cyrene in the fifth year of the rebellion. If this
Ptolemy really was the son of Philip, son of Amyntas, he must have
inherited from his father his madness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò epi-manes</span>\] for
women, for, while wedded to Eurydikē, the daughter of Antipatros,
although he had children he went into a state-of-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\] for Berenikē,
whom Antipatros had sent to Egypt with Eurydikē. Having
conceived-a-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erastheis</span>\] for this
woman, he had children by her, and when his end drew near he left the
kingdom of Egypt to Ptolemy (after whom the Athenians name their
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phulē</span>) being the son of
Berenikē and not of the daughter of Antipatros.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.7.1">

This Ptolemy, having-conceived-a-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erastheis</span>\] for
Arsinoe, his full sister, married her, violating Macedonian custom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizomena</span>\] in doing
so, but following that of his Egyptian subjects. Secondly he put to
death his brother Argaios, who was, it is said, plotting against him;
and it was he who brought down from Memphis the corpse
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nekros</span>\] of
Alexander.[^33] He put to death another brother also, son of Eurydikē,
on discovering that he was creating disaffection among the Cypriotes.
Then Magas, the half-brother of Ptolemy, who had been entrusted with the
governorship of Cyrene by his mother Berenikē—she had borne him to
Philip, a Macedonian but of no note and of lowly origin—induced the
people of Cyrene to revolt from Ptolemy and marched against Egypt.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.7.2">

Ptolemy fortified the entrance into Egypt and awaited the attack of the
Cyrenaeans. But while on the march Magas was informed that the
Marmaridai, a tribe of Libyan nomads, had revolted, and thereupon fell
back upon Cyrene. Ptolemy resolved to pursue, but was checked owing to
the following circumstance. When he was preparing to meet the attack of
Magas, he engaged mercenaries, including some four thousand Gauls.
Discovering that they were plotting to seize Egypt, he led them through
the river to a deserted island. There they perished at one another’s
hands or by famine.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.7.3">

Magas, who was married to Apame, daughter of Antiokhos, son of Seleukos,
persuaded Antiokhos to break the treaty that his father Seleukos had
made with Ptolemy and to attack Egypt. When Antiokhos resolved to
attack, Ptolemy dispatched forces against all the subjects of
Antiokhos—he sent plunderers to overrun the lands of the weaker, and an
army to hold back the stronger—so that Antiokhos never had an
opportunity to attack Egypt. I have already stated how this Ptolemy sent
a fleet to help the Athenians against Antigonos and the Macedonians, but
it did very little to save Athens. His children were born of Arsinoe—not
his sister, but the daughter of Lysimakhos. His sister who had wedded
him happened to die before this, leaving no issue, and there is in Egypt
a district called Arsinoites after her.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.8.1">

It is pertinent to add here a report about Attalos, because he too is
one of the Athenian eponymous-heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\]. A
Macedonian by the name of Dokimos, a general of Antigonos, who
afterwards surrendered both himself and his property to Lysimakhos, had
a Paphlagonian eunuch called Philetairos. All that Philetairos did to
further the revolt from Lysimakhos, and how he won over Seleukos, will
form an episode in my account of Lysimakhos. Attalos, however, son of
Attalos and nephew of Philetairos, received the kingdom from his cousin
Eumenes, who handed it over. The greatest of his achievements was his
forcing the Gauls to withdraw from the seacoast into the region that
they still hold.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.8.2">

After the likenesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\] of the
eponymous-heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\] come statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of gods,
Amphiaraos, and Eirene \[‘Peace’\] carrying the boy Ploutos
\[‘Wealth’\[. Here stands a bronze figure of Lycurgus (Lukourgos), son
of Lykophron, and of Kallias, who, as most of the Athenians say, brought
about the peace between the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] and
Artaxerxes, son of Xerxes.[^34] Here also is Demosthenes, whom the
Athenians forced to retire to Kalaureia, the island off Troizen, and
then, after receiving him back, banished again after the disaster at
Lamia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.8.3">

Exiled for the second time[^35] Demosthenes crossed once more to
Kalaureia, and committed suicide there by taking poison, being the only
Greek \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēn</span>\] exile
whom Arkhias failed to bring back to Antipatros and the Macedonians.
This Arkhias was a man from Thourioi who undertook the unholy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hosion</span>\] task of
bringing to Antipatros for punishment those who had opposed the
Macedonians before the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] met with
their defeat in Thessaly. Such was Demosthenes’ reward for his great
devotion \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eu-noia</span>\] to
Athens. I think it is well said, the saying that no man who has
unsparingly thrown himself into political-life
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">politeiā</span>\] trusting in
the loyalty of the democracy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tà tou dēmou</span>\] has ever
met with a beautiful death.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.8.4">

Near the likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of Demosthenes
is a sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\]
of Ares, where are placed two statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of
Aphrodite, one of Ares made by Alkamenes, and one of Athena made by a
man from Paros by the name of Lokros. There is also a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Enyo, made
by the sons of Praxiteles. About the temple stand \[images of\]
Hēraklēs, Theseus, Apollo binding his hair with a fillet
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tainiā</span>\], and statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\] of
Kalades, who it is said to have framed laws for the Athenians, and of
Pindar, and this likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] \[of Pindar\]
is one of the rewards the Athenians gave him for praising
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ep-aineîn</span>\] them in a
song that he made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.8.5">

Close by stand statues of Harmodios and Aristogeiton, who killed
Hipparkhos.[^36] The reason
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] for this deed
and the way it was done have been related by others; of the statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\] some were
made by Kritios, the old ones being the work of Antenor. When Xerxes
captured Athens after the Athenians had abandoned the city he took away
these statues also among the spoils, but they were afterwards restored
to the Athenians by Antiokhos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.8.6">

Before the entrance of the theater
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theatron</span>\] that they
call the Odeum
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ōideion</span>\] are statues
of Egyptian kings. They are all alike called Ptolemy, but each has his
own surname. For they call one Philometor, and another Philadelphos,
while the son of Lagos is called Soter, a name given him by the
Rhodians. Of these, Philadelphos is he whom I have mentioned before
among the eponymous-heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumoi</span>\], and near
him is a likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of his sister
Arsinoe.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.1">

The one called Philometor is eighth in descent from Ptolemy son of
Lagos, and his surname was given him in sarcastic mockery
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khleuasmos</span>\], for we
know of none of the kings who was so hated by his mother. Although he
was the eldest of her children she would not allow him to be called to
the throne, but prevailed on his father before the call came to send him
to Cyprus. Among the reasons assigned for Kleopatra’s enmity towards her
son is her expectation that Alexander the younger of her sons would
prove more subservient, and this consideration induced her to urge the
Egyptians to choose Alexander as king.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.2">

When the people
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">plēthos</span>\] offered
opposition, she dispatched Alexander for the second time to Cyprus,
ostensibly as general, but really because she wished by this means to
make Ptolemy more afraid of her. Finally she covered with wounds those
eunuchs she thought were best disposed \[toward her, and thus least
likely to object\], and she presented them to the people
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">plēthos</span>\], pretending
that she was the victim of Ptolemy’s machinations, and that he had
treated the eunuchs in such a fashion. The people of Alexandria rushed
to kill Ptolemy, and when he escaped on board a ship, made Alexander,
who returned from Cyprus, their king.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.3">

Retribution for the exile of Ptolemy came upon Kleopatra, for she was
put to death by Alexander, whom she herself had made to be king of the
Egyptians. When the deed was discovered, and Alexander fled in fear of
the citizens, Ptolemy returned and for the second time assumed control
of Egypt. He made war against the Thebans, who had revolted, reduced
them two years after the revolt, and treated them so cruelly that they
were left not even a memorializing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hupomnēma</span>\] of their
former prosperity, which had so grown that they once surpassed in wealth
the richest of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], even the
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Delphi and the people of Orkhomenos. Shortly after this Ptolemy met with
his appointed fate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">moira</span>\], and the
Athenians, who had been benefited by him in many ways, which I need not
stop to relate, set up a bronze \[statue\] of him and of Berenikē, his
only legitimate child.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.4">

Next in line after the Egyptians are set up the statues of Philip and of
his son Alexander. The events of their lives were too important to make
digressive remarks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parerga</span>\] in what is
another story. In the case of the Egyptians, they had their tokens of
gratitude bestowed upon them because the honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\] they received
was genuine and because they were benefactors, but it was rather the
sycophancy \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kolakeiā</span>\]
of the people \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">plēthos</span>\]
that resulted in tokens of gratitude to Philip and Alexander, since they
set up a \[statue of\] Lysimakhos also not so much out of goodwill
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eunoiā</span>\] as because
they thought it would serve their immediate ends.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.5">

This Lysimakhos was a Macedonian by birth and one of Alexander’s
bodyguards
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doruphoroi</span>\], whom
Alexander once in anger shut up in a chamber with a lion, and afterwards
found that he had overpowered the beast. Henceforth he always treated
him with respect, and honored him as much as the noblest Macedonians.
After the death of Alexander, Lysimakhos ruled those of the Thracians,
who are neighbors of the Macedonians, who had been under the sway of
Alexander and before him of Philip. These would comprise but a small
part of Thrace. If populations be compared with populations no people
except the Celts are more numerous than the Thracians taken all
together, and for this reason no one before the Romans reduced the whole
Thracian population. But the Romans have subdued all Thrace, and they
also hold such Celtic territory as is worth possessing, but they have
intentionally overlooked the parts that they consider useless through
excessive cold or barrenness.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.6">

Then Lysimakhos made war against his neighbors, first the Odrysai,
secondly the Getai and their king Dromikhaites. Engaging with men not
unversed in warfare and far his superiors in number, he himself escaped
from a position of extreme danger, but his son Agathokles, who was
serving with him then for the first time, was taken prisoner by the
Getai. Lysimakhos met with other reverses afterwards, and attaching
great importance to the capture of his son made peace with Dromikhaites,
yielding to the king of the Getai the parts of his empire beyond the
Istros, and, chiefly under compulsion, giving him his daughter in
marriage. Others say that not Agathokles but Lysimakhos himself was
taken prisoner, regaining his liberty when Agathokles made a treaty with
the king of the Getai on his behalf. On his return he married to
Agathokles Lysandra, the daughter of Ptolemy, son of Lagos, and of
Eurydikē.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.7">

He also crossed with a fleet to Asia (Minor) and helped to overthrow the
empire \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] of
Antigonos.[^37] And he founded the modern city of Ephesos, extending as
far as the coast, bringing to it as settlers people of Lebedos and
Kolophon, after destroying their cities, so that the iambic poet Phoenix
composed-a-lament
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thrēneîn</span>\] for the
capture of Kolophon. Mermesianax, the one who wrote
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] elegies
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">elegeia</span>\], was, I
think, no longer living, otherwise he too would certainly have been
moved by the taking of Kolophon to make-a-lament
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oduresthai</span>\].
Lysimakhos also went to war with Pyrrhos-son-of-Aiakidēs. Waiting for
his departure from Epeiros—Pyrrhos was of a very roving disposition—he
ravaged Epeiros until he reached the royal tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thēkai</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.9.8">

The next parts of the story are not credible
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pista</span>\] to me, but
Hieronymos of Kardia writes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] that he \[=
Lysimachus\] destroyed the tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thēkai</span>\] and cast out
the bones of the corpses. But this Hieronymos has a reputation generally
of being biased against all the kings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileîs</span>\] except for
Antigonos, and of being unfairly partial towards him. As to the
treatment of the tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] of the people
of Epeiros, it is perfectly plain that it was malice that made him
record that a Macedonian destroyed the tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thēkai</span>\] of the dead.
Besides, Lysimakhos was surely aware that they were the ancestors not of
Pyrrhos only but also of Alexander. In fact, Alexander was a native of
Epeiros and descended from the lineage of the Aiakidai on his mother’s
side, and the subsequent alliance between Pyrrhos and Lysimakhos proves
that even as enemies they were not irreconcilable. Possibly Hieronymos
had grievances against Lysimakhos, especially for his destroying the
city of the people of Kardia and founding Lysimakheia in its stead on
the isthmus of the Thracian Chersonesus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.10.1">

As long as Aridaios reigned, and after him Kassandros and his sons,
friendly relations continued between Lysimakhos and Macedon. But when
the kingdom devolved upon Demetrios, son of Antigonos, Lysimakhos,
henceforth expecting that war would be declared upon him by Demetrios,
resolved to take aggressive action. He was aware that Demetrios
inherited a tendency to aggrandize, and he also knew that he visited
Macedonia at the summons of Alexander and Kassandros, and on his arrival
murdered Alexander himself[^38] and ruled the Macedonians in his stead.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.10.2">

For these reasons he clashed with Demetrios at Amphipolis and came near
to being pushed out from Thrace,[^39] but after Pyrrhos came to his aid
he mastered Thrace and afterwards extended his empire at the expense of
the Nestians and Macedonians. The greater part of Macedonia was under
the control of Pyrrhos himself, who came from Epeiros with an army and
was at that time on friendly terms with Lysimakhos. When, however,
Demetrios crossed over into Asia (Minor) and made war on Seleukos, the
alliance between Pyrrhos and Lysimakhos lasted only as long as Demetrios
continued hostilities; when Demetrios submitted to Seleukos, the
friendship between Lysimakhos and Pyrrhos was broken, and when war broke
out Lysimakhos fought against Antigonos son of Demetrios and against
Pyrrhos himself, had much the better of the struggle, conquered
Macedonia and forced Pyrrhos to retreat to Epeiros.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.10.3">

Erotic-passion \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\]
has a way of bringing many calamities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sumphrorai</span>\] for
humans. Lysimakhos, although by this time of mature age and considered
happy \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eudaimōn</span>\] in
respect of his children, and although Agathokles had children by
Lysandra, nevertheless married Lysandra’s sister Arsinoe. This Arsinoe,
fearing for her children, lest on the death of Lysimakhos they should
fall into the hands of Agathokles, is said for this reason to have
plotted against Agathokles. People have already written
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] about how
Arsinoe got into a state of erotic-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\] for Agathokles,
and, being unsuccessful, they say that she plotted against his life.
They say also that Lysimakhos discovered later his wife’s machinations,
but by now, toward the end, he had no resources left, having lost all
who were near-and-dear
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">philoi</span>\] to him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.10.4">

Since Lysimakhos, then, entrusted to Arsinoe the murder of Agathokles,
Lysandra fled to Seleukos, taking along her children and her brothers,
who were taking refuge with Ptolemy and who finally adopted this course.
They were accompanied on their escape to Seleukos by Alexander, who was
the son of Lysimakhos by an Odrysian woman. So, going up to Babylon,
they entreated Seleukos to make war on Lysimakhos. And, at the same
time, Philetairos, to whom the property of Lysimakhos had been
entrusted, aggrieved at the death of Agathokles and suspicious of the
treatment he would receive at the hands of Arsinoe, seized
Pergamon-on-the-Kaïkos, and sending a herald offered both the property
and himself to Seleukos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.10.5">

Lysimakhos, hearing of all these things, lost no time in crossing into
Asia (Minor),[^40] and, taking the initiative, he attacked Seleukos,
suffered a severe defeat, and was killed. Alexander, his son by the
Odrysian woman, after interceding long with Lysandra, won possession of
his body and afterwards conveyed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] it to the
Chersonesus and buried it, where his tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] is still to be
seen between the district
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kōmē</span>\] of Kardia and
Paktye.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.1">

Such were the things that happened in connection with Lysimakhos. The
Athenians have also a likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of Pyrrhos.
This Pyrrhos was not related to Alexander, except by way of genealogy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genos</span>\]. Pyrrhos was
son of Aiakidēs, son of Arybbas, but Alexander was son of Olympias,
daughter of Neoptolemos, and the father of Neoptolemos and Arybbas was
Alketas, son of Tharypos. And from Tharypos to Pyrrhos, son of Achilles,
are fifteen generations
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">geneai</span>\]. Now, Pyrrhos
was the first who after the capture of Troy disdained to return to
Thessaly, but sailing to Epeiros dwelled there following the
oracular-pronouncements
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsmoi</span>\] of Helenos.
By Hermione Pyrrhos had no child, but by Andromache he had Molossos,
Pielos, and Pergamos, who was the youngest. Helenos also had a son,
Kestrinos, being married to Andromache after the killing of Pyrrhos at
Delphi.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.2">

Helenos on his death passed his rulership
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] to Molossos,
son of Pyrrhos, so that Kestrinos with volunteers from the people of
Epeiros took possession of the region beyond the river Thyamis, while
Pergamos crossed into Asia (Minor) and killed Areios, despot in
Teuthrania, who fought with him in single combat for the rulership
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\], and gave his
name to the city which is still called after him.[^41] For Andromache,
who accompanied him, there is still a hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] in the
city.[^42] Pielos remained behind in Epeiros, and to him as ancestor
Pyrrhos-son-of-Aiakidēs and his fathers traced their descent, and not to
Molossos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.3">

Down to the time of Alketas, son of Tharypos, Epeiros too was under one
king. But the sons of Alketas after a quarrel agreed to rule with equal
authority, remaining faithful to their compact; and afterwards, when
Alexander, son of Neoptolemos, died among the Leukanoi, and Olympias
returned to Epeiros through fear of Antipatros, it was Aiakidēs, son of
Arybbas, who continued in allegiance to Olympias and joined in her
campaign against Aridaios and the Macedonians, although the men of
Epeiros refused to accompany him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.4">

Olympias on her victory behaved in-unholy-ways
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hosia</span>\] in the
matter of the death of Aridaios, and in even more-unholy-ways
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hosia</span>\] with regard
to certain Macedonian men, and for this reason was considered to have
deserved her subsequent treatment at the hands of Kassandros; so
Aiakidēs at first was not received even by the people of Epeiros because
of their hatred of Olympias, and when afterwards they forgave him, his
return to Epeiros was next opposed by Kassandros. When a battle occurred
at Oineadai between Philip-brother-of-Kassandros and Aiakidēs, it was
Aiakidēs who was wounded and who shortly after met what was fated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò khreōn</span>\].[^43]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.5">

The people of Epeiros accepted Alketas as their king, being the son of
Arybbas and the elder brother of Aiakidēs, but of an uncontrollable
temper \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thūmos</span>\] and on
this account banished by his father. Immediately on his arrival he began
to take out his insanity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mainesthai</span>\] on the
people of Epeiros, until they rose up and put him and his children to
death at night. After killing him they brought back
Pyrrhos-son-of-Aiakidēs. No sooner had he arrived than Kassandros made
war on him, while he was young in years and before he had consolidated
his empire \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\].
When the Macedonians attacked him, Pyrrhos went to Ptolemy, son of
Lagos, in Egypt. Ptolemy gave him as wife the half-sister of his
children, and restored him by way of an Egyptian force.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.6">

The first of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] that Pyrrhos
attacked on becoming king were the people of Corcyra. He saw that the
island was near his own territory, and he did not wish others to have a
base from which to attack him. My account of Lysimakhos has already
related how he \[= Pyrrhos\] fared, after taking Corcyra, in his war
with Lysimakhos—how he expelled Demetrios and ruled Macedonia until he
was in turn expelled by Lysimakhos, the most important of his
achievements until he waged war against the Romans,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.11.7">

being the first Greek
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēn</span>\] we know of to
do so. For no further battle, it is said, took place between Aeneas and
Diomedes with his Argives. One of the many ambitions of the Athenians
was to reduce all Italy, but the disaster at Syracuse[^44] prevented an
encounter then with the Romans. Alexander, son of Neoptolemos, of the
same family as Pyrrhos but older, died among the Leukanoi before he
could engage the Romans in battle.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.12.1">

So Pyrrhos was the first to cross the Ionian Sea from Greece \[Hellas\]
to attack the Romans.[^45] And even he crossed on the invitation of the
people of Tarentum. For they were already involved in a war with the
Romans, but were no match for them unaided. Pyrrhos was already in their
debt, because they had sent a fleet to help him in his war with Corcyra,
but the most cogent arguments of the envoys of Tarentum were their
accounts of Italy, how its prosperity was equal to that of the whole of
Greece \[Hellas\], and their plea that it was unholy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hosion</span>\] to dismiss
them when they had come as friends and suppliants in their hour of need.
When the envoys urged these considerations, Pyrrhos remembered the
capture of Troy, which he took to be an omen of his success in the war,
as he was a descendant of Achilles making war upon a settlement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apoikiā</span>\] of Trojans.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.12.2">

Pleased with this proposal, and being a man who never lost time when
once he had made up his mind, he immediately proceeded to man war ships
and to prepare transports to carry horses and men-at-arms. There are
books \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">biblia</span>\] written
by men of no renown when it comes to writing-things-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-graphē</span>\], which are
called commentaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_emphasis">hupomnēmata</span>\]. When I read
these I marveled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaumazein</span>\] greatly
both at the personal bravery of Pyrrhos in battle, and also at the
forethought \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pronoia</span>\]
he displayed whenever a conflict was imminent. So, on this occasion also
when crossing to Italy with a fleet he eluded the observation of the
Romans, and for some time after his arrival they were unaware of his
presence; it was only when the Romans made an attack upon the people of
Tarentum that he appeared on the scene with his army, and his unexpected
assault naturally threw his enemies into confusion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.12.3">

And being perfectly aware that he was no match for the Romans, he
prepared to let loose against them his elephants. The first European to
acquire elephants was Alexander, after subduing Poros and the power of
the Indians; after his death others of the kings got them but Antigonos
more than any; Pyrrhos captured his beasts in the battle with Demetrios.
When on this occasion they came in sight the Romans were seized with
panic, and did not believe they were animals.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.12.4">

For although the use of ivory in arts and crafts all men obviously have
known for a long time, the actual beasts, before the Macedonians crossed
into Asia, nobody had seen at all except for the Indians themselves, for
the Libyans, and for their neighbors. This is proved by Homer, who
describes the couches and houses of the more prosperous kings as
ornamented with ivory, but never mentions the beast; but if he had seen
or heard about it he would, in my opinion, have been much more likely to
speak of it than of the battle between the dwarf-men and cranes.[^46]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.12.5">

Pyrrhos was brought over to Sicily by an embassy of the Syracusans. The
Carthaginians had crossed over and were destroying the Greek
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnides</span>\] cities,
and had set up a siege of Syracuse, the only city now remaining. When
Pyrrhos heard this from the envoys he abandoned Tarentum and the
Italiots on the coast, and crossing into Sicily forced the Carthaginians
to raise the siege of Syracuse. In his self-conceit, although the
Carthaginians, being Phoenicians of Tyre by ancient descent, were more
experienced seafarers than any other barbarian people of that day,
Pyrrhos was nevertheless encouraged to engage them in a naval battle,
employing the people of Epeiros, the majority of whom, even after the
capture of Troy, knew nothing of the sea nor even as yet how to use
salt. Witness the words of Homer in the
<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Odyssey</span>:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Nothing they know of <span custom-style="chs_verse_number">the
sea</span>, and they mix not salt with what they eat.[^47]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.1">

Defeated on this occasion, Pyrrhos retreated with the remainder of his
vessels to Tarentum. Here he met with a serious reverse. And his
withdrawal, for he knew that the Romans would not let him depart without
striking a blow, he contrived in the following manner. On his return
from Sicily and his defeat, he first sent various dispatches to Asia
(Minor) and to Antigonos, asking some of the kings for troops, some for
money, and Antigonos for both. When the envoys returned and their
dispatches were delivered, he summoned those in authority, whether from
Epeiros or from Tarentum, and without reading any of the dispatches
declared that reinforcements would come. A report spread quickly even to
the Romans that Macedonians and men from Asia (Minor) also were crossing
to the aid of Pyrrhos. The Romans, on hearing this, made no move, but
Pyrrhos, on the approach of that very night, crossed to the headlands of
the mountain called Keraunion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.2">

After the defeat in Italy, Pyrrhos gave his forces a rest and then
declared war on Antigonos, his chief ground of complaint being the
failure to send reinforcements to Italy. Overpowering the native troops
of Antigonos and his Gallic mercenaries he pursued them to the coast
cities, and himself reduced upper Macedonia and the Thessalians. The
extent of the fighting and the decisive character of the victory of
Pyrrhos are shown best by the Celtic armor dedicated in the sanctuary of
Itonian Athena between Pherai and Larisa, with this inscription on them:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

These shields did the Molossian one, as a gift to Itonian Athena,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.3">

hang up, Pyrrhos did, taking them from the bold Gauls \[Galatai\],

</div>

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

having destroyed the entire army of Antigonos. No big wonder
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thauma</span>\],

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

since the Aiakidai are masters of the spear, even now as also in the
past.

</div>

These shields then are here, but the shields of the Macedonians
themselves he dedicated to Dodonian Zeus. They too have an inscription:

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

These \[shields\] once ravaged the golden land of Asia,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

and they brought slavery upon the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\].

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Now ownerless they lie by the columns of the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Zeus,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

spoils from boastful Macedonia.

</div>

Pyrrhos came very near to reducing Macedonia entirely, but,

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.4">

being usually readier to do what came first to hand, he was prevented by
Kleonymos. This Kleonymos, who persuaded Pyrrhos to abandon his
Macedonian adventure and to go to the Peloponnesus, was a Lacedaemonian
who led a hostile army into the Lacedaemonian territory for a reason I
will relate after giving the descent of Kleonymos. Pausanias, who was in
command of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] at
Plataea,[^48] was the father of Pleistoanax, he of Pausanias, and he of
Kleombrotos, who was killed at Leuktra fighting against Epameinondas and
the Thebans. Kleombrotos was the father of Agesipolis and Kleomenes,
and, Agesipolis dying without issue, Kleomenes ascended the throne.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.5">
