Kleomenes had two sons, the elder being Akrotatos and the younger
Kleonymos. Now Akrotatos died first; and when afterwards Kleomenes died,
a claim to the throne was put forward by Areus son of Akrotatos, and
Kleonymos took steps to induce Pyrrhos to enter the country. Before the
battle of Leuktra[^49] the Lacedaemonians had suffered no disaster, so
that they even refused to admit that they had yet been defeated in a
land battle. For Leonidas, they said, had won the victory,[^50] but his
followers were insufficient for the entire destruction of the Persians;
the achievement of Demosthenes and the Athenians on the island of
Sphakteria[^51] was no victory, but only a trick in war.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.6">

Their first reverse took place in Boeotia, and they afterwards suffered
a severe defeat at the hands of Antipatros and the Macedonians.[^52]
Thirdly the war with Demetrios[^53] came as an unexpected misfortune to
their land. Invaded by Pyrrhos and seeing a hostile army for the fourth
time, they arrayed themselves to meet it along with the Argives and
Messenians who had come as their allies. Pyrrhos won the day, and came
near to capturing Sparta without further fighting, but desisted for a
while after ravaging the land and carrying off plunder.[^54] The
citizens prepared for a siege, and Sparta even before this in the war
with Demetrios had been fortified with deep trenches and strong stakes,
and at the most vulnerable points with buildings as well.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.7">

Just about this time, while the Laconian war was dragging on, Antigonos,
having recovered the Macedonian cities, hastened to the Peloponnesus
being well aware that if Pyrrhos were to reduce Lacedaemon and the
greater part of the Peloponnesus, he would not return to Epeiros but to
Macedonia to make war there again. When Antigonos was about to lead his
army from Argos into Laconia, Pyrrhos himself reached Argos. Victorious
once more he dashed into the city along with the exiles, and his
formation not unnaturally was broken up.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.8">

When the fighting was now taking place by sanctuaries and houses, and in
the narrow lanes, between detached bodies in different parts of the
city, Pyrrhos, left by himself, was wounded in the head. It is said that
his death[^55] was caused by a blow from a tile thrown by a woman. The
Argives however declare that it was not a woman who killed him but
Demeter in the likeness of a woman. This is what the Argives themselves
relate about his end, and Lykeas, the exegete
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ex-hēgetēs</span>\] for the
local-population
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrioi</span>\], has also
said so in hexameters
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\]. They \[= the
Argives\] have a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Demeter,
built in accordance with an oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrē-</span>\], on the spot
where Pyrrhos died,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.13.9">

and, in there, Pyrrhos is buried. I consider it a wonder
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thauma</span>\] that, of those
who are called Aiakidai, three met their end
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teleutē</span>\] in the same
kinds of way through the agency of the god
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ek tou theou</span>\]—if, as
Homer says, Achilles was killed by Alexander, son of Priam, and by
Apollo, and if the people of Delphi were bidden by the Pythia to slay
Pyrrhos, son of Achilles, and if the end of the son of Aiakidēs was such
as the Argives say and as Lykeas has said-in-poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]. What
Hieronymos of Kardia has written
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\], however, is
different, since a man who associates with royalty cannot help being
partial in what he writes up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-graphein</span>\]. If
Philistos had just-cause \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā
dikaiā</span>\] in suppressing the most unholy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hosia</span>\] deeds of
Dionysius, because he expected to be restored to Syracuse from exile,
surely Hieronymos may be fully forgiven for writing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] to please
Antigonos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.1">

In this way did the period when the people of Epeiros reached their
zenith come-to-a-catastrophic-end
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kata-strephein</span>\].
Entering the Odeum
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ōideion</span>\], one finds
situated there, among other things that are also worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], a figure of
Dionysus. Nearby is a fountain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\] called
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Enneakrounos</span> \[‘Nine
Streams’\]; the way it is now is the way it had been arranged
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kosmeîsthai</span>\] by
Peisistratos. Unlike the cisterns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phreata</span>\] that are
found all over the city, this fountain is really a freshwater spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\]. Looming over
the fountain \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\]
are two shrines \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāoi</span>\].
One of them is sacred to Demeter and the Maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Korē</span>\]. Inside the
other one, a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Triptolemos
has been set up. I will write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] the things
that pertain to him \[= Triptolemos\], but I will omit whatever part of
the things-that-are-said
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] pertains to
Dēiopē.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.2">

The Greeks \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]
who dispute
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">amphisbēteîn</span>\], more
than anyone else, the claims made by the people of Athens regarding
their antiquity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhaiotēs</span>\] and also
regarding the gifts they say they have received from the gods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\], are the people
of Argos, just as among those who are barbarians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">barbaroi</span>\] the
Egyptians compete with the Phrygians. So, it is said \[by the people of
Argos\] that when Demeter came to Argos she was received by Pelasgos
into his home \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikos</span>\],
and that Khrysanthis, knowing about the abduction
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpagē</span>\] of the Maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Korē</span>\],
related-the-story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">di-hēgeîsthai</span>\] to her.
They say that, at a later point, Trokhilos, revealer-of-the-mysteries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierophantēs</span>\], fled
from Argos because of the enmity of Agenor, came to Attica, and married
a woman of Eleusis, by whom he had two children, Eubouleus and
Triptolemos. This is what-is-said
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] by the people
of Argos. But the people of Athens and those who inhabit Athens with
them \[…\] know that Triptolemos, son of Keleus, was the first to
sow-seed \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">speirein</span>\] for
getting cultivated grain-to-be-harvested
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.3">

There are on one hand verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] of Musaeus—if in
fact even these verses really belong to Musaeus—that say, in the singing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">āidesthai</span> =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aeidesthai</span>\], that
Triptolemos is the son of Ōkeanos and Earth. There are on the other hand
verses of Orpheus—again, I do not think that these verses belong to
Orpheus—saying that Eubouleus and Triptolemos are sons of Dysaules, and
that because they made-revelations
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēnuein</span>\] to Demeter
about her daughter, she gave them as her gift the sowing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">speirein</span>\] of
grains-to-be-harvested
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpoi</span>\]. But
Khoirilos, an Athenian, who made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] a drama
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drâma</span>\] called
<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Alopē</span>, says that Kerkyon
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">and</span> Triptolemos were
brothers, that their mother was the daughter of Amphiktyon, and that the
father of Triptolemos was Raros—while the father of Kerkyon was
Poseidon.I was getting ready to go further in connection with this
thing-that-is-said
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\], telling about
however many things the sacred-place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] has available
for interpretation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ex-hēgēsis</span>\]—I mean,
the sacred place in Athens that is
called <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Eleusinion</span>, but a
vision \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">opsis</span>\] that
came from a dream
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oneiar</span>\] held me back.
As for things that it is divinely-allowed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hosion</span>\] to write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] in
addressing everyone, I will turn \[implied
-<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">trepesthai</span>\] to these
things while turning away
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-trepesthai</span>\] from
other things.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.4">

In front of the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\], where is also
the statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Triptolemos, is a bronze bull being led as it were to sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\], and what has
been made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pe-poíētai</span>\]
there is a seated figure of Epimenides of Knossos, who they say came to
a field \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agros</span>\],
entered a cave
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">spēlaion</span>\] there, and
fell-asleep
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koimâsthai</span>\]. The sleep
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hupnos</span>\] did not leave
him before the fortieth year, and afterwards he made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] and purified
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kathairein</span>\] Athens and
other cities. But Thales, who stopped the plague
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nosos</span>\] for the
Lacedaemonians, was not related to Epimenides in any way, and did not
belong to the same city. The one I mentioned first was from Knossos, but
Thales was from Gortyn, according to Polymnastos of Kolophon, who
composed \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]
verses \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] with
reference to him for the Lacedaemonians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.5">

Still farther off is a shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Eúkleia</span> ‘she of good
glory \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kleos</span>\]’, this
too being a dedication
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēma</span>\] having to do
with \[the victory over\] the Persians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mēdoi</span>\] who had landed
at Marathon. It is in-responsiveness-to
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> + dative case\]
this victory \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nīkē</span>\]
that the Athenians have- their most lofty -thoughts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phroneîn</span> ‘have
thoughts’ + <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">malista</span> ‘most
of all’\]. A special example is Aeschylus. When the completion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teleutē</span>\] of his life
was coming into view for him, he reminisced
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmoneuein</span>\] not about
any of his other deeds, even though he had reached such heights of glory
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] with his poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēsis</span>\] and with his
participation in the naval battles of Artemision and at Salamis.
Instead, he just wrote down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] \[in an
epigram\] his name, his father’s name, the name of his city of origin
\[= Athens\], and how he had as his witnesses for affirming his
manly-valor \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andreiā</span>\]
the grove \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">alsos</span>\] at
Marathon—and the Persians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mēdoi</span>\] who had landed
there.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.6">

Looming over the Kerameikos and the portico
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\] called the
King’s Portico \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Stoā</span>
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Baslileios</span>\] is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Hephaistos.
No wonder \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thauma</span>\], I
thought, that next to it stands a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena,
because I know the thing-that-is-said
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\]
in-responsiveness-to
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> + dative case\]
Erikhthonios. And when I saw that the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena had
gray \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">glaukoi</span>\] eyes I
made-inquiries-and-found-out
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heuriskein</span>\] that the
myth \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mūthos</span>\] comes
from the Libyans. For it has been said by the Libyans that she is the
daughter of Poseidon and of the \[personified\] lake
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">limnē</span>\] Tritonis, so
that, for this reason, she has gray
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">glaukoi</span>\] eyes like
Poseidon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.14.7">

Nearby is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Aphrodite
the celestial one
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Ouraniā</span>\]; the first
humans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] to
establish the custom of worshipping
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sebesthai</span>\] her were
the Assyrians, and then, after the Assyrians, the Paphians of Cyprus and
the Phoenicians who live at Askalon in Palestine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Palaistinē</span>\]; it is
from the Phoenicians that the people of Kythēra learned the practice of
worshipping \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sebesthai</span>\]
her. Among the Athenians it was Aigeus who established
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kathistasthai</span>\] the
practice, who thought that he was childless (he had, in fact, no
children at the time) and that his sisters had suffered their misfortune
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sumphorā</span>\] because of
the wrath \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēnīma</span>\] of
Aphrodite the celestial one
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Ouraniā</span>\]. The statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], as it exists
even in my time, is of Parian marble and is the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] of Pheidias.
One of the Athenian demes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] is that of the
Athmoneis, who say that Porphyrion, an earlier king than Aktaios,
founded their sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the
celestial one
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Ouraniā</span>\]. But the
traditions current among the demes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] often differ
altogether from those of the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.15.1">

As one goes to the portico
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\] that they call
painted \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poikilē</span>\],
because of its paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\], there is a
bronze statue of Hermes of-the-Marketplace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agoraios</span>\], and near it
a gate \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pulē</span>\]. Placed
over it \[= the gate\] is a trophy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropaion</span>\] erected by
the Athenians, who in a cavalry action overcame Pleistarkhos, to whose
command his brother Kassandros had entrusted his cavalry and
mercenaries. This portico
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\] contains \[wall
paintings that represent\], first, the Athenians arrayed against the
Lacedaemonians at Oinoe in the Argive territory. What has been painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphesthai</span>\] is not
the critical-point
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akmē</span>\] of the struggle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōn</span>\] nor when the
action \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] had
advanced as far as the display
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epideixis</span>\] of deeds of
valor, but the beginning of the fight when the combatants were about to
close in on each other.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.15.2">

On the middle wall are \[wall paintings that represent\] the Athenians
and Theseus fighting with the Amazons. So it seems that only the women
did not lose through their defeats their reckless courage in the face of
danger; Themiskyra was taken by Hēraklēs, and afterwards the army that
they \[= the Amazons\] dispatched to Athens was destroyed, but
nevertheless they \[= the Amazons\] came to Troy to fight all the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] as well as
the Athenians themselves. Next after the Amazons are shown the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] when they
have taken Troy \[Ilion\], and the kings assembled on account of the
outrage \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tolmēma</span>\]
committed by Ajax against Cassandra. The painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] includes Ajax
himself, Cassandra, and other captive women.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.15.3">

At the concluding part of the painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] are
\[represented\] the men who fought at Marathon, namely, the men from
\[the city of\] Plataea-in-Boeotia and the men from all the
territory-of-Athens \[= Attica\]. They are at the moment of coming into
contact in hand-to-hand combat with the barbarians. At this point, the
two sides are evenly matched for the action
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\], but then, in a
close-up of the battle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">makhē</span>\], the barbarians
are starting to turn and run, heading for the marshland
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">helos</span>\] and crowding
each other \[into the morass\]. At the outer edges of the painting are
\[represented\] the \[beached\] ships of the Phoenician navy and the
Greeks \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] who
are slaughtering those of the barbarians who are scrambling to climb on
board. And at this point is painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphesthai</span>\] also the
hero \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\] by the
name of Marathon, after whom the plain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pedíon</span>\] called
Marathon gets its name. Also represented
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikazesthai</span>\] is
Theseus as he appeared when he was coming back up from under the earth.
Also, Athena and Hēraklēs. I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\], the people of
Marathon were the first to establish-the-custom-of-venerating
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] Hēraklēs as
a god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]. Featured
most prominently in the painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] are
Kallimakhos, who had been elected commander-in-chief
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polem-arkhos</span>\] by the
Athenians, and Miltiades, one of the generals
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratēgoi</span>\]. Also
\[featured is\] a hero
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\] called
Ekhetlos, about whom I will make mention
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] at a later
point as well.[^56]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.15.4">

Here are dedicated bronze shields, and some have an inscription
\[saying\] that they are taken from the Skiōnaioi and their allies,[^57]
while others, smeared with pitch lest they should be worn by age and
rust, are said to be those of the Lacedaemonians who were taken
prisoners in the island of Sphakteria.[^58]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.16.1">

Here are placed bronze statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\], one, in
front of the portico
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoā</span>\], of Solon, who
wrote \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] the
laws \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomoi</span>\] for the
Athenians,[^59] and, a little farther away, one of Seleukos, whose
future prosperity was foreshadowed by signs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeia</span>\] that were not
at all unclear
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphanes</span>-\]. When he was
about to set forth from Macedonia with Alexander, and was sacrificing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] at Pella to
Zeus, the wood \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xula</span>\]
that was placed on the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] moved
all-by-itself
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">automato-</span>\] toward the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] and
caught-fire
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">haptesthai</span>\] without
the application of fire. After Alexander died, Seleukos, in fear of
Antigonos, who had arrived at Babylon, fled to Ptolemy, son of Lagos,
and then returned again to Babylon. On his return he overcame the army
of Antigonos and killed Antigonos himself, afterwards capturing
Demetrios, son of Antigonos, who had advanced with an army.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.16.2">

After these successes, which were shortly followed by the fall of
Lysimakhos, he \[= Seleukos\] entrusted to his son Antiokhos all his
empire \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] in Asia
(Minor), and himself proceeded rapidly towards Macedonia, having with
him an army both of Greeks \[Hellēnes\] and of barbarians. But Ptolemy,
brother of Lysandra, had taken refuge with him from Lysimakhos; this man
\[= Ptolemy\], who was in any case prone to be-daring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tolmân</span>\] and for this
reason was called Thunderbolt
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Keraunos</span>\],
\[accomplished quite a daring act\] when the army of Seleukos had
advanced as far as Lysimakheia: he \[= Ptolemy\] killed Seleukos by
stealth. Then he turned over to the \[other\] kings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileîs</span>\] his
possessions \[= the possessions of Seleukos\],[^60] while he \[=
Ptolemy\] ruled-as-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\] over
Macedonia until, being as far as we know the first of the kings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileîs</span>\] to dare
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tolmân</span>\] to face the
Gauls \[Galatai\] in battle, he was killed by thesebarbarians.[^61] The
empire \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] was
restored-to-safety
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōzesthai</span>\] by
Antigonos son of Demetrios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.16.3">

I am persuaded that Seleukos was the most righteous
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikaios</span>\], and in
particular the most pious-in-ritual
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eu-sebēs</span>\] of the kings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">baslileîs</span>\]. For one
thing, it was Seleukos who sent-back
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kata-pempein</span>\] to
Brankhidai for the people of Miletus the bronze Apollo that had been
conveyed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-komizesthai</span>\] by
Xerxes to Ecbatana in Persia. For another thing, when he founded
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikizein</span>\] Seleukeia on
the river Tigris and brought to it Babylonians as settlers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sunoikoi</span>\], he spared
the wall \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\] of
Babylon as well as the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Bēl, near
which he permitted the Chaldaeans to settle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.17.1">

In the Agora \[‘Marketplace’\] of the Athenians there are things that
are not meaningful
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-sēma</span>\] to all
\[though they are meaningful to me\]. Among such things is an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] \[sacred\] to
Pity \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Eleos</span>\]
\[personified\]. Of all the other gods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\] he \[=
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Eleos</span>\] is the most
helpful \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ōphelimos</span>\] in
the life \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bios</span>\]
of-humans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpinos</span>\]
and in the vicissitudes of their affairs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pragmata</span>\], but only
the Athenians, alone among the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], assign
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nemein</span>\] to him \[=
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Eleos</span>\] honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] \[of worship\].
And they \[= the Athenians\] have institutionalized not only those
things that pertain to love-of-humanity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">philanthrōpiā</span>\] but
they also piously-engage-in-rituals
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eusebeîn</span>\] more than
the others. I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] they also have an
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\]
\[sacred\] to Decency
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Aidōs</span>\]
\[personified\], one to Special-Wording
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Phēmē</span>\]
\[personified\], and one to Initiative
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hormē</span>\]
\[personified\]. It is clear
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēla</span>\], visibly
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enargōs</span>\] so, that
those who excel in piously-engaging-in-ritual
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eu-sebeîn</span>\] have an
equally great share in good
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēstē</span>\] fortune
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tukhē</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.17.2">

Not far from the Agora is a gymnasium that is named after Ptolemy, its
founder. In this gymnasium are stone Hermai worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] and a likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] in bronze of
Ptolemy. Here also is Juba the Libyan and Khrysippos[^62] of Soloi.
Close by the gymnasium is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Theseus,
where are paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] of Athenians
battling Amazons. \[The story of\] this war
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polemos</span>\] has also been
crafted \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîsthai</span>\]
for them on the shield
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aspis</span>\] of their
\[statue of\] Athena and upon the base
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bathron</span>\] of the
\[statue of\] Olympian Zeus. There has also been painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphesthai</span>\] in the
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Theseus the battle between the Centaurs and the Lapithai. Theseus has
already killed a Centaur, but, for the others \[= the other fighters\],
the fighting is still undecided.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.17.3">

The painting \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\]
on the third wall \[of the sanctuary of Theseus\] is not clear
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">saphēs</span>\] for those who
have not inquired-about-and-learned
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">punthanesthai</span>\] what is
said \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legein</span>\]. It \[=
the lack of clarity\] is due partly to the passage of time and partly to
the fact that Mikon \[the painter\] did not paint
\[<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">graphein</span>\] the entirety of
what is said to have happened. When Minos was bringing to Crete Theseus
and the rest of the group-that-was sent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stolos</span>\], which was a
group of young-ones
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paides</span>\], he \[=
Minos\] conceived a passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erâsthai</span>\] for
Periboia, and, when Theseus opposed him with the greatest kind of
opposition \[imaginable\], he \[= Minos\] got angry and hurled insults
at him \[= Theseus\], saying that he \[= Theseus\] was not the son of
Poseidon, claiming that he \[= Theseus\] could not bring-back-to-safety
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-sōzein</span>\] for him
the signet-ring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sphrāgis</span>\] that he \[=
Minos\] happened to be wearing, if he \[= Minos\] threw it into the sea.
Saying these things, Minos is said to have thrown the signet-ring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sphrāgis</span>\], but they
say that Theseus came up \[for air\] from out of the sea holding that
signet-ring \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sphrāgis</span>\]
and holding also a gold garland
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanos</span>\] that
Amphitrite gave him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.17.4">

With regard to the end
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teleutē</span>\] of Theseus
many things have been said, and these things are not \[mutually\]
consistent. They say he was kept tied-down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">deesthai</span>\] until he was
brought-back \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-agein</span>\]
by Hēraklēs \[to the light of day\], but, of all the things I heard, the
most believable
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pithanon</span>\] is as
follows. Theseus invaded Thesprotia to carry off the wife of the
Thesprotian king, and in this way lost the greater part of his army, and
both he and Peirithoös—he too was taking part in the expedition, being
eager for the marriage—were taken captive. The Thesprotian king kept
them tied-down \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">deein</span>\]
at Kikhyros.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.17.5">

Among the things worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] at Thesprotia
are a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Zeus at
Dodona and an oak
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phēgos</span>\] sacred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierā</span>\] to the god
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]. Near Kikhyros
is a lake called Akherousia, and a river called Akheron. There is also
Kokytos, a stream of water
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hudōr</span>\] that is
the-farthest-away-from-giving-any-pleasure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aterpestaton</span>\]. I think
it was because Homer had seen these places that he acted boldly in
putting into his poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēsis</span>\] the things
having to do with Hadēs, and gave to the rivers there the names of those
in Thesprotia. While Theseus was thus held-back
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ekhesthai</span>\], the sons
of Tyndareus \[= the Dioskouroi\] led their armed forces against
Aphidna, captured it, and restored Menestheus to the kingship.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.17.6">

Now Menestheus took no account of the children of Theseus, who had
secretly withdrawn to Elephenor in Euboea, but he was aware that
Theseus, if ever he was-brought-back-to-safety
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-komizesthai</span>\] from
Thesprotia, would be a powerful antagonist, and so he curried favor with
the people \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\],
with the result that Theseus, when he had been
brought-back-home-to-safety
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-sōzesthai</span>\], was
expelled \[after his homecoming\]. Theseus now set-off-on-a-voyage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stellesthai</span>\] to
\[reach a man called\] Deukalion in Crete. Being carried off-course by
winds to the island of Skyros he was treated splendidly by the
inhabitants, thanks to the fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] of his lineage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genos</span>\] and to the
worthiness of his own achievements. For this very reason, Lykomedes
plotted his death. And-from-what-I-have-just-said-you-can-now-see-why
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">men dē</span>\] the Athenians
had their hero-precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēkos</span>\] \[of Theseus\].
This was after the Persians landed at Marathon. It was when Kimon, son
of Miltiades, removed the population of Skyros, thus exacting
vindication \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikē</span>\] for
the death of Theseus, and brought-to-safety
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] his bones to
Athens.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.1">

The sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\]
of the Dioskouroi is ancient. They themselves are represented as
standing, while their sons are seated on horses. Here Polygnotus[^63]
painted \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] the
marriage of the daughters of Leukippos, which was \[a story that was\]
pertinent to them \[= the Dioskouroi\], while Mikon painted those who
sailed with Jason to the land of Kolkhis. He \[=Mikon\] focused his
\[artistic\] effort on Akastos and the horses of Akastos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.2">

Looming over the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the
Dioskouroi is a sacred-precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] of Aglauros.
It was to Aglauros and her sisters, Herse and Pandrosos, that they say
Athena gave Erikhthonios, whom she had hidden in a box
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kibōtos</span>\], forbidding
them to pry curiously into what was entrusted to their charge.
Pandrosos, they say, obeyed, but the other two opened the box
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kibōtos</span>\], and went mad
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mainesthai</span>\] when they
saw Erikhthonios, and they threw themselves down the steepest part of
the Acropolis. Here it was that the Persians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mēdoi</span>\] climbed \[up
the Acropolis\] and killed the Athenians who thought that they
understood the oracle[^64] better than did Themistocles, and fortified
the Acropolis with logs and stakes.[^65]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.3">

Close by is the Prytaneion \[‘City Hall’\], in which the laws of Solon
are inscribed, and statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] are placed
of the goddesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] Eirene
\[‘Peace’\] and Hestia \[‘Hearth’\], while among the statues-of-humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\] is
Autolykos, a contestant in the pankration.[^66] And I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] the likenesses of
Miltiades and Themistocles have had their inscriptions reinscribed to
refer to a Roman and a Thracian.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.4">

As one descends from here to the lower part of the city, there is a
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Serapis, whose worship the Athenians introduced from Ptolemy. Of the
Egyptian sanctuaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] of Serapis the
most famous is at Alexandria, the oldest at Memphis. Into the second of
these two neither stranger nor priest may enter, until they
make-a-funeral-for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaptein</span>\] Apis. Not
far from the sanctuary of Serapis is the place where they say that
Peirithoös and Theseus made their pact before setting forth to
Lacedaemon and afterwards to Thesprotia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.5">

Close by is built a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Eileithuia,
who they say came from the Hyperboreans to Delos as a helper
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">boēthoos</span>\] to Leto in
her labor; and from Delos the name spread to other populations. The
people of Delphi sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] to Eileithuia
and sing a hymn
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">humnos</span>\] of Olen. But
the Cretans customarily-think
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] that
Eileithuia was born at Amnisos in the territory of Knossos, and that
Hērā was her mother. Only among the Athenians are the wooden-figures
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\] of Eileithuia
draped \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kaluptesthai</span>\]
all the way to the feet. The women told me that two \[of these
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\] are Cretan, being
offerings \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēmata</span>\]
of Phaedra, and that the third
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\], which is the
oldest, Erysikhthon conveyed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] from Delos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.6">

Before one enters the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Olympian
Zeus—Hadrian ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] of the
Romans dedicated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anatithenai</span>\] the
temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] and the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] \[of
Zeus\], so worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], which in size
exceeds all other statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] except for
the colossi \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kolossoi</span>\]
in Rhodes and in Rome, and is made of ivory and gold with an artistic
skill \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\] that is
remarkable when the size is taken into account—before one enters, as I
say, there are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\] of Hadrian,
two of Thasian stone, two of Egyptian. In front of the columns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kiones</span>\] stand bronze
statues that the Athenians call
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apoikoi poleis</span>. The whole
enclosure \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\]
\[of the precinct\] is about four stadium-lengths, and it is full of
statues; for every city has dedicated a likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] Hadrian, but
the Athenians have surpassed them all in dedicating
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anatithenai</span>\], in the
back part of the temple, the colossus
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kolossos</span>\] \[of Zeus\],
so worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.7">

Within the enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] are
antiquities: a bronze Zeus, a shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Kronos and
Rhea, and a sacred-precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] of Earth
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Gē</span>\] surnamed Olympian
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Olumpiā</span>\]. There is an
opening in the floor here, which is the width of a cubit, and they say
that it was here that the water flowed off after the cataclysm that
occurred in the time of Deukalion, and into it they cast every year
ground wheat mixed with honey.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.8">

On top of a column
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kiōn</span>\] is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andrias</span>\] of Isocrates,
in whose memory \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\]
three things are to be noted: his being most-painstaking
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiponōtatos</span>\] in
continuing to have students
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mathētai</span>\] up to the
end of his ninety-eight years, his being most-moderate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōphronestatos</span>\] in
keeping aloof from politics
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">politeiā</span>\] and from
officiousness in public-affairs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koina</span>\], and his being
most-devoted-to-freedom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eleutherōtatos</span>\] in
dying a voluntary death, distressed as he was at the news of the battle
at Khairōneia.[^67] There are also statues in Phrygian marble of
Persians supporting a bronze tripod; both the figures and the tripod are
worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\]. The ancient
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Olympian Zeus the Athenians say was built by Deukalion, and they show as
a sign \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeion</span>\]—that
Deukalion resided
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in Athens—a
tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] that is
not far from the present temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.18.9">

Hadrian constructed other buildings also for the Athenians: a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Hērā and Zeus
Panhellēnios \[‘belonging to all Hellenes’\], a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] that was
common \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koinon</span>\] to all
the gods, and, most famous of all, a hundred columns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kiones</span>\] of Phrygian
marble. The walls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toikhoi</span>\] too are
constructed of the same material as the porticoes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stoai</span>\]. And there are
rooms there adorned with a gilded roof and with alabaster stone, as well
as with statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] and
paintings \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\]. In
them are kept books
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">biblia</span>\]. There is also
a gymnasium named after Hadrian; of this too the columns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kiones</span>\] are a hundred
in number, from the Libyan quarries.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.19.1">

Close to the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Olympian Zeus
is a statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
the Pythian Apollo. There is also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Apollo
surnamed Delphinios. They say that when the temple was finished, with
the exception of the roof, Theseus arrived in the city, unknown as yet
to everybody. When he came to the temple of the Delphinian, wearing a
tunic \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khitōn</span>\] that
reached to his feet and with his hair neatly plaited
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">plekesthai</span>\], those who
were building the roof by way of mockery
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khleuasiā</span>\] inquired
why a girl \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\]
who was in the right season
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hōrā</span>\] for getting
married was wandering around all by herself. The only answer that
Theseus made was to unyoke, it is said, the oxen from a wagon
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hamaxa</span>\] close by, and
to throw it higher than the roof of the temple they were building.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.19.2">

Concerning the place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōríon</span>\] called The
Gardens \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kēpoi</span>\], and
the temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Aphrodite, there is no word
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] about them,
nothing that is told
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legesthai</span>\]—nor about
the Aphrodite that stands near the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]. Now the shape
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\] of it is
tetragonal, like that of the Hermai, and the inscription
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epigramma</span>\] indicates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmainein</span>\] that
Aphrodite the celestial one
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Ouraniā</span>\] is the oldest
of what are called the Fates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Moirai</span>\]. And the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Aphrodite in the Gardens
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kēpoi</span>\] is the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] of Alkamenes.
It is one of those few things that are most worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] in Athens.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.19.3">

There is also the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Hēraklēs,
called ‘Brightness of the Dog’ \[Kynosarges\]; the things having to do
with the bright-white
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">leukē</span>\] dog
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kuōn</span>\] may be known by
reading \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epilegesthai</span>\]
\[the pronouncement of\] the oracle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsmos</span>\]. There are
altars \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmoi</span>\] of
Hēraklēs and Hebe, who they customarily-think
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] is the
daughter of Zeus and lives with
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-oikeîn</span>\] Hēraklēs.
An altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] has
been built to Alkmene and to Iolaos, who shared-in-labors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-poneîn</span>\] with
Hēraklēs with regard to most of his deeds
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\]. The Lyceum
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Lukeion</span>\] has its name
from Lykos \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Lukos</span>\], the
son of Pandion, but it was considered sacred to Apollo from the
beginning down to my time, and here was the god first named Lykios
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Lukios</span>\]. It is said
that the Termilai also, to whom Lykos came when he fled from Aigeus,
were called Lykioi
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Lukioi</span>\] after him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.19.4">

Behind the Lyceum is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\][^68] of Nisos,
who was killed while king of Megara by Minos, and he \[= his body\] was
conveyed \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] by
the Athenians to this place, and he was buried here. About this Nisos
the word \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] is
that his hair was purple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">porphurai</span>\], and that
it had-to-happen
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrē-</span>\] that he would
die if it was cut off. When the Cretans attacked the land \[of Megara\],
they captured by assault the other cities of the region of Megara, but
Nisaia, where Nisos had taken refuge, they besieged. It is said that it
was here that the daughter of Nisos, conceiving a passion for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erasthēnai</span>\] Minos, cut
off her father’s hair.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.19.5">

Anyway, they say that it happened this way. As for the rivers that flow
through the land of the Athenians, they are the Ilissos and its
tributary the Eridanos, the name of which is the same as that of the
Celtic river. This Ilissos is the river by which Oreithyia was
playfully-dancing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paizein</span>\] when, as they
say, she was abducted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazesthai</span>\] by the
North Wind \[Boreas\]. With Oreithyia he \[= Boreas\] lived
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-oikeîn</span>\], and
because of the tie-as-in-laws
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kēdos</span>\] between him and
the Athenians he helped them by destroying most of the barbarians’
warships \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">triēreis</span>\].
The Athenians concede that the Ilissos is sacred to other deities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\] as well, and on
its banks is an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of the Muses of
Ilissos. The place too is pointed out
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">deiknusthai</span>\] where the
Peloponnesians killed Kodros, son of Melanthos and king of Athens.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.19.6">

Across the Ilissos is a place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōríon</span>\] called Agrai
and a temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Artemis <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Agroterā</span>. They
say that Artemis first hunted here when she came from Delos, and for
this reason the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] holds a bow
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxon</span>\]. A marvel
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thauma</span>\] to the eyes,
though not so conducive
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epagōgon</span>\] to hear of,
is a race-course
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stadion</span>\] of white
marble, the size of which can best be estimated from the fact that
beginning in a crescent on the heights above the Ilissos it descends in
two straight lines to the river banks. This was built by Herodes, an
Athenian, and the greater part of the Pentelic quarry was used up in its
construction.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.1">

Leading from the Prytaneion \[‘City Hall’\] is a road called Tripods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Tripodes</span>\]. The place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōríon</span>\] takes its
name from the shrines
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāoi</span>\], large enough to
hold the tripods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tripodes</span>\] that stand
upon them, of bronze, and containing works of artisanship that are most
worthy of remembering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\], including a
Satyr, of which Praxiteles is said to have thought-of
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phroneîn</span>\] very highly.
Once upon a time, Phryne asked him which of his works
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\] was the most
beautiful of them all, and they say that he agreed to give that one as a
gift \[to her\], but he refused to say which of his works appeared to
him to be the most beautiful of them all. Well, a slave of Phryne rushed
up to Praxiteles saying that a fire had broken out in his building and
that the greater number of his works
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\] were lost,
though not all were destroyed.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.2">

Praxiteles at once started to rush out the door saying that his labor
was all lost if in fact the fire
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phlox</span>\] had caught his
Satyr and his Love \[Eros\]. But Phryne ordered him to stay and be of
good courage, for he had suffered no grievous loss, but had been trapped
into confessing which were the most beautiful of his works. So, Phryne
chose the statue of Love \[Eros\]; meanwhile, a Satyr is in the temple
of Dionysus close by—a boy holding out a cup. The Love \[Eros\] standing
with him and the Dionysus were made by Thymilos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.3">

The oldest sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Dionysus is
near the theater. Within the enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] are two
temples \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāoi</span>\] and two
statues of Dionysus, the Eleuthereus \[‘Deliverer’\] and the one that
Alkamenes made of ivory and gold. There are paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] here. One of
them shows Dionysus bringing up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-agein</span>\] Hephaistos
to the sky \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ouranos</span>\].
And the following things are also said about this by the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]: Hephaistos,
when he was born, was thrown down by Hērā. In revenge, he sent to her as
a gift a golden throne
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thronos</span>\] with
invisible bonds
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">desmoi</span>\]. When Hērā sat
down she was held bound, and Hephaistos refused to listen to any other
of the gods except for Dionysus—in him he placed the fullest trust—and
after making him drunk Dionysus brought him to the sky
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ouranos</span>\]. Also painted
\[on the wall painting\] are Pentheus and Lycurgus (Lukourgos) paying
the penalty \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikē</span>\] for
having committed-outrage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hubrizein</span>\] against
Dionysus; also Ariadne, asleep; Theseus, departing by sea; and Dionysus,
arriving to abduct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazein</span>\] Ariadne.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.4">

Near the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Dionysus
and the theater is a structure that is said to be a replica
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mīmēsis</span>\] of the tent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skēnē</span>\] of Xerxes. It
has been rebuilt, for the old building was burned down by the Roman
general \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratēgos</span>\]
Sulla when he captured Athens.[^69] The cause
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] of the war was
this. Mithridates was king over the barbarians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">barbaroi</span>\] around the
Black Sea \[<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Pontos Euxeinos</span>\].
Now his pretext
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prophasis</span>\] for making
war against the Romans, and how he crossed into Asia \[Minor\], and what
cities he took by force of arms or made his friends, I must leave for
those to find out who wish to know the things concerning Mithridates.
What I will highlight here is the capture of Athens.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.5">

There was an Athenian, Aristion, whom Mithridates used as his envoy to
the Greek \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnides</span>\]
cities. He persuaded the Athenians to join Mithridates rather than the
Romans, although he did not persuade all, but only the common-people
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] and, in
particular, the most turbulent part of the common-people
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\]. But those
Athenians who were of any account
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] fled to the
Romans of their own accord. In the engagement that followed, the Romans
won a decisive victory; Aristion and the Athenians fled and were pursued
right into the city \[of Athens itself\], while Arkhelaos and the
barbarians were pursued right into the \[harbor city of\] Peiraieus.
This Arkhelaos was another general of Mithridates, whom earlier than
this the Magnesians who inhabit
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] the region of
Mount Sipylos wounded when he raided their territory, killing most of
the barbarians as well. So, Athens was besieged.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.6">

Taxilos, a general
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratēgos</span>\] of
Mithridates, was at the time besieging Elateia in Phokis, but, on
receiving the news, he withdrew his troops towards Attica. Learning
this, the general
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratēgos</span>\] of the
Romans entrusted the siege of Athens to a portion of his army, and with
the greater part of his forces advanced in person to engage Taxilos in
Boeotia. On the third day from this, news came to both the Roman armies;
Sulla heard that the Athenian fortifications had been breached, and the
besieging force learned that Taxilos had been defeated in battle near
Khairōneia. When Sulla returned to Attica he rounded up inside the
Kerameikos the Athenians who had opposed him, and one chosen by lot out
of every ten he ordered to be led to execution.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.20.7">

Sulla did not relent in his anger against the Athenians, and so a few
who managed to escape to Delphi inquired there whether the time had now
come when it was fated for even Athens to become a deserted place. The
Pythia said-in-an-oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrē-</span>\]
the-things-having-to-do-with the ‘wine-skin’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">askos</span>\]. Afterwards,
Sulla was afflicted with that disease
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nosos</span>\], which I learn
also afflicted Pherecydes of Syros. Although Sulla treated the Athenian
people in a way that was so savage as to be unseemly for a Roman, I do
not think that this was the cause
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] of his
misfortune \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sumphorā</span>\].
What caused it, rather, was I think the cosmic-anger
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēnīma</span>\] of the
Lord-of-Suppliants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hikesios</span>\], for he \[=
Sulla\] had dragged Aristion from the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Athena,
where he had sought asylum, and killed him. Thus was Athens afflicted by
the war with Rome, but it blossomed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">antheîn</span>\] again when
Hadrian was-‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.1">

In the theater the Athenians have portrait-statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\] of the poets
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiētai</span>\] of tragedy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tragōidiā</span>\] and comedy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kōmōidiā</span>\], but they
\[= the statues\] are mostly of undistinguished persons. With the
exception of Menander no poet
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiētēs</span>\] of comedy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kōmōidiā</span>\] represented
here won a reputation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\], but tragedy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tragōidiā</span>\] has two
illustrious representatives, Euripides and Sophocles. It is said that
after the death of Sophocles, when the Lacedaemonians invaded Attica,
their commander saw in a vision Dionysus, who ordered him to honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\], with all the
customary honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] of the dead,
the new Siren \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Seirēn</span>\].
It seemed to him that the dream
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">onar</span>\] referred to
Sophocles and his poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēsis</span>\], and down to
the present day people are used to liken to a Siren whatever is
enchanting \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epagōgon</span>\]
in both poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēmata</span>\] and prose
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.2">

The likeness \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of
Aeschylus is, I think, much later than his death and than the painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] of the action
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] at Marathon.
Here is what Aeschylus himself said: that, when he was a young-man
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">meirakion</span>\] and he once
fell asleep while he was guarding the grapes in a vineyard, Dionysus
appeared to him and ordered him to make
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] tragedy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tragōidiā</span>\]. When day
came, in obedience to the vision, he made an attempt and started to
compose \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] with
the greatest of ease.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.3">

These are the things that he \[= Aeschylus\] said. On the South Wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\], as it is
called, of the Acropolis, which faces the theater, there is dedicated a
gilded head of Medusa the Gorgon, and around it is crafted an aegis
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aigis</span>\]. Looming over
the theater is a grotto
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">spēlaion</span>\] in the rocks
under the Acropolis. This also has a tripod standing over it. In it are
\[likenesses of\] Apollo and Artemis slaying the children of Niobe. This
Niobe I myself saw when I went up to the mountain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oros</span>\] called Sipylos.
When one is close by, it is a rock
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">petrā</span>\], a steep crag
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēmnos</span>\], showing not
at all the shape
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\] of a woman who
is lamenting \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pentheîn</span>\]
or the like; but if one gets further away from it one will think one is
seeing a woman shedding-tears
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dakruein</span>\],
with-sunken-eyes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katēphēs</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.4">

On the way to the Athenian Acropolis from the theater is the tomb of
Kálōs. Daidalos killed this Kálōs, who was his sister’s son and a
learner of the craft
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\]. Because of
this he fled to Crete; afterwards he ran off to the residence of Kokalos
in Sicily. The sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Asklepios
is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] both for its
paintings \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] and
for the statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of the god
and his children. In it there is a spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\], at which they
say that Poseidon’s son Halirrhothios ravished Alkippe the daughter of
Ares, who killed the ravisher and was the first to be put on trial
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikē</span>\]
in-compensation-for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> + dative\] the
killing \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phonos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.5">

Among the votive offerings there is a breastplate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thōrax</span>\] originating
from the people known as the Sauromatai. On seeing this, one will say
that no less than Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] are
barbarians skilled in the arts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnai</span>\]. I say this
for the following reasons. The Sauromatai have no iron, neither mined by
themselves nor yet imported. They have, in fact, no dealings at all with
the \[other\] barbarians who inhabit the places surrounding them. To
meet this deficiency they have invented things
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ex-heuriskein</span>\]. In
place of iron they use bone for their spear-blades, and cornel-wood for
the bows \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxa</span>\] from
which they shoot arrows, with bone points for the arrows. They throw a
lasso around any enemy they encounter, and then, turning around their
horses, they up-end the enemy caught in the lasso.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.6">

Their breastplates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thōrakes</span>\] they make in
the following way. Each man keeps many mares, since the land is not
divided \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">merizein</span>\] into
allotments \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">klēroi</span>\],
nor does it bear anything except wild trees, as the people are nomads.
These mares they not only use for war, but they also sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] them to the
local \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōroioi</span>\]
gods \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\] and eat
them for food. Their hooves they collect, clean, split, and make from
them as it were scales of serpents
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakontes</span>\]. Whoever
has never seen a serpent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakōn</span>\] must at least
have seen a pine-cone still green. He will not be mistaken if he likens
the product from the hoof to the segments that are seen on the
pine-cone. These pieces they bore and stitch together with the sinews of
horses and oxen, and then use them as breastplates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thōrakes</span>\] that are as
beautiful and strong as those of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]. For they
can withstand blows of missiles or when struck in close combat.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.21.7">

Linen breastplates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thōrakes</span>\] are not so
useful to those fighting in battles, for they let the iron pass through,
if the blow be a violent one. They aid hunters, however, for the teeth
of lions or leopards break off in them. One may see linen breastplates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thōrakes</span>\] dedicated in
other sanctuaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\], notably in the
one at Gryneion, where is found a most beautiful grove
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">alsos</span>\] of Apollo, with
cultivated trees, and all those other kinds of trees that, although they
bear no fruit, are pleasing to smell or look at.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.1">

Moving past the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Asklepios,
as one goes along this way toward the Acropolis, there is a shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Themis. In
front of it, heaped-up-as-a-tumulus
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kekhōstai</span>\], is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\][^70] for
Hippolytus. The end of his life, they say, came from curses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katārai</span>\]. Everybody,
even a barbarian who has learned the language of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], knows about
the erotic-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\] of Phaedra and
about the wickedness that her nurse
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">trophos</span>\] dared to
commit as her servant. The people of Troizen also \[= just as the
Athenians\] have a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\][^71] of
Hippolytus, and their story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] about it is as
follows.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.2">

When Theseus was about to marry Phaedra, he did not wish, in case he had
children, for Hippolytus either to be ruled by them or for Hippolytus to
be king \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\]
instead of them, and so he sent him \[= Hippolytus\] to Pittheus \[in
Troizen\] to be raised there to become the future king of Troizen.
Sometime later, Pallas and his sons rebelled against Theseus. After
killing them he \[= Theseus\] went to Troizen for purification
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katharsia</span>\], and
Phaedra first saw Hippolytus there.[^72] Conceiving-a-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erasthēnai</span>\] for him
she made-contrivances
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleuein</span>\] that
resulted in death.[^73] The people in Troizen have a myrtle-bush
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mursinē</span>\][^74] that has
every one of its leaves pricked with holes; they say that it did not
grow originally in this way, the holes being the result-created
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] by two causes.
One was the saturation-of-longing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">asē</span>\] that she felt in
her erotic-passion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\] and the other
was the pin \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peronē</span>\]
that Phaedra wore in her hair.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.3">

When Theseus had united into one state
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] the many
Athenian demes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\],
he established the custom of worshipping
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sebesthai</span>\] Aphrodite,
surnamed ‘common to every district’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Pan-dēmos</span>\] and
\[worshipping also\] Persuasion
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Peithō</span>\]. The old
statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] no
longer existed in my time, but those I saw were the work of no inferior
artisans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnītai</span>\].
There is also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Earth
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Gē</span>\] \[who has the
epithet\] <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kourotrophos</span>
\[‘nurturing the young’\] and of Demeter \[who has the epithet\] Chloe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Khloē</span> ‘burst of
green’\]. One can learn all about their epithets
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epōnumiai</span>\] by getting
into conversations
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\] with the
priests \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereis</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.4">

There is only one entrance to the Acropolis. It affords no other, being
precipitous all around and having a strong wall. The Gateway
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Propulaia / Propylaea</span>\]
has a roof of white marble, and down to the present day it is unrivalled
for the arrangement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kosmos</span>\] and size of
its stones. Now as to the likenessess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\] of the
horsemen \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hippeis</span>\], I
cannot tell for certain whether they are the sons of Xenophon or whether
they were made merely for their good looks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">euprepeia</span>\]. On the
right of the Gateway \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Propulaia
/ Propylaea</span>\] is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Wingless
Nike. From this point the sea is visible, and here it was, so they say,
that Aigeus threw himself down to his death.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.5">

I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] the ship that
carried the young people to Crete began its voyage with black sails; but
Theseus, who was sailing off on his daring-adventure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tolmē</span>\] against the
bull of Minos, so it is called, had told his father beforehand that he
would use white sails if he should sail back victorious over the bull.
But he had a memory-loss
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lēthē</span>\] of these things
after Ariadne was taken from him. So, Aigeus, when from this
vantage-point he saw the vessel carried along
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] by black
sails, thinking that his son was dead, threw himself down to
destruction. There is in Athens a hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] that is named
as belonging to Aigeus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.6">

On the left of the Gateway
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Propulaia / Propylaea</span>\]
is a building \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikēma</span>\]
that houses paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\]. Among those
not effaced by time there was Diomedes taking the \[statue of\] Athena
from Troy, and Odysseus in Lemnos taking away the bow
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxon</span>\] of Philoctetes.
There in the paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] is Orestes
killing Aigisthos, and Pylades killing the sons of Nauplios, who had
come as helpers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">boēthooi</span>\] for
Aigisthos. And there is Polyxena about to be slaughtered
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sphazesthai</span>\] near the
tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of
Achilles. Homer did well in bypassing this deed, which is so
raw-in-its-cruelty
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ōmon</span>\]. And I think he
also did well in making
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] Achilles
capture Skyros, differing entirely from those who say that Achilles had
a life-experience
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">diaita</span>\] in Skyros
together with the maidens there, as Polygnotus has pictured-in-painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\]. He \[=
Polygnotus\] also painted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] Odysseus
happening upon the girls washing clothes with Nausikaa at the river,
just like what Homer made-in-poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]. There are
also other paintings, including one that features Alcibiades,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.7">

and in that painting are signs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeia</span>\] indicating the
victory \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nīkē</span>\] his
horses won at Nemeā. There is also Perseus returning
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] to
Seriphos and carrying to Polydektes the head of Medusa. As for things
having to do with Medusa I am not inclined
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prothūmos</span>\] to
give-indications
