\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmainein</span>\] in my
account \[here\] about Attica. Included among the paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\]—I omit the
boy carrying the water-jars
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hudriai</span>\] and the
wrestler of Timainetos[^75]—is Musaeus. I have read
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epilegesthai</span>\] verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] in which Musaeus
receives from the North Wind \[Boreas\] the gift of flight, but, in my
opinion, Onomacritus made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] these
\[verses\], and there is nothing that is verifiably by Musaeus except
for a hymn \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">humnos</span>\] to
Demeter, \[composed\] for the Lykomidai.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.22.8">

Right at the very entrance to the Acropolis \[at the Propulaia /
Propylaea\] are (1) a Hermes called Hermes of the Propulaia
\[/Propylaea\] and (2) \[statues of\] the Graces
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kharites</span>\]. These they
say were made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]
by Socrates, the son of Sophroniskos. The Pythia was witness to his
being the wisest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sophōtatos</span>\] of humans.
She refused to address in the same way Anakharsis, although he really
wanted it to happen, and that is why he had come to Delphi.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.1">

Among the things the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] say is that
there were Seven Wise
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Sophoi</span>\] Men. Two of
them were the tyrant
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannos</span>\] \[Pittakos\]
of Lesbos and Periandros \[of Corinth\] the son of Kypselos. And yet
Peisistratos and his son Hippias were more humane
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">philanthrōpoi</span>\] than
Periandros, also more skilled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sophoi</span>\] in warfare and
in the proper-arrangement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kosmos</span>\] of citizens
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polītai</span>\], until, on
account of the murder of Hipparkhos, Hippias went the other way as he
yielded to his anger
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thūmos</span>\], especially
with regard to a woman whose name was Leaina \[meaning ‘Lioness’\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.2">

What I am about to say has never before been committed to a
\[historical\] write-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sungraphē</span>\], but it is
generally given credence by most Athenians. When Hipparkhos died,
Hippias subjected Leaina to degradations that led to her death, because
he understood that she was the mistress
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hetaira</span>\] of
Aristogeiton and therefore could not possibly, he thought, be in
ignorance of the plot
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleuma</span>\]. In
compensation, when the tyranny
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannis</span>\] of the
Peisistratidai was brought to an end, the Athenians set up a bronze
\[statue of a\] lioness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">leaina</span>\] in memory
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] of the woman.
The statue was a dedication initiated by Kallias, and the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] \[on the
statue\] was done by Kalamis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.3">

Close by is a bronze statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andrias</span>\] of Diitrephes
shot through by arrows.[^76] Among the things accomplished by this
Diitrephes as reported by the Athenians is his leading back home the
Thracian mercenaries who arrived too late to take part in the expedition
of Demosthenes against Syracuse. He also made a landing at
Euripos-at-Khalkis, where the Boeotians had an inland town Mykalessos,
marched up to this town from the coast, and captured it. Of the
inhabitants the Thracians killed not only the combatants but also the
women and children. There is-evidence
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">martureîn</span>\] for me \[to
cite\]. All the Boeotian cities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poleis</span>\] that the
Thebans captured were inhabited
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîsthai</span>\] in my
time, since the people escaped just before the capture. So, if the
barbarians had not killed off the people of Mykalessos the survivors
would have afterwards reoccupied the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.4">

It was such a great wonder
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thauma</span>\] for me to see
the likeness \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of
Diitrephes pierced with arrows. I say this because the only Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] for whom it
is a local-thing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrion</span>\] to
use-bow-and-arrows
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxeuein</span>\] are the
Cretans. After all, the men of Opountian Lokris, whom Homer made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] to be carrying
bows \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxa</span>\] and slings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sphendonai</span>\] when they
came to Ilion \[= Troy\], we know were-armed-as-heavy-infantry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hoplīteuein</span>\] by the
time of the Persian wars. Nor for that matter did the Malians continue
the practice \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">meletē</span>\]
of using bow-and-arrows
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxa</span>\]; even more, I
think that they did not know it before the time of Philoctetes, and they
gave it up soon after. Near the Diitrephes—I do not wish to write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] the less
distinguished likenesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\]—are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of gods; of
Hygieia, who they say is the daughter of Asklepios, and of Athena, who
also has this name Hygieia by way of epithet
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.5">

There is also a stone
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lithos</span>\], not very big
but just large enough to serve as a seat for a little man. On it they
say Silenos rested when Dionysus came to the land. I-say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] the oldest of the
Satyrs they call Silenoi. Wishing to know better than most people who
the Satyrs are, I got into conversations
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\] with many about
this very matter. Euphemos, a man from Caria, said that on a voyage to
Italy he was driven off-course by winds and was carried into the outer
sea, beyond the trajectory of seamen. He affirmed that there were many
uninhabited islands while others were inhabited
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] by wild
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agrioi</span>\] men. The
sailors did not wish to make a landing at the second islands,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.6">

because, having made a landing before, they had some experience of the
inhabitants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enoikoûntes</span>\], but on
this occasion they would have to be violently-forced
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">biasthênai</span>\] \[to make
a landing\]. The islands were called Satyrides by the sailors, and the
inhabitants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enoikoûntas</span>\] were
rustic, and had upon their flanks tails not much smaller than those of
horses. As soon as they noticed their visitors, they ran down to the
ship without a shout and assaulted the women in the ship. To end it all,
the sailors in fear tossed over \[to them\] on the island a barbarian
woman, whom the Satyrs outraged
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hubrizein</span>\] not only in
the usual way, but also all over her body.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.7">

Having viewed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theâsthai</span>\] other
things also on the Athenian Acropolis, I know them. There is a bronze
boy holding the sprinkler
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peri-rrhantērion</span>\], by
Lykios son of Myron. And there is Myron’s Perseus, \[shown\] right after
having just done
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergazesthai</span>\] the Deed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] with regard to
Medusa. There is also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Artemis
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Braurōniā</span>; the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is the work of
Praxiteles, and the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]
derives her name from the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of Brauron. The
old wooden-statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\] is in Brauron,
the Artemis in-Tauroi
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Taurikē</span>\], as she is
called.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.8">

There is the horse called Dourios \[‘Wooden’\] set up there, made of
bronze. That the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēma</span>\] of Epeios \[=
the ‘Wooden Hourse’\] was a mechanism
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēkhanēma</span>\] to make a
breach in the Trojan wall is known to everybody who does not attribute
utter credulity to the Phrygians \[= the Trojans\]. But it is said about
that horse that it contained the best
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aristoi</span>\] of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], and the
figuring \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\] of
the bronze fits in well with what is said about it. Menestheus and
Teukros are peeping out of it, and so too are the sons of Theseus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.9">

Of the statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\] that stand
behind the horse, the likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of Epikharinos
who perfected the footrace-in-armor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hoplītodrameîn</span>\] was
made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] by
Kritios, while the credit goes to Oinobios for the fine work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] with regard to
\[the likeness of\] Thucydides the son of Oloros.[^77] Oinobios had
succeeded in getting a decree
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">psēphisma</span>\] passed for
the return of Thucydides to Athens, but he was treacherously murdered as
he was returning, and there is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\][^78] for him
not far from the gate known as the Melitides.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.23.10">

Things to be said with regard to Hermolykos, who competed in the
pankration, also with regard to Phormion,[^79] the son of Asopikhos, I
omit, since others have written down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] those
things. About Phormion, however, I have one further thing to write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\]. Quite one
of the best men in Athens and distinguished for the fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] of his
ancestors, he happened to be heavily in debt. So, he withdrew to the
deme \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] Paiania
and lived there until the Athenians elected him to command a naval
expedition. But he refused the office on the grounds that before his
debts were discharged he lacked the mind-set
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phronēma</span>\] to face his
troops. So, the Athenians, who were absolutely determined to have
Phormion as commander, paid all his creditors.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.1">

In this place has been made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîsthai</span>\] \[a statue
of\] Athena striking Marsyas the Silenos for taking up the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aulos</span> \[‘double-reed’\],
which the goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>
(feminine)\] wished to be cast aside, once and for all. As one moves
past the works I have spoken of, there is what is talked about as the
Battle \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Makhē</span>\] of
Theseus with the so-called Bull of Minos, whether this was a man or a
beast of the kind he is said to have been in the prevalent story. I say
it this way because even in our time women have given birth to
monstrosities \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">terata</span>\]
that are far more-wondrous
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaumasiōtera</span>\] than
this.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.2">

There is also set up a \[statue of\] Phrixos the son of Athamas, carried
ashore to the land of Kolkhis by the ram. Having sacrificed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] it \[= the
ram\] to some god or other, presumably to the one called Laphystios by
the people of Orkhomenos, he has cut out the thighs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēroi</span>\] in accordance
with the custom \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomos</span>\]
of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] and is
watching them as they burn. Next are set up other likenesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikones</span>\], including
one of Hēraklēs strangling the serpents
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakontes</span>\], as the
story \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] has it.
There is Athena too coming up out of the head of Zeus, and also a bull
dedicated by the Council of the Areiopagos on some occasion or other,
about which one could, if one wanted to, say- many different
-likely-things
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikazein</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.3">

I have already said earlier that the Athenians, far more than other
people, share in a zeal
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">spoudē</span>\] for
that-which-is-divine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theion</span>\]. They were the
first to surname
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epοnomazein</span>\] Athena as
Erganē \[= patroness of
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span> ‘work’\]; they were
the first to set up limbless Hermai; and the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] \[of their
goddess\] is shared by a Daimōn \[‘superhuman force’\] of zealous-ones
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">spoudaioi</span>\].[^80]
Whoever prefers things that have been made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîsthai</span>\] with
artistry \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\] to
mere antiquity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhaiotēs</span>\], such a
person may have the following things to view
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theâsthai</span>\]: a man
wearing a helmet, by Kleoitas, whose nails the artist has made of
silver, and a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Earth
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Gē</span>\] imploring Zeus to
rain upon her; perhaps the Athenians themselves needed downpourings \[of
rain\], or maybe all the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] had been
plagued with a drought. There also are set up Timotheus the son of Konon
and Konon himself; Procne too, who has already made up her mind about
the boy, and Itys as well—a group dedicated by Alkamenes. There has also
been made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîsthai</span>\]
an Athena displaying her olive-plant
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phuton</span>\], and Poseidon
displaying his wave
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kūma</span>\];

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.4">

also, there is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Zeus, one
made by Leokhares[^81] and another one called Polieus \[‘of the city’\],
the traditions
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kathestēkota</span>\] for
sacrificing \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\] to
whom I will write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] without
writing down \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\]
the reason \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> + dative\] these
\[traditions\]. Upon the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Zeus Polieus
they place barley mixed with wheat and leave it unguarded. The ox, which
they keep already prepared for sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\], goes to the
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] and makes
contact \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">haptesthai</span>\]
with the grain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">spermata</span>\]. One of the
priests \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereis</span>\] they
call the ox-slayer
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouphonos</span>\], and he
kills the ox; then, casting aside the axe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pelekus</span>\] at that spot,
according to the ritual
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomos</span>\], he runs away.
The others bring the axe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pelekus</span>\] to trial
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikē</span>\], as if they did
not know the man who did
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\] the deed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.5">

They do \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\] these
things as I have just said they do them. And now, as one enters the
temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] that they
name the Parthenon, all the details that have been put into what is
called the \[east\] pediment
\[<span custom-style="chs_foreign_emphasis">aetos</span>\] show the
birth \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genesis</span>\] of
Athena, but on the rear \[= west\] pediment there is the strife
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eris</span>\] between Athena
and Poseidon over the ownership of the land \[of Athens\]. As for the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] \[of
the goddess\] itself, it is made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîsthai</span>\] of ivory
and gold. On the middle of her helmet
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kranos</span>\] is placed a
likeness \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of the
Sphinx—the things that are said of the Sphinx I will write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] when my
discourse \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] moves
ahead to things having to do with Boeotia—and on either side of the
helmet \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kranos</span>\] are
griffins \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">grupes</span>\] in
relief.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.6">

These griffins, Aristeas[^82] of Prokonnesos says in his verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\], fight for the
gold with the Arimaspoi beyond the Issedones. The gold that the griffins
guard, he says, comes out of the earth; the Arimaspoi are men all born
with one eye; griffins are beasts like lions, but with the beak and
wings of an eagle. I will say no more about the griffins.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.7">

The statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Athena is standing \[not seated\], with a tunic
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khitōn</span>\] reaching to
the feet, and on her breast the head of Medusa is worked in ivory. She
holds a \[statue of\] Nike about four cubits high, and in the other hand
a spear \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doru</span>\]; at her
feet is placed a shield
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aspis</span>\] and near the
spear \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doru</span>\] is a
serpent \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakōn</span>\]. This
serpent \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakōn</span>\] would
be Erikhthonios. On the pedestal of the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is the birth
of Pandora in relief. It has been said-in-poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîsthai</span>\] by Hesiod
and others that this Pandora was the first woman; before Pandora was
born there was as yet no womankind. And there, as I know because I saw
it, is a portrait-statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] Hadrian—it
is the only one there, but at the entrance there is one \[= a
portrait-statue\] of Iphikrates,[^83] who
accomplished-for-public-display
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apodeiknusthai</span>\] many
wondrous \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaumasta</span>\]
deeds.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.24.8">

Beyond the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] is a bronze
Apollo, and it is said that Pheidias made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]. They call it
the Locust God
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Parnopios</span>\], because
once when locusts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parnopes</span>\] were
devastating the land the god said that he would drive them from Attica.
That he did drive them away they know, but they do not say how. I myself
know that locusts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parnopes</span>\] have been
destroyed three times in the past on Mount Sipylos, and not in the same
way. Once a gale arose and swept them away; on another occasion violent
heat came on after rain and destroyed them; the third time, sudden cold
caught them and they died.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.1">

Such were the things I saw happening to the locusts. On the Athenian
Acropolis is a \[statue of\] Pericles, the son of Xanthippos, and one of
Xanthippos himself, who fought against the Persians at the naval battle
of Mykale.[^84] But the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andrias</span>\] of Pericles
stands apart, while near Xanthippos stands \[a statue of\] Anacreon of
Teos, the first poet after Sappho of Lesbos to compose
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] love poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōtika</span>\] as the major
part of what he wrote
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\], and his
posture \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\] is as
it were that of a man singing in a state of intoxication
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">methē</span>\].
Deinomenes[^85] has made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] the two female
figures which stand near, Io, the daughter of Inakhos, and Kallisto, the
daughter of Lykaon, about both of whom there are similar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">homoia</span>\] stories
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">diēgēmata</span>\]:
erotic-passion \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\]
of Zeus, wrath \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">orgē</span>\]
of Hērā, and metamorphosis
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">allagē</span>\]—Io becoming a
cow and Kallisto, a bear.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.2">

At the south wall is \[represented\] the war they say was fought with
the giants \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gigantes</span>\],
who once dwelled about Thrace and on the isthmus of Pallene, also the
battle \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">makhē</span>\] between
the Athenians and the Amazons, also the deed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] accomplished
against the Persians at Marathon, also the destruction of the Gauls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Galatai</span>\] in
Mysia.[^86] Each is about two cubits, and all were dedicated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anatithenai</span>\] by
Attalos. There stands too Olympiodoros, who won fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] for the
greatness of his achievements, especially in the crisis when he
displayed a brave confidence among men who had met with continuous
reverses and were therefore in despair of winning a single success in
the days to come.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.3">

For the disaster at Khairōneia[^87] was the beginning of misfortune for
all the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], and
especially did it turn into slaves
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">douloi</span>\] those who had
been blind to the danger and such as had sided with Macedon. Most of
their cities Philip captured; with Athens he nominally came to terms,
but really imposed the severest penalties upon it, taking away the
islands and putting an end to its empire
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] at sea. For a
time the Athenians remained passive, during the reign of Philip and
subsequently of Alexander. But when on the death of Alexander the
Macedonians chose Aridaios to be their king, though the whole empire
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] had been
entrusted to Antipatros, the Athenians now thought it intolerable if
Greece \[Hellas\] should be forever under the Macedonians, and
themselves embarked on war besides inciting others to join them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.4">

The cities \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poleis</span>\]
that took part were, of the Peloponnesians, Argos, Epidauros, Sikyon,
Troizen, the people of Elis, the Phliasians, Messene; on the other side
of the Corinthian Isthmus the people of Lokris, the people of Phokis,
the Thessalians, Karystos, the Acarnanians belonging to the Aetolian
League. The Boeotians, who occupied
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nemesthai</span>\] the
territory of Thebes now that there were no Thebans left to dwell there,
in fear that the Athenians would injure them by founding-a-settlement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epoikizein</span>\] on the
site of Thebes, refused to join the alliance and lent all their forces
to furthering the Macedonian cause.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.5">

The armed forces under the alliance had their own generals
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratēgoi</span>\] from each
city, but the Athenian Leosthenes was chosen to command all of them,
both because of the prestige
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">axiōma</span>\] of his city
and also because he had the reputation of being an experienced soldier.
He had already proved himself a general benefactor of all Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]. All those
of them who were serving as mercenaries in the armies of Darius and his
satraps Alexander had wished to deport to Persia, but Leosthenes was too
quick for him, and he brought
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] them by sea
to Europe. On this occasion too he accomplished
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apodeiknusthai</span>\]
brilliant deeds \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\],
true to expectation, and so his death produced a general despair that
was chiefly responsible for the defeat. A Macedonian garrison
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phrourā</span>\] was set over
the Athenians, and it occupied first Mounukhia and afterwards Peiraieus
also and the Long Walls.[^88]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.6">

On the death of Antipatros Olympias came over from Epeiros, killed
Aridaios, and for a time was-the-ruler
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhein</span>\]; but shortly
afterwards she was besieged by Kassandros, captured, and handed over to
the people \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">plēthos</span>\].
As for Kassandros and his rule-as-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\], my
account \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] will
deal only with what is relevant to the Athenians. He seized the fort of
Panakton in Attica, also Salamis, and he established as tyrant in Athens
Demetrios the son of Phanostratos, a man who had won a reputation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] for wisdom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sophiā</span>\]. The
tyrrannical-régime
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannis</span>\] of this man
was terminated by Demetrios the son of Antigonos, a young man who was
ambitiously
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">philotīmōs</span>\] disposed
to promote Hellenism \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò
Hellēnikon</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.7">

Meanwhile Kassandros, who had an underlying hatred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mīsos</span>\] for the
Athenians, cultivated Lakhares, who up to now had been a champion of the
people \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\], and
persuaded him to undertake a plot to achieve a tyrannical-régime
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannis</span>\]. Of all the
tyrants \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannoi</span>\] we
know of, no régime of any of them was so cruel to humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] and so
uncaring toward what is divine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò theion</span>\]. Although
Demetrios the son of Antigonos had his differences with the populace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of the
Athenians, he nevertheless deposed Lakhares from his tyranny
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannis</span>\], who, on the
capture of the fortifications, escaped to Boeotia. Lakhares took golden
shields \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aspides</span>\] from
the Acropolis, and stripped even the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena of
its removable ornamentation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kosmos</span>\]; he was
accordingly suspected of being a very wealthy man,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.25.8">

and was murdered by some men of Κorōneia for the sake of this wealth.
After freeing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eleutheroûn</span>\] the
Athenians from tyrants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannoi</span>\] Demetrios
the son of Antigonos did not restore the Peiraieus to them immediately
after the flight of Lakhares, but subsequently overcame them and brought
a garrison \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phrourā</span>\]
even into the upper city, fortifying the place called the Place of the
Muses \[Mouseion / Museum\]. This is a hill right opposite the Acropolis
within the ancient enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] \[of the
city\] where they say Musaeus
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mousaios</span> ‘Man of the
Muses’\] used to sing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">āidein</span>\], and, dying of
old age, was buried. Afterwards a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] also was built
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikodomeîn</span>\] here for a
Syrian. At the time to which I refer Demetrios fortified and held it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.1">

But, later on, a few men brought back to mind
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] their
forefathers \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">progonoi</span>\],
and what a transformation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">metabolē</span>\] of the
ancient prestige
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">axiōma</span>\] of the
Athenians had come to pass. Then, just like that, they went ahead and
elected Olympiodoros to be their general
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stratēgos</span>\]. He led
them, both the old men and the young, against the Macedonians,[^89]
hoping for military success by trusting more in their zeal
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prothūmiā</span>\] than in
their strength \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">rhōmē</span>\].
The Macedonians came out to engage him, but he overcame them, pursued
them to the Place of the Muses \[Mouseion / Museum\], and captured the
position.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.2">

So Athens was freed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eleutheroûsthai</span>\] from
the Macedonians, and though all the Athenians did engage-in-the-struggle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōnizesthai</span>\] in a way
that is worthy of recording, Leokritos the son of Protarkhos is said to
have displayed the greatest boldness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tolmē</span>\] in facing the
deed-to-be-done
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\]. For he was the
first to scale the fortification for the Place of the Muses \[Mouseion /
Museum\], and the first to rush inside; and when he fell fighting, the
Athenians paid him great honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\], and they even
dedicated his shield
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aspis</span>\] to Zeus
Eleutherios \[‘of Freedom’\] and inscribed on it the name of Leokritos
and his success.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.3">

This is the greatest deed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] of
Olympiodoros, aside from other accomplishments, which include his
recovering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anasōzesthai</span>\]
Peiraieus and Mounukhia; and again, when the Macedonians were raiding
Eleusis he collected a force of Eleusinians and defeated the invaders.
Still earlier than this, when Kassandros had invaded Attica,
Olympiodoros sailed to Aetolia and persuaded the Aetolians to
come-and-help
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">boētheîn</span>\]. This allied
force was the main reason
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aition</span>\] why the
Athenians escaped war with Kassandros. Olympiodoros has not only honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] in Athens, both
on the Acropolis and in the Prytaneion \[‘City Hall’\], but also a
portrait-painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphē</span>\] at Eleusis.
Likewise, the people of Phokis who originate from Elateia dedicated at
Delphi a bronze statue of Olympiodoros for help in their revolt from
Kassandros.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.4">

Near the likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of Olympiodoros
stands a bronze statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Artemis
with the surname
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\]
Leukophryne, dedicated by the sons of Themistocles. I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] the Magnesians
whom he ruled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhein</span>\]—and this rule
was granted to him by the King
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Basileus</span>\] \[of the
Persian Empire\]—hold Artemis Leukophryne in honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\]. But my
narrative \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] must
move ahead, with its goal kept in mind, which is, to go through all
subjects relating to things Greek
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnika</span>\]
while-keeping-in-mind-the-similarities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">homoiōs</span>\]. Endoios was
an Athenian by birth and a student of Daidalos, who also, when Daidalos
was in exile because of the death of Kálōs, went with him to Crete. His
\[= of Endoios\] is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena
seated, with an inscription
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epigramma</span>\] saying that
Kallias dedicated the image, but Endoios made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.5">

There is also a building
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikēma</span>\] called the
Erekhtheion \[/Erechtheum\]. In front of the entrance is an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Zeus Hypatos
\[‘the Most High’\], on which they never sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] anything alive
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">empsūkhon</span>\] but they
deposit \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tithenai</span>\]
baked-goods \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pemmata</span>\],
and they follow-the-custom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] of not using
any wine either. As one goes inside, there are altars
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmoi</span>\], one belonging
to Poseidon, on which in following up on an oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteuma</span>\] they
sacrifice \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] also
to Erekhtheus; the second \[altar belongs\] to the hero
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\] Boutēs; and the
third to Hephaistos. On the walls are paintings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphai</span>\] that depict
the Boutadai \[‘descendants of Boutēs’\]; there is also inside—the
building \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikēma</span>\] is
double—sea-water in a well
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phrear</span>\]. This is no
great wonder \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thauma</span>\],
since other inhabitants of any midland region
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mesógaia</span>\] also have
such wells, in particular the Carians who inhabit Aphrodisias. But this
particular well
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phrear</span>\] \[in Athens\]
lends itself to a scientific-write-up for this reason: it makes the
sound of waves when a south wind blows. And on the surface of the rock
is the outline \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\]
of a trident \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">triaina</span>\].
It is said that these things appeared
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phanēnai</span>\] as evidence
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">marturia</span>\] in support
of Poseidon’s claim to the land.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.6">

Both the city \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\]
\[of Athens\] and the whole of the land
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gē</span>\] are alike sacred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierā</span>\] to Athena; for
even those who in their demes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] have traditions
of worshipping \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sebein</span>\]
other gods nevertheless hold Athena in honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\]. But the thing
that was customarily-thought
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizesthai</span>\] to be the
most holy \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hagion</span>\]
thing by all in common \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">en
koinōi</span>\] already for many years before the demes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] came-together
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-eltheîn</span>\] is the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Athena \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Poliás</span>\] that is
on what is now called the Acropolis, but was in early days \[called\]
the <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Polis</span>. A tale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phēmē</span>\] concerning it
says that it \[= the wooden statue of Athena
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Poliás</span>\] fell from the
sky \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ouranos</span>\]; but I
will not follow up and say whether it was this way or some other way. A
golden lamp \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lukhnos</span>\]
for the goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theós</span>
(feminine)\] was made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] by
Kallimakhos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.26.7">

Having filled the lamp
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lukhnos</span>\] with olive
oil, they wait until the same day next year, and the oil is sufficient
for the lamp \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lukhnos</span>\]
during the interval, although it is lit both day and night. The wick in
it is made of flax from Karpasia, the only kind of flax that does not
get burned up by the fire \[of the flame\], and a bronze palm above the
lamp reaches to the roof and draws off the smoke. The Kallimakhos who
made the lamp, although not of the first rank with regard to this craft
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\], was
nevertheless the best in cleverness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sophiā</span>\], so that he
was the first to drill holes through stones, and he gave himself the
title of <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katatēxitekhnos</span>
\[‘having expertise in the process of melting’\], or perhaps others gave
the title and he established it as his.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.1">

In the temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Athena <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Poliás</span> \[‘of the
Polis’\] is set up a wooden Hermes, said to have been a dedication
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēma</span>\] by Kekrops,
but not clearly visible because of sprays of myrtle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mursinē</span>\]. The
votive-offerings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēmata</span>\] worthy of
taking-account \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\]
are, of the old ones, a folding chair, the making
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēma</span>\] of which is by
Daidalos; also spoils taken from the Persians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mēdoi</span>\], namely the
breastplate \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thōrax</span>\] of
Masistios, who commanded the cavalry at Plataea,[^90] and a scimitar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akinakēs</span>\] said to have
belonged to Mardonios. Now Masistios I know was killed by the Athenian
cavalry. But Mardonios was facing in battle the Lacedaemonians and was
killed by a Spartan; so, the Athenians could not have taken the scimitar
to begin with, and, furthermore, the Lacedaemonians would scarcely have
let them carry it off
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pheresthai</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.2">

About the olive tree
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">elaiā</span>\] they have
nothing to say except that it was evidence
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">marturion</span>\] adduced by
the goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theós</span>
(feminine)\] for the contest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōn</span>\] \[with
Poseidon\] for the land. They also say that, when the the Mede \[=
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ho Mēdos</span>, = the
Persians\] set Athens on fire, the olive tree
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">elaiā</span>\] was burned
down, but on the very day it was burned it grew again to the height of
two cubits. Adjoining the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Athena is the
temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Pandrosos, the only one of the sisters who was not-guilty
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-aitios</span>\] with regard
to what-had-been-entrusted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parakatathēkē</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.3">

The things about this that most of all cause-wonder
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaumazein</span>\] for me are
not completely knowable
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gnōrima</span>\], but I will
write down what kinds of things take place. Two maidens
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthenoi</span>\] dwell
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] not far from
the temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Athena <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Poliás</span>. The
Athenians call them Arrhephoroi
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arrhēphoroi</span>\]. For a
time they live a regulated-life
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">diaita</span>\] \[there\] at
the place of the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\], but
when the festival
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\] comes round
they ritually-perform
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\] at night the
following. They place on their heads what the priestess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereia</span>\] of Athena
gives them to carry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pherein</span>\]—neither she
who gives it knows
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eidénai</span>\] what it is
that she is giving nor do they who carry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pherein</span>\] it understand
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epistasthai</span>\] what it
is. Now, there is an enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] in the
city, the enclosure of Aphrodite in the Gardens
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kēpoi</span>\], as she is
called. It is not far away, and there is an underground
descending-passage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kathodos</span>\] that goes
through it \[= the enclosure\]. This descending-passage is
not-artificial-but-natural
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">automatē</span>\]. By way of
this passage the maidens descend
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katienai</span>\], and, \[when
they arrive\] down below
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katō</span>\], they leave
behind the things they were carrying
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pherein</span>\] and
\[replacing those things\] they take
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lambanein</span>\] something
else, which they bring-back
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\]—something
that is covered
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kaluptesthai</span>\]. These
maidens \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthenoi</span>\],
after this, are dismissed, and then there are other maidens led
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] up to the
Acropolis as replacements for them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.4">

Near the temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]
of Athena is \[...\] the likeness of an old woman about a cubit high.
She is called an attendant
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">diakonos</span>\] of
Lysimakhe. And there are large bronze statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of men
facing each other for a fight, one of whom they call Erekhtheus, the
other Eumolpos. But those Athenians who are acquainted with antiquity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ta arkhaia</span>\] must
surely know that the man killed by Erekhtheus was Immarados, the son of
Eumolpos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.5">

On the pedestal
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bathron</span>\] are also
statues of Theainetos, who was seer to Tolmides, and of Tolmides
himself, who when in command of the Athenian fleet inflicted severe
damage upon the enemy, especially upon the Peloponnesians who dwell
along the coast. He burned the dock-yards
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">neōria</span>\] at Gythion and
captured Boiai, belonging to the ‘peripheral-dwellers’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">perioikoi</span>\], and the
island of Cythera. He made a descent on Sikyonia, and, attacked by the
citizens as he was ravaging the country, he put them to flight and
chased them to the city. Returning afterwards to Athens, he conducted
Athenian colonists to Euboea and Naxos and invaded Boeotia with an army.
Having ravaged the greater part of the land and reduced Khairōneia by
way of a siege, he advanced into the territory of Haliartos, where he
was killed in battle and all his army defeated.[^91] Such were the
things I learned about Tolmides.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.6">

There are also old statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Athena,
no limbs of which indeed are missing, but they are rather black and too
fragile to bear a blow. For they too were caught by the flames when the
Athenians had gone on board their ships and the King
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Basileus</span>\] \[of the
Persian Empire\] captured the city, which had been emptied of its
able-bodied inhabitants. There is also a boar-hunt (I do not know for
certain whether it is the Calydonian boar) and Kyknos fighting with
Hēraklēs. This Kyknos is said to have killed, among others, Lykos the
Thracian, a prize having been proposed for the winner of the duel, but
near the river Peneios he was himself killed by Hēraklēs.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.7">

One of the Troizenian stories
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\] about Theseus
is the following. When Hēraklēs visited Pittheus at Troizen, he laid
aside his lion’s skin to eat his dinner, and there came in to see him
some Troizenian children together with Theseus, then about seven years
of age. It is said that when they saw the skin the other children ran
away, but Theseus slipped out not much afraid, seized an axe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pelekus</span>\] from the
attendants \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">diakonoi</span>\],
and straightway attacked the skin in earnest, thinking it to be a lion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.8">

This is the first Troizenian story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] about Theseus.
The next is that Aigeus placed boots and a sword under a rock as tokens
for the child, and then sailed away to Athens; Theseus, when sixteen
years old, pushed the rock away and departed, taking what Aigeus had
deposited. There is a representation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of what is said
in this story \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\]
on the Acropolis, everything in bronze except the rock.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.9">

There is another deed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] that they \[=
the Athenians\] have represented-in-the-form-of-a-dedicatory-offering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-tithenai</span>\], and
here is the tale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] that pertains
to that deed. The land of the Cretans and especially the part that is
next to the river Tethris was ravaged by a bull. I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] beasts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thēria</span>\] in ancient
times were much more formidable for humans. For example, there is the
Nemean lion. And the lion of Parnassus. And so many serpents
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakontes</span>\] in many
parts of Greece \[Hellas\]. And then there are the boars of Calydon and
Erymanthos.

</div>

Also the one from Krommyon in the land of Corinth. It was said that some
\[of these beasts\] were sent up from the earth down below, that others
were sacred \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] to
the gods, while still others had been let loose for the punishment
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmōriā</span>\] of humankind.
In the case of this bull as well, the Cretans say that it was sent by
Poseidon to their land because, although Minos was ruler
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn</span>\] of the Greek
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnikē</span>\] Sea
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Thalassa</span>\], he did not
give more honor \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\]
to Poseidon than to the other gods.

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.27.10">

Anyway, they say that this bull was conveyed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] from
Crete to the Peloponnesus, and became one of what are called the Twelve
Labors \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">āthloi</span>\] of
Hēraklēs. When he was set loose on the Plain of the Argives he fled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pheugein</span>\] through the
isthmus of Corinth and then fled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pheugein</span>\] further into
the land of Attica as far as the Attic deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of Marathon,
killing everyone he encountered, including Androgeōs, son of Minos.
Minos then sailed against Athens with his navy, not believing that the
Athenians were guiltless
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-aitioi</span>\] in the
death of Androgeōs, and oppressed them so badly that it was finally
agreed that they \[= the Athenians\] would bring seven girls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthenoi</span>\] and seven
boys \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paides</span>\] to the
Minotaur who was said to dwell
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in the
Labyrinth \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">laburinthos</span>\]
at Knossos. But, later on, Theseus is said to have driven the bull of
Marathon to the Acropolis, where he sacrificed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] it to the
goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>
(feminine), = Athena\]. And the dedicatory-offering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-thēma</span>\] \[that
signals this deed\] is from the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of Marathon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.1">

Why they set up a bronze statue of Kylon in spite of his plotting a
tyranny
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannis</span>\],[^92] I
cannot say for certain; but I infer that it was because he was very
beautiful to look upon, and of no undistinguished fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\], having won an
Olympian victory in the double-foot-race
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">diaulos</span>\], and he had
married the daughter of Theagenes, tyrant of Megara.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.2">

Above and beyond the things that I have so far inventoried
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katalegein</span>\], there are
two tithes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dekatai</span>\]
dedicated by the Athenians in the aftermath of wars. There is first a
bronze statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]
of Athena, tithe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dekatē</span>\] from the
\[victory over the\] Persians who landed at Marathon. It is the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\] of Pheidias,
but the reliefs upon the shield, including the fight between Centaurs
and Lapithai, are said to have been metalworked
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toreuein</span>\] by someone
named Mys, for whom they say Parrhasios son of Euenor designed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kata-graphein</span>\] this
and the rest of his works
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\]. The point of
the spear of this Athena and the crest of her helmet are already visible
to those sailing to Athens as they pass by Cape Sounion. The other tithe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dekatē</span>\] is a bronze
chariot, offered by the Boeotians and by the people of Khalkis in
Euboea.[^93] There are two other offerings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēmata</span>\], (1) a
statue of Pericles, the son of Xanthippos, and (2) the best of those
works of Pheidias that are most worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena
named ‘the one from Lemnos’, since those who dedicated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anatithenai</span>\] it were
from there.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.3">

All the Acropolis is surrounded by a wall; a part was constructed by
Kimon, son of Miltiades, but all the rest is said to have been built
round it by the Pelasgians, who once lived under the Acropolis. The
builders, they say, were Agrolas and Hyperbios. On inquiring who they
were I could discover nothing except that they were Sicilians originally
who emigrated to Akarnania.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.4">

As one descends, not to the lower city, but to just beneath the
Propylaia \[‘Gateway’\], there is a fountain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\] and near it a
sacred space \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\]
of Apollo in a cave
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">spēlaion</span>\]. It was
here, according to customary-thinking
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\], that Apollo
had sex \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-genesthai</span>\]
with Kreousa, daughter of Erekhtheus. \[There seems to be a gap here in
the text.\] When the Persians \[Medes\] had landed in Attica,
Philippides was sent as a messenger \[from Marathon\] to Sparta
\[Lacedaemon\]. When he returned \[to Marathon\], he said that the
Spartans \[Lacedaemonians\] had postponed sending out \[any
reinforcements\], on the grounds that it was their custom not to go out
to fight before the circle of the moon was full. Philippides went on to
say that near Mount Parthenios he had been met by Pan, who told him that
he is kindly-disposed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eu-nous</span>\] to the
Athenians and would come as their ally
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">summakhos</span>\] to
Marathon. This deity, then, gets honored
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmâsthai</span>\] in return
for this message
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">angeliā</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.5">

There is also the Peak of Ares \[Areiopagos\], so named because Ares was
the first to be put on trial here; my narrative
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] has already
made it clear
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēloûn</span>\][^94] that he
killed Halirrhothios, and what were the grounds for this act of his.
Afterwards, they say, Orestes was put on trial for killing his mother,
and there is an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] to Athena Areia
\[‘Warlike’\], which he dedicated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathenai</span>\] after he
was acquitted. The unhewn stones on which stand the defendants and the
prosecutors, they call the stone of Hubris \[‘Outrage’\] and the stone
of Anaideia \[‘Shamelessness’\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.6">

Close by is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the
goddesses \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] whom
the Athenians call the Semnai \[‘the august ones’\], but Hesiod in the
<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Theogony</span> calls them Erinyes
\[‘Furies’\].[^95] It was Aeschylus who first represented them with
snakes in their hair. But on the statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] neither of
these nor of any of the under-earth
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hupo-gaioi</span>\] deities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\] is there
anything horrific. There are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Pluto
\[Ploutōn\], Hermes, and Earth, in the name of whom sacrifices-are-made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] by those who
are acquitted of guilt
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] on the Peak of
Ares \[Areiopagos\]; sacrifices-are-made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] also on other
occasions by both city-folk and visitors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenoi</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.7">

Within the enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Oedipus,
whose bones, after diligent inquiry, I found were brought
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] from Thebes.
I am prevented from thinking as trustworthy the things having to do with
the death of Oedipus as composed-in-poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] by Sophocles.
I am prevented by Homer, who says that, after the death of Oedipus,
Mekisteus \[of Athens\] came to Thebes and participated-in-the-athletic
contest \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōnizesthai</span>\]
at the funeral-compensating-for-his-death
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epitaphios</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.8">

The Athenians have other law courts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikastēria</span>\] as well,
which do not have so great a fame
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\]. There is the
so-called <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Parabuston</span> and
the Triangle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Trigōnon</span>\]; the first
of the two is in an obscure part of the city, and in it the most trivial
cases are tried; the second is named from its shape. The names of Frog
Court \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Batrakhioûn</span>\] and
Red Court
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Phoinikioûn</span>\], due to
their colors, have lasted down to the present day. The largest court, to
which the greatest numbers come, is called
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hēliaiā</span>. One of the other
courts that deal with bloodshed is called \[…\] Palladion, into which
are brought cases of involuntary homicide. All are agreed that Demophon
was the first to be put on trial there, but as to the nature of the
charge accounts differ.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.9">

It is said that after the capture of Troy \[Ilion\] Diomedes was
returning-home
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] with his
ships when night overtook them as they sailed near Phaleron. The Argives
went ashore, though they thought that they had landed in hostile
territory, since the darkness prevented them from seeing that they were
in Attica. At that point, they say that Demophon, he too being unaware
of the facts and ignorant that those who had landed were Argives,
responded-to-the-alarm-and-went-on-the-attack
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ek-boētheîn</span>\]. He
killed a number of the men, seized the Palladium, and rode off with it.
An Athenian, however, not seeing in the dark that Demophon, riding his
horse, was heading in that direction, was knocked over and trampled to
death. So, Demophon was brought to trial, some say by the relatives of
the man who was trampled, others say by the community
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò koinon</span>\] of the
Argives.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.10">

At the Delphinion are tried those who claim that they have committed
justifiable homicide, which was the plea put forward by Theseus on the
occasion when he was acquitted, after having killed Pallas, who had
risen in revolt against him, and his sons. Before Theseus was acquitted
it was the established custom among all men for the one who sheds blood
to go into exile, or, if he remained, to be put to a similar death. The
Court in the Prytaneion \[‘City Hall’\], as it is called, where they try
iron and all similar inanimate things, had its origin, I think
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizō</span>\],
in-response-to \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> +
dative case\] the following event. It was when Erekhtheus was king of
Athens that the ox-slayer
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bou-phonos</span>\] first
killed an ox at the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Zeus
Polieus. Leaving the axe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pelekus</span>\] where it lay
he went out of the land into exile, and the axe
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pelekus</span>\] was
immediately put-on-trial
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krinesthai</span>\] and
acquitted, and the trial has been repeated year by year down to the
present.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.28.11">

Furthermore, it is also said that inanimate objects have on occasion of
their own accord inflicted righteous retribution upon men; of this the
scimitar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">akinakēs</span>\] of
Cambyses affords the best and most famous instance.[^96] Near the sea at
the Peiraieus is Phreattys. Here it is that men in exile, when a further
charge has been brought against them in their absence, make their
defense on a ship while the judges listen on land. The story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] is that Teukros
first defended himself in this way before Telamon, claiming that he had
not done anything that contributed to the death of Ajax. Let this
account suffice for those who are interested to learn about the law
courts \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikastēria</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.1">

Near the Peak of Ares
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Areiopagos</span>\] is shown a
ship built for the procession
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pompē</span>\] of the
Panathenaia. This ship, I suppose, has been surpassed in size by others,
but I know of no builder who has outdone the vessel at Delos, with its
nine banks of oars below the deck.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.2">

Outside the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\], too, in the
demes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] and on
the roads \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hodoi</span>\], the
Athenians have sanctuaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] of the gods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\], and tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] of heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\] and of men
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andres</span>\]. Nearest is
the Academy \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Akadēmiā</span>\],
a place \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrion</span>\] that
once belonged to a private-individual
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">idiōtēs</span>\], but in my
time a gymnasium. As one goes down to it
\[=<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Akadēmiā</span>\], there is
an enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] of Artemis,
and wooden-statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\] of Ariste
\[‘Best’\] and Kalliste \[‘Most Beautiful’\]. I think, and my thinking
is in agreement with the poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epos</span> plural\] of
Pamphos, that these are surnames
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēseis</span>\] of
Artemis. I know another tale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] that is told
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legesthai</span>\] about them,
but I shall pass over that one. Then there is a small shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nåos</span>\], into which
every year on fixed days they carry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Dionysus
Eleuthereus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.3">

Such are their sanctuaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\] here, and of
the tombs \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] the
first is that of Thrasyboulos son of Lykos, in all respects the best
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aristos</span>\] of all famous
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logimoi</span>\] Athenians,
whether they lived before him or after him. The greater number of the
things to be said about him I shall pass over, but the following thing
will suffice for verification
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pistis</span>\] concerning
what-is-said \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\]:
he put down what is called the tyranny
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">turannis</span>\] of the
Thirty,[^97] setting out from Thebes with a force amounting at first to
sixty men; he also persuaded the Athenians, who were
divided-by-factionalism
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stasiazein</span>\], to be
reconciled and to abide by their reconciliation. His is the first tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\], and after it
come those of Pericles, Khabrias,[^98] and Phormion.[^99]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.4">

There is also a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] for all the
Athenians who happened to die in war, whether in battles
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">makhai</span>\] at sea or on
land, except for those who had their struggle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōnizesthai</span>\] at
Marathon. These, on account of their manly-valor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andragathiā</span>\], have
their burial-places
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] on the
field-of-battle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrā</span>\], but the others
lie along the road to the Academy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Akadēmiā</span>\], and over
their burial-places
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] stand slabs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stēlai</span>\] that say \[by
way of inscriptions\] the name and the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of each. First
were buried those who in Thrace, after a victorious advance as far as
Drabeskos,[^100] were unexpectedly attacked by the Edonians and
slaughtered. It is also said that strokes-of-lightning
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">keraunoi</span>\] fell upon
them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.5">

Among the generals were Leagros, to whom was entrusted chief command of
the army, and Sophanes of Decelea, who killed—when he came to the help
of the Aeginetans—Eurybates the Argive, who won the prize in the
pentathlon[^101] at the Nemean games. This was the third expedition that
the Athenians dispatched to places outside of Greece \[Hellas\]. For
against Priam and the Trojans war was made in common
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo koinou logou</span>\] by
all the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\]; but by
themselves the Athenians sent armies, first with Iolaos to Sardinia,
secondly to what is now Ionia, and thirdly on the mentioned occasion to
Thrace.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.6">

In front of the monument is a slab
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stēlē</span>\] on which are
(represented) horsemen
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hippeis</span>\] fighting.
Their names are Melanopos and Makartatos, who met their death fighting
against the Lacedaemonians \[Spartans\] and Boeotians on the borders of
Eleon and Tanagra. There is also a tomb of Thessalian horsemen
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hippeis</span>\] who, by
reason of an old alliance, came when the Peloponnesians with Arkhidamos
invaded Attica with an army for the first time,[^102] and, close by,
that of Cretan bowmen
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">toxotai</span>\]. Again there
are tombs \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmata</span>\] of
Athenians: of Cleisthenes, who invented the system of the subdivisions
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phulai</span>\]
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek"></span>at present
existing,[^103] and of horsemen
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hippeis</span>\] who died when
the Thessalians shared the fortune of war with the Athenians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.7">

Here too lie the men of Kleōnai, who came with the Argives into
Attica;[^104] the occasion of which I will write
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] when in the
course of my narrative
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] I come to the
Argives. There is also the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of the
Athenians who fought against the Aeginetans before the invasion of the
Medes \[Persians\]. It was surely a just decree
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleuma</span>\] even for a
democracy when the Athenians actually allowed slaves a public funeral,
and to have their names inscribed on a slab
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stēlē</span>\], which declares
that in the war they proved to be good men in relation to their masters
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">despotai</span>\]. There are
also \[written on tombs\] names of other men, their fields-of-battle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōnes</span>\] located in
various different places
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōria</span>\]. Here lie the
most renowned \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logimoi</span>\]
of those who went against Olynthus,[^105] and Melesandros, who sailed
with a fleet along the Maeander River into upper Caria;[^106]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.8">

also those who died in the war with Kassandros, and the Argives who once
fought as the allies of Athens. It is said that the alliance between the
two sides came about in the following way. The city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] of the
Lacedaemonians \[Spartans\] was once shaken by an earthquake sent by the
god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\], and the
Helots seceded to Ithome.[^107] After the secession the Spartans
\[Lacedaemonians\] sent for help to various places, including Athens,
and the Athenians dispatched specially-chosen troops under the command
of Kimon, the son of Miltiades. These the Spartans \[Lacedaemonians\]
dismissed, because they suspected them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.9">

It was intolerable, the Athenians thought, that they had been insulted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peri-hubrizesthai</span>\]
this way, and on their way back they made an alliance with the Argives,
the immemorial enemies of the Spartans \[Lacedaemonians\]. Afterwards,
when a battle was imminent at Tanagra,[^108] the Athenians opposing the
Boeotians and Spartans \[Lacedaemonians\], the Argives reinforced the
Athenians. For a time the Argives had the better, but night came on and
took from them the assurance of their victory, and on the next day the
Spartans \[Lacedaemonians\] had the better, as the Thessalians betrayed
the Athenians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.10">

It occurred to me to account for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katalegein</span>\] the
following men also. First, there is Apollodoros, commander of the
mercenaries, who was an Athenian dispatched by Arsites, satrap of
Phrygia-by-the-Hellespont, and who saved their city for the Perinthians
when Philip had invaded their territory with an army.[^109] He, then, is
buried here, and also Euboulos[^110] the son of Spintharos, along with
men who though brave were not attended by good fortune; some attacked
Lakhares when he was tyrant, others planned the capture of the Peiraieus
when in the hands of a Macedonian garrison, but before the deed could be
accomplished were betrayed by their accomplices and put to death.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.11">

Here also lie those who fell near Corinth.[^111] The god
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\] showed most
distinctly here and again at Leuktra[^112] that those whom the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] call brave
are as nothing if Good Fortune be not with them, seeing that the
Spartans \[Lacedaemonians\], who had on this occasion overcome
Corinthians and Athenians, and furthermore Argives and Boeotians, were
afterwards at Leuktra so utterly defeated by the Boeotians alone. After
those who were killed in Corinth, we come across elegiac verses
declaring that one and the same slab has been erected to those who died
in Euboea and Chios,[^113] and to those who perished in the remote parts
