of the continent of Asia \[Minor\], or in Sicily.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.12">

The names of the generals are inscribed with the exception of Nikias,
and among the private soldiers are included the Plataeans along with the
Athenians. This is the reason why Nikias was passed over, and my account
is identical with that of Philistos, who says that while Demosthenes
made a truce for the others and excluded himself, attempting to commit
suicide when taken prisoner, Nikias voluntarily submitted to the
surrender.[^114] For this reason Nikias did not have his name inscribed
on the slab, being condemned as a voluntary prisoner and an unworthy
soldier.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.13">

On another slab are the names of those who fought in the region of
Thrace and at Megara,[^115] and when Alcibiades persuaded the Arcadians
in Mantineia and the people of Elis to revolt from the Spartans
\[Lacedaemonians\],[^116] and of those who were victorious over the
Syracusans before Demosthenes arrived in Sicily. Here were buried also
those who fought in the sea-fights near the Hellespont,[^117] those who
opposed the Macedonians at Khairōneia,[^118] those who were killed at
Delium in the territory of Tanagra,[^119] the men whom Leosthenes led
into Thessaly, those who sailed with Kimon to Cyprus,[^120] and of those
who with Olympiodoros[^121] expelled the garrison not more than thirteen
men.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.14">

The Athenians declare that when the Romans were waging a border war they
sent a small force to help them, and later on five Attic warships
assisted the Romans in a naval action against the Carthaginians.
Accordingly, these men also have their tomb here. The achievements of
Tolmides and his men, and the manner of their death, I have already set
forth, and any who are interested may take note that they are buried
along this road. Here lie too those who with Kimon achieved the great
feat of winning a land and naval victory on one and the same day.[^122]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.15">

Here also are buried Konon and Timotheus, father and son, the second
pair thus related to accomplish illustrious deeds, Miltiades and Kimon
being the first; Zeno too, the son of Mnaseas and Khrysippos[^123] of
Soloi, Nikias the son of Nikomedes, the best in painting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">zōia graphein</span> =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">zōigraphos</span>\] of all his
contemporaries, Harmodios and Aristogeiton, who killed Hipparkhos, the
son of Peisistratos; there are also two orators, Ephialtes, who was
chiefly responsible for the abolition of the privileges of the
Areiopagos[^124], and Lycurgus \[Lykourgos\],[^125] the son of
Lykophron;

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.29.16">

Lycurgus \[Lykourgos\] provided for the state-treasury six thousand five
hundred talents more than Pericles, the son of Xanthippos, collected,
and he furnished for the procession of the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]
golden figures of Nike and ornaments for a hundred girls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénoi</span>\]; for war he
provided armor and projectiles, besides increasing the fleet to four
hundred warships. As for buildings, he completed the theater that others
had begun, while during his political life he built ship-sheds
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">neōs oikoi</span>\] at the
dockyards in Peiraieus. He built also the gymnasium near what is called
the Lyceum. Everything made of silver or gold became part of the plunder
that Laoites made away with when he became tyrant, but the buildings
remained to my time.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.30.1">

Before the entrance to the Academy is an altar to Eros, with an
inscription indicating that Kharmos was the first Athenian to dedicate
an altar to that god. The altar within the city called the altar of
Ant-eros they say was dedicated by resident aliens, because the Athenian
Meles, spurning the love of Timagoras, a resident alien, ordered him to
ascend to the highest point of the rock and cast himself down. Now
Timagoras took no account of his life, and was ready to gratify the
youth in any of his requests, so he went and cast himself down. When
Meles saw that Timagoras was dead, he suffered such pangs of remorse
that he threw himself from the same rock and so died. From this time the
resident aliens worshipped as Ant-eros the avenging spirit of Timagoras.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.30.2">

In the Academy is an altar to Prometheus, and from it they run to the
city carrying burning torches. The contest is while running to keep the
torch still lit; if the torch of the first runner goes out, he has no
longer any claim to victory, but the second runner has. If his torch
also goes out, then the third man is the victor. If all the torches go
out, no one is left to be winner. There is an altar to the Muses, and
another to Hermes, and one inside to Athena, and they have built one to
Hēraklēs. There is also an olive tree, accounted to be the second that
appeared.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.30.3">

Not far from the Academy is the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Plato, to
whom the god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]
foretold
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pro-sēmainein</span>\] that he
would be the best
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aristos</span>\] when it comes
to philosophy. The manner of the foretelling
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pro-sēmainein</span>\] was
this. On the night before Plato was to become his pupil Socrates dreamed
that he saw a swan
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kuknos</span>\] fly into his
insides \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kolpos</span>\]. Now
the swan is a bird with a reputation for the art-of-the-Muses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mousikē</span>\], because,
they say, a practitioner-of-the-art-of-the-Muses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mousikos</span>\] by the name
of Swan \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kuknos</span>\] became
king of the Ligyes on the other side of the Eridanos beyond the Celtic
territory, and after his death by the will of Apollo he was changed into
the bird. I am ready to believe that a
practitioner-of-the-art-of-the-Muses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mousikos</span>\] became king
of the Ligyes, but I cannot believe that a bird was generated out of a
man.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.30.4">

In this landscape
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrā</span>\] is visible the
tower \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">purgos</span>\] of
Timon, the only man to see that there is no way to be happy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eudaimōn</span>\] except to
shun other humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\]. There is
also pointed out a place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōros</span>\] called the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kolōnos Hippios</span>
\[‘Tumulus of Horses’\], the first point in Attica, they say, that
Oedipus reached—these things that are said do differ from what is in the
poetry \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēsis</span>\] Homer,
but they say these things in any case—and an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Poseidon
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hippios</span> \[‘(controller
of) horses’\], and of Athena
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hippiā</span> \[‘(controller of)
horses’\], and a hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] of Peirithoös
and Theseus, Oedipus and Adrastos. The grove
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">alsos</span>\] and shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Poseidon were
burned down by Antigonos[^126] when he invaded Attica, who at other
times also ravaged the land of the Athenians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.31.1">

The small demes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\]
of Attica, the founding of all of which happenend separately, presented
the following things that are worthy of remembrance
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\]. At Alimous is
a sanctuary of Demeter
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Thesmophoros</span> and of the
Maiden \[Korē\], and at Zoster \[‘Waistband’\] on the coast is an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] to Athena, as
well as to Apollo, to Artemis and to Leto. They say that Leto did not
give birth to her children here, but loosened her waistband with a view
to her delivery, and the place received its name from this incident.
Prospalta has also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the Maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Korē</span>\] and Demeter, and
Anagyros has a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the Mother
of the gods. At Kephale the chief cult is that of the Dioskouroi, for
the inhabitants call them the Great gods.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.31.2">

At Prasiai is a temple of Apollo. Hither they say are sent the
first-fruits of the Hyperboreans, and the Hyperboreans are said to hand
them over to the Arimaspi, the Arimaspi to the Issedones, from these the
Scythians bring them to Sinope, thence they are carried by Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] to Prasiai,
and the Athenians take them to Delos. The first-fruits are hidden in
wheat straw, and they are known of none. There is at Prasiai a monument
to Erysikhthon, who died on the voyage home from Delos, after the sacred
mission thither.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.31.3">

How Amphiktyon banished Kranaos, his kinsman by marriage and king of
Athens, I have already related. They say that fleeing with his
supporters to the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of Lamptrai he
died and was buried there, and at the present day there is a monument to
Kranaos at Lamptrai. At Potamoi in Attica is also the tomb of Ion the
son of Xouthos—for he too dwelled among the Athenians and was their
commander-in-chief in the war with Eleusis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.31.4">

Such is the way it is told
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legesthai</span>\]. The people
of Phlya and Myrrhinous have altars
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmoi</span>\] of Apollo
Dionysodotos \[‘gift of Dionysus’\], Artemis Selasphoros
‘light-bearer’\], Dionysus Anthios \[‘he of the blossoms’\], the nymphs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">numphai</span>\] named
Ismenides, and Earth \[Gē\], whom they name the Great Goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]; a
second temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]
has altars \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmoi</span>\] of
Demeter Anēsidōrā \[‘sender-up of gifts’\], Zeus Ktēsios \[ ‘giver of
possessions’\], Athena Tithrōnē, the Maiden \[Korē\] who is Prōtogonē
\[‘generated first of all’\], and the goddesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] named Semnai.
The wooden-likeness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\] at Myrrhinοus
is of Κolainis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.31.5">

The people of Athmonia honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\] Artemis
Amarysia. On inquiry I discovered that the guides
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">exhēgētai</span>\] knew
nothing about these female figures, but I conjecture
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-ballomai</span>\] as
follows. Amarynthos is a town in Euboea, the inhabitants of which honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\] Amarysia, while
the festival \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\]
of Amarysia which the Athenians celebrate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] is no less
splendid than the Euboean. The name \[of the goddess\], I think, came to
Athmonia in this way, while the Kolainis in Myrrhinous is named after
Kolainos. I have already written that many of the inhabitants of the
demes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] say that
they were ruled-by-kings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuesthai</span>\] even
before the rule \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\]
of Kekrops. Now Kolainos, say the people of Myrrhinous, is the name of a
man who ruled \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhein</span>\]
before Kekrops became-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.31.6">

There is a deme \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\]
called Akharnai, where they honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\], among the gods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\],Apollo Aguieus
\[‘he of the causeways’\], and Hēraklēs, and there is an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Athena
Hygieia. And they call upon the name of Athena
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hippiā</span> \[‘(controller of)
horses’\] and Dionysus Melpomenos \[‘singing-and-dancing’ (in a
chorus)\] and, with reference to the same god, Kissos \[‘ivy’\], saying
that the plant ivy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kissos</span>\] first appeared
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phanēnai</span>\] there.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.1">

The Attic mountains are Pentelikos, where there are quarries, Parnes,
where there is hunting of wild boars and of bears, and Hymettos, which
grows the most suitable pasture for bees, except that of the
Alazones.[^127] For these people have actually bees ranging free, tamely
following the other creatures when they go to pasture. These bees are
not kept shut up in hives, and they work in any part of the land they
happen to visit. They produce a solid mass from which you cannot
separate either wax or honey. Such then is its nature.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.2">

The Athenians have also statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of gods on
their mountains. On Pentelikos is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena, on
Hymettos one of Zeus Hymettios. There are altars
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmoi</span>\] both of Zeus
Ombrios \[‘he of the rain’\] and of Apollo Proopsios \[’foreseer’\]. On
Parnes is a bronze Zeus Parnethios, and an altar to Zeus Semaleus. There
is on Parnes another altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\], and on it they
make-sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\], calling Zeus
sometimes Ombrios, sometimes Apēmios. Ankhesmos is a mountain of no
great size, with a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Zeus
Ankhesmios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.3">

Before turning to a description of the islands, I follow up further on
matters having to do with the demes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmoi</span>\] \[of Attica\].
There is a deme \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\]
called Marathon, equally distant from the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] of the
Athenians and from Karystos in Euboea. It was at this point in Attica
that the barbarians landed, were defeated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krateîsthai</span>\] in
battle, and lost some of their ships as they were trying to pull away
\[from the shore\].[^128] On the plain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pedíon</span>\] is the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of the
Athenians, and upon it are slabs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stēlai</span>\] with
\[inscriptions of\] the names of those killed, organized by way of their
subdivisions \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phūlai</span>\];
and there is another tomb for the men of Plataea from Boeotia and also
for the slaves. I say-this-because
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gar</span>\] slaves too fought
there, and it was the first time that this happened.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.4">

There is also an individual monument
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] for one man,
Miltiades son of Kimon, although his end
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teleutē</span>\] happened
later, after he had failed to capture Paros and for this reason had been
put on trial by the Athenians. At this place \[= Marathon\] every night
you can hear horses neighing and you can sense that men are fighting in
combat. No one who has deliberately set out to experience this vision
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] in-full-view
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">en-argēs</span>\] has ever
really had any success, but still, if something is experienced in some
alternative way by someone who has no ear for such things, this is no
cause for anger \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">orgē</span>\]
on the part of the spirits
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimones</span>\]. The people
of Marathon worship
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sebesthai</span>\] both those
who died in the fighting, calling them heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\], and also
\[the hero\] Marathon, from whom the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] derives its
name, and then Hēraklēs, saying that they were the first among the
Greeks \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] to
establish-the-custom-of-thinking
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] him to be a
god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.5">

They \[= the people of Marathon\] tell about something that happened at
the battle \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">makhē</span>\] \[of
Marathon\]. It was the presence of a man who had the looks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eidos</span>\] of a farmer
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agr-oikos</span>\]—and
implements \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skeuē</span>\] to
match. Wielding a plough
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arotron</span>\] he
slaughtered with it many of the barbarians, and then, after having done
what-was-done \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\]
he disappeared \[= became
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">a-phanēs</span>\]. When the
Athenians consulted the god \[Apollo\], he did not
make-an-oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsai</span>\] with regard
to him \[= the man with the plough\] but simply commanded them to honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\] Ekhetlaios (=
he of the plough-handle) as a hero
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\]. A
trophy-column
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropaion</span>\] of white
marble has been made \[to mark the turning-point or
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropaion</span> of the battle of
Marathon\]. The Athenians say that they buried the Persians, since it is
a universally \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pantōs</span>\]
holy-thing \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hosion</span>\] for
the corpse \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nekros</span>\] of
a human to be covered by the earth, but I could not find any tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] for them.
There was neither a tumulus
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōma</span>\] nor any other
marker \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeion</span>\] to be
seen. They must have carried them \[= the dead Persians\], just as they
found them, to some ditch and tossed them in.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.6">

In Marathon is a spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\] called Makaria,
and what they say about it is as follows. When Hēraklēs left Tiryns,
fleeing from Eurystheus, he went to live with his friend Keyx, who was
king of Trakhis. When Hēraklēs departed the life of humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\], Eurystheus
demanded his children. But the king of Trakhis sent them to Athens,
saying that he was weak while Theseus was hardly powerless to protect
them. The arrival of the children as suppliants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiketai</span>\] caused for
the first time war between Peloponnesians and Athenians, since Theseus
refused to give them up \[= the children of Hēraklēs\] at the demand of
Eurystheus. And they say that an oracle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsmos</span>\] was given
the Athenians that one of the children of Hēraklēs must die a voluntary
death, or else victory
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nīkē</span>\] could not be
theirs. Then Makaria, daughter of Deianeira and Hēraklēs, slaughtered
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-sphazein</span>\] herself
and gave to the Athenians the upper hand
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kratos</span>\] in the war and
to the spring \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\]
her own name.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.32.7">

There is at Marathon a lake
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">limnē</span>\] which for the
most part is marshy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hel-ōdēs</span>\]. Into this
lake fell the barbarians \[= the Persians\] as they were turning and
running \[after the battle\], since they did not know their way around
the roads, and it is said that much of the slaughter
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phonos</span>\] that followed
was because of this. Above the lake are the stone stables of the horses
of Artaphernes, and there are marks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeia</span>\] of his tent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skēnē</span>\] on the rocks.
Out of the lake flows a river, providing near the lake itself water
suitable for cattle, but near its mouth it becomes saline and full of
sea fish. A little beyond the plain is the Hill of Pan and a Cave of
Pan, which is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\]. The entrance to
it is narrow, but farther in are chambers and baths and the so-called
Pan’s herd of goats, which are rocks that look very much like goats.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.1">

At some distance from Marathon is Brauron, where, they say that
Iphigenia, the daughter of Agamemnon, landed carrying the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Artemis
when she fled from Tauroi; leaving the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] there she came
to Athens also and afterwards to Argos. There is indeed an old wooden
image of Artemis here, but who in my opinion have the one taken from the
barbarians I will set forth in another place.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.2">

About sixty stadium-lengths from Marathon as you go along the road by
the sea to Oropos stands Rhamnous. The houses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikēseis</span>\] for human
habitation are on the coast, but a little way inland is a sacred space
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Nemesis,
who of all the gods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\] is the most
inexorable toward humans who-commit-outrage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hubristai</span>\]. It is
thought that the wrath
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēnīma</span>\] of this
goddess \[(<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">he</span>)
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\] countered the
barbarians \[= Persians\] who landed at Marathon. Scornfully thinking
that nothing stood in the way of their capturing Athens, they were
bringing a piece of Parian marble for the making
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poiēsis</span>\] of a trophy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropaion</span>\], as if their
task were already finished.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.3">

Of this marble Pheidias made a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Nemesis,
and on the head of the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine) \] is
a garland \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanos</span>\]
picturing deer and small statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Nike. In
her left hand she holds an apple branch, in her right hand a cup on
which are crafted the figures of Aethiopians. As to the Aethiopians, I
could hazard no guess myself, nor could I accept the statement of those
who are convinced that the Aethiopians have been carved upon the cup
because of the river Okeanos. For the Aethiopians, they say, dwell near
it, and Okeanos is the father of Nemesis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.4">

It is not the river Okeanos, but the farthest part of the sea navigated
by man, near which dwell the Iberians and the Celts, and Okeanos
surrounds the island of Britain. But of the Aethiopians beyond Syene,
those who live farthest in the direction of the Red Sea are the
Ichthyophagoi (Fish-eaters), and the gulf round which they live is
called after them. The most righteous of them inhabit the city Meroe and
what is called the Aethiopian plain. These are they who show the Table
of the Sun,[^129] and they have neither sea nor river except the Nile.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.5">

There are other Aethiopians who are neighbors of the Mauroi and extend
as far as the Nasamones. For the Nasamones, whom Herodotus calls the
Atlantes, and those who profess to know the measurements of the earth,
named the Lixitai, are the Libyans who live the farthest close to Mount
Atlas, and they do not till the ground at all, but live on wild vines.
But neither these Aethiopians nor yet the Nasamones have any river. For
the water near Atlas, which provides a beginning to three streams, does
not make any of the streams a river, as the sand swallows it all up at
once. So the Aethiopians dwell near no river Okeanos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.6">

The water from Atlas is muddy, and near the source were crocodiles of
not less than two cubits, which when the men approached dashed down into
the spring. The thought has occurred to many that it is the reappearance
of this water out of the sand which gives the Nile to Egypt. Mount Atlas
is so high that its peaks are said to touch the sky
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ouranos</span>\], but is
inaccessible because of the water and the presence everywhere of trees.
Its region indeed near the Nasamones is known, but we know of nobody yet
who has sailed along the parts facing the sea. I must now resume.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.7">

Neither this nor any other ancient statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Nemesis has
wings, for not even the holiest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hagiōtata</span>\]
wooden-images \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\]
of the people of Smyrna have them, but those who came later, wishfully
thinking that the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]
appears-in-epiphanies
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-phainesthai</span>\]
mostly as a consequence of passionate-love
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erân</span>\], make
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] wings for
Nemesis as they do for Eros \[‘passionate-love’ personified\] . I will
now go go through what has been artistically-worked
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergazesthai</span>\] into the
pedestal of the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], having made
such preliminary remarks as I have made for the sake of clarity. The
Greeks \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] say
that Nemesis was the mother of Helen, while Leda breast-fed her and
raised \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">trephein</span>\] her.
And, along these same lines, they as well as everyone else say that the
father of Helen is not Tyndareus but Zeus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.33.8">

Having heard these things Pheidias has represented Helen as being led to
Nemesis by Leda, and he has represented Tyndareus and his children with
a man Hippeus by name standing by with a horse. There are Agamemnon and
Menelaos and Pyrrhos, the son of Achilles and first husband of Hermione,
the daughter of Helen. Orestes was passed over because of his crime
against his mother, yet Hermione stayed by his side in everything and
bore him a child. Next upon the pedestal is one called Epochus and
another youth; the only thing I heard about them was that they were
brothers of Oinoe, from whom the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] has its name.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.34.1">

The land of Oropos, between Attica and the land of Tanagra, which
originally belonged to Boeotia, in our time belongs to the Athenians,
who always fought for it but never won secure possession until Philip
gave it to them after taking Thebes. Their city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] is on the coast
and affords nothing remarkable for any scientific-write-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sungraphē</span>\]. About
twelve stadium-lengths from the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Amphiaraos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.34.2">

It is said that, when Amphiaraos was fleeing from Thebes, the earth
opened up and received-from-down-below
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hupo-dekhesthai</span>\] both
him and his chariot. Except, it is also said that it did not happen
here. There is a place called the Chariot
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Harma</span>\], located on the
road from Thebes to Khalkis. It was first among the people of Oropos
that it became customary to think
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] Amphiaraos
to be a god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]. In
later time, all Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] have come
around to thinking
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hēgeîsthai</span>\] the same
way. I can enumerate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kata-legein</span>\] other
humans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] from
back then who now have honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] that belong to
gods \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\]; some even
have cities dedicated to them, such as Elaious in Chersonnesus,
dedicated to Protesilaos, and Lebadea of the Boeotians, dedicated to
Trophonios. The people of Oropos have both a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] and a white
marble statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]
of Amphiaraos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.34.3">

The altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] shows
parts. One part is to Hēraklēs, Zeus, and Apollo Healer, another is
given up to heroes and to wives of heroes, the third is to Hestia and
Hermes and Amphiaraos and the children of Amphilokhos. But Alkmaion,
because of his treatment of Eriphyle, is honored neither in the temple
of Amphiaraos nor yet with Amphilokhos. The fourth portion of the altar
is to Aphrodite and Panacea, and further to Iaso, Hygieia and Athena
Healer. The fifth is dedicated to the nymphs and to Pan, and to the
rivers Akhelōos and Kephisos. The Athenians too have an altar to
Amphilokhos in the city, and there is at Mallus in Cilicia an oracle of
his which is the most trustworthy of my day.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.34.4">

The Oropians have near the temple a spring, which they call the Spring
of Amphiaraos; they neither sacrifice into it nor are accustomed to use
it for purifications or for lustral water. But when a man has been cured
of a disease through a response the custom is to throw silver and coined
gold into the spring, for by this way they say that Amphiaraos rose up
after he had become a god. Iophon of Knossos, a guide, produced
responses in hexameter verse, saying that Amphiaraos gave them to the
Argives who were sent against Thebes. These verses unrestrainedly
appealed to popular taste. Except those whom they say Apollo inspired of
old none of the seers uttered oracles, but they were good at explaining
dreams and interpreting the flights of birds and the entrails of
victims.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.34.5">

My opinion is that Amphiaraos devoted himself most to the exposition of
dreams. It is manifest that, when his divinity was established, it was a
dream oracle that he set up. One who has come to consult Amphiaraos is
accustomed first to purify himself. The mode of purification is to
sacrifice to the god, and they sacrifice not only to him but also to all
those whose names are on the altar. And when all these things have been
first done, they sacrifice a ram, and, spreading the skin under them, go
to sleep and await enlightenment in a dream.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.1">

There are islands not far from Attica. Of the one called the Island of
Patroklos I have already given an account.[^130] There is another when
you have sailed past Sounion with Attica on the left. On this they say
that Helen landed after the capture of Troy,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.2">

and for this reason the name of the island is Helene. Salamis lies over
against Eleusis, and stretches as far as the territory of Megara. It is
said that the first to give this name to the island was Cychreus, who
called it after his mother Salamis, the daughter of Asopos, and
afterwards it was colonized by the Aeginetans with Telamon. Philaios the
son of Eurysakes the son of Ajax, is said to have handed the island over
to the Athenians, having been made an Athenian by them. Many years
afterwards the Athenians drove out all the Salaminians, having
discovered that they had been guilty of treachery in the war with
Kassandros,[^131] and mainly of set purpose had surrendered to the
Macedonians. They sentenced to death Aiskhetades, who on this occasion
had been elected general for Salamis, and they swore never to forget the
treachery of the Salaminians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.3">

There are still the remains of a marketplace, a temple of Ajax and his
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] in
ebony. Even at the present day the Athenians pay honors to Ajax himself
and to Eurysakes, for there is an altar of Eurysakes also in Athens. In
Salamis is shown a stone not far from the harbor, on which they say that
Telamon sat when he gazed at the ship in which his children were sailing
away to Aulis to take part in the joint expedition of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.4">

Those who dwell about Salamis say that it was when Ajax died that the
flower first appeared in their country. It is white and tinged with red,
both flower and leaves being smaller than those of the lily; there are
letters on it like to those on the iris. About the judgment concerning
the armor I heard a story of the Aeolians who afterwards settled at
Ilion, to the effect that when Odysseus suffered shipwreck the armor was
cast ashore near the tomb of Ajax. As to the hero’s size, a Mysian was
my informant.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.5">

He said that the sea flooded the side of the tomb facing the beach and
made it easy to enter the tomb, and he told me to form an estimate of
the size of the corpse in the following way. The bones on his knees,
called by doctors the knee-pan, were in the case of Ajax as big as the
discus of a boy in the pentathlon. I saw nothing to wonder at in the
stature of those Celts who live farthest off on the borders of the land
which is uninhabited because of the cold; these people, the Kabareîs,
are no bigger than Egyptian corpses. But I will relate all that appeared
to me worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span><span custom-style="chs_highlight">\]</span>.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.6">

For the Magnesians on the Lethaios, Protophanes, one of the citizens,
won at Olympia in one day victories in the pankration[^132] and in
wrestling. Into the tomb of this man robbers entered, thinking to gain
some advantage, and after the robbers people came in to see the corpse,
which had ribs not separated but joined together from the shoulders to
the smallest ribs, those called by doctors bastard. Before the city of
the Milesians is an island called Lade, and from it certain islets are
detached. One of these they call the islet of Asterios, and say that
Asterios was buried in it, and that Asterios was the son of Anax, and
Anax the son of Earth. Now the corpse is not less than ten cubits.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.7">

But what really caused me surprise is this. There is a small city of
upper Lydia called The Doors of Temenus. There a crest broke away in a
storm, and there appeared bones the shape of which led one to suppose
that they were human, but from their size one would never have thought
it. At once the story spread among the multitude that it was the corpse
of Geryon, the son of Khrysaor, and that the seat also was his. For
there is a man’s seat carved on a rocky spur of the mountain. And a
torrent they called the river Okeanos, and they said that men ploughing
met with the horns of cattle, for the story is that Geryon reared
excellent cows.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.35.8">

And when I criticized the account and pointed out to them that Geryon is
at Gadeira, where there is, not his tomb, but a tree showing different
shapes, the guides of the Lydians related the true story, that the
corpse is that of Hyllos, a son of Earth, from whom the river is named.
They also said that Hēraklēs from his sojourning with Omphale called his
son Hyllos after the river.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.36.1">

But I will return to my subject. In Salamis is a sanctuary of Artemis,
and also a trophy erected in honor of the victory which Themistocles the
son of Neokles won for the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\].[^133] There
is also a sanctuary of Kykhreus. When the Athenians were fighting the
Persians at sea, a serpent is said to have appeared in the fleet, and
the god in an oracle told the Athenians that it was Kykhreus the hero.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.36.2">

Before Salamis there is an island called Psyttalea. Here they say that
about four hundred of the barbarians \[= Persians\] landed, and when the
fleet of Xerxes was defeated, these also were killed after the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] had crossed
over to Psyttaleia. The island has no artistic statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], only some
roughly carved-wooden-statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\] of Pan.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.36.3">

As one goes to Eleusis from Athens along what the Athenians call the
Sacred Way \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hierā
Hodos</span>\], there is a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] that was made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]—the tomb of
Anthemokritos.[^134] The people of Megara committed against him a most
wicked deed, for when he had come as a herald to forbid them to encroach
upon the land in future they put him to death. For this act the wrath of
the Two Goddesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] lies upon them
even to this day, for they are the only Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] that not
even ‘King’ \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\]
Hadrian could make more prosperous.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.36.4">

After the tombstone of Anthemokritos comes the tomb of Molottos, who was
deemed worthy of commanding the Athenians when they crossed into
Euboea[^135] to reinforce Plutarch,[^136] and also a place called
Skiron, which received its name for the following reason. The
Eleusinians were making war against Erekhtheus when there came from
Dodona a seer called Skiros, who also set up at Phaleron the ancient
sanctuary of Athena Skiras. When he fell in the fighting the Eleusinians
buried him near a torrent, and the hero has given his name to both place
and torrent.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.36.5">

Close by is the tomb of Kephisodoros, who was champion of the people and
opposed to the utmost Philip, the son of Demetrios, king of Macedon.
Kephisodoros induced to become allies of Athens two kings, Attalos the
Mysian and Ptolemy the Egyptian, and, of the self-governing peoples, the
Aetolians with the Rhodians and the Cretans among the islanders.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.36.6">

As the reinforcements from Egypt, Mysia, and Crete were for the most
part too late, and the Rhodians, whose strength lay only in their fleet,
were of little help against the Macedonian men-at-arms, Kephisodoros
sailed with other Athenians to Italy and begged aid of the Romans.[^137]
They sent a force and a general, who so reduced Philip and the
Macedonians that afterwards Perseus, the son of Philip, lost his throne
and was himself taken prisoner to Italy. This Philip was the son of
Demetrios. Demetrios was the first of this house to hold the throne of
Macedon, having put to death Alexander, son of Kassandros, as I have
related in a former part of my account.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.1">

After the tomb of Kephisodoros is the tomb of Heliodoros Halis. A
portrait of this man is also to be seen in the great temple of Athena.
Here too is the tomb of Themistocles, son of Poliarkhos, and grandson of
the Themistocles who fought the sea fight against Xerxes and the
Persians. Of the later descendants I shall mention none except Akestion.
She, her father Xenokles, his father Sophocles, and his father Leon, all
of them up to her great-grandfather Leon won the honor of being
torch-bearers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dāidoukhoi</span>\], and in
her own lifetime she saw as torch-bearers, first her brother Sophocles,
after him her husband Themistocles, and after his death her son
Theophrastus. Such was the fortune
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tukhē</span>\], they say, that
happened to her.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.2">

A little way past the tomb of Themistocles is a precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] that is
sacred \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] to
Lakios, a hero \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\],
and there is a deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] called after
him, Lakiadai; also the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Nikokles of
Tarentum, who won a unique reputation as a citharode
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kitharōidos</span> =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kitharā</span>-singer\]. There
is also an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Zephyrus and
a sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Demeter and her daughter. With them Athena and Poseidon have honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\]. They say that
in this place \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrion</span>\]
Phytalos welcomed Demeter in his home, for which act the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\] gave
him the fig tree. This story is borne out by the inscription on the tomb
of Phytalos:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Hero \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\] and king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anax</span>\], Phytalos here
received the one who is Semnē \[‘holy’\],

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Demeter, when she first created revealed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phainein</span>\] the
fruit-of-the-harvest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpos</span>\] that comes in
the season of harvesting.

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

It is the sacred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierē</span>\] fig-tree
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sukē</span>\], that is what
the generation of mortals
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thnētoi</span>\] have have
given it as a name.[^138]

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Whence Phytalos and his lineage have received honors immortal.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.3">

Before crossing the Kephisos one comes to the tomb of Theodoros, the
best tragic actor of his day.[^139] By the river is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Mnesimakhe,
and a votive statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēma</span>\] of her son
cutting his hair as a gift for Kephisos. That this habit has existed
from ancient times among all the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] may be
inferred from the poetry of Homer,[^140] who makes Peleus vow that on
the safe return of Achilles from Troy he will cut off the young man’s
hair as a gift for the Sperkheios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.4">

Across the Kephisos is an ancient altar of Zeus Meilikhios \[‘benign’\].
At this altar Theseus obtained purification at the hands of the
descendants of Phytalus after killing brigands, including Sinis who was
related to him through Pittheus. Here is the tomb of Theodektes[^141] of
Phaselis, and also that of Mnesitheus. They say that he was a skillful
physician and dedicated statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\], among which
is a representation of Iakkhos. On the road stands a small temple called
that of Cyamites.[^142] I cannot state for certain whether he was the
first to sow beans, or whether they gave this name to a hero because
they may not attribute to Demeter the discovery of beans. Whoever has
been initiated at Eleusis or has read what are called the Orphika knows
what I mean.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.5">

Of the tombs, the largest and most beautiful are that of a Rhodian who
settled in Athens, and the one made by the Macedonian Harpalos, who ran
away from Alexander and crossed with a fleet from Asia to Europe. On his
arrival in Athens he was arrested by the citizens, but ran away after
bribing among others the friends of Alexander. But before this he
married Pythonikē, whose family I do not know, but she was a courtesan
in Athens and in Corinth. His love for her was so great that when she
died he made her a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] which is of all
the old tombs of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] the most
worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\]. .

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.6">

There is a sanctuary in which are set statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Demeter,
her daughter, Athena, and Apollo. At the first it was built in honor of
Apollo only. That is because, as they say, Kephalos the son of Deion,
having helped Amphitryon to destroy the Teleboans, was the first to
dwell \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in the
island that now is called after him Kephallenia, and they say that he
resided \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">met-oikeîn</span>\]
till that time at Thebes, exiled from Athens because he had killed his
wife Procris. In the tenth generation afterwards Khalkinos and Daitos,
descendants of Kephalos, sailed to Delphi and asked the god for
permission to return to Athens.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.37.7">

He ordered them first to sacrifice to Apollo in that spot in Attica
where they should see a man-of-war running on the land. When they
reached the mountain called the Many-colored Mountain a snake was seen
hurrying into its hole. In this place they sacrificed to Apollo;
afterwards they came to Athens and the Athenians made them citizens.
After this is a temple of Aphrodite, before which is a wall worthy of
viewing \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], made of
unfinished stone.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.1">

The streams called Rheitoi are rivers only in so far as they have a flow
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">rheuma</span>\]. I say this
because the water \[of these streams\] is sea water. It is a reasonable
belief that they flow beneath the earth from the Euripos of the people
of Kalkhis, and plunge into a sea of a lower level. The streams called
Rheitoi are said to be sacred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieroi</span>\] to the Maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Korē</span>\] and to Demeter,
and only the priests
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereîs</span>\] \[of these
goddesses\] are permitted to catch the fish in them. In ancient times, I
learn, these streams were the boundaries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">horoi</span>\] between the
land of the Eleusinians and that of the other Athenians,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.2">

and the first to dwell
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] on the other
side of the Rheitoi was Krokon, where at the present day is what is
called the royal-palace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basíleia</span>\] of Krokon.
This Krokon the Athenians say shared-his-welling
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-oikeîn</span>\] with
Saisara, daughter of Keleus. Not all of them say this, but only those
who belong to the deme
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] of Skambonidai.
I could not find the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Crocon, but
Eleusinians and Athenians both agreed in identifying the tomb of
Eumolpos. This Eumolpos they say came from Thrace, being the son of
Poseidon and Khione. Khione they say was the daughter of the wind Boreas
and of Oreithyia. Homer poetically-says
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] nothing about
the lineage \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genos</span>\] of
Eumolpos, but in his verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] he calls him
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agēnōr</span> \[‘very manly’\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.3">

When the Eleusinians fought with the Athenians, Erekhtheus, king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] of the
Athenians, was killed, as was also Immarados, son of Eumolpos. These
were the terms on which they concluded the war: the Eleusinians were in
all ways to be subject to the Athenians—except that would be on their
own in ritually-conducting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teleîn</span>\] the
\[Eleusinian\] mysteries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teletē</span>\]. The
sacred-rites \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiera</span>\]
for the Two Goddesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theai</span>\] would be
performed \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\] by
Eumolpos and by the daughters of Keleus, whom Pamphos and Homer agree in
naming Diogénia, Pammerope, and, the third, Saisara. Eumolpos was
survived by Keryx, the younger of his sons whom the Kerykes themselves
say was a son of Aglauros, daughter of Kekrops, and of Hermes, not of
Eumolpos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.4">

There is also a hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] of
Hippothoön, after whom the civic-lineage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phulē</span>\]
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek"></span>is named, and, close by,
one of Zarex. The latter they say learned the art-of-the-Muses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mousikē</span>\] from Apollo,
but my opinion is that he was a Lacedaemonian who came as a stranger
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenos</span>\] to the land,
and that after him is named Zarax, a town in the Laconian territory near
the sea. If there is a local
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrios</span>\] Athenian
hero \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\] called
Zarex, I have nothing to say concerning him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.5">

At Eleusis flows a \[stream named\] Kephisos that is more-violent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">biaioteron</span>\] than the
stream \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">rheuma</span>\] by the
same name as mentioned above, and by the side of it is the place they
call Erineus. They say that Pluto \[Ploutōn\] descended
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katabainein</span>\] there
\[to the lower world\] after abducting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazein</span>\] the Maiden
\[Korē\]. Near this Kephisos Theseus killed a brigand
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lēistēs</span>\] named
Polypemon and surnamed Procrustes.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.6">

The Eleusinians have a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Triptolemos,
of Artemis Propulaia \[‘of the Portal’\], and of Poseidon Patēr
\[‘father’\], also a well
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phrear</span>\] called
Kallikhoron \[‘beautiful place-for-dance-and-song’), where first the
women of the Eleusinians set up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">histanai</span>\] a
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khoros</span> ‘place for
song-and-dance’, and they sang
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">āidein</span>\], directing the
song at the goddess
\[(<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">he</span>)
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theā</span>, = Artemis\]. They
say that the plain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pedíon</span>\] called Rharion
was the first to be sown and the first to grow crops-for-harvest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpos</span>\], and for this
reason it is the custom to use sacrificial-barley
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oulai</span>\] from its
produce and to make cakes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pemmata</span>\] for the
sacrifices \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiai</span>\].
Here is shown what is called the threshing-floor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">halōs</span>\] of Triptolemos,
and an altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.7">

As for the things inside the wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\] of the
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\], I
had a dream \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oneiros</span>\]
about them, but this dream did not permit me to write it down. Those who
are not initiated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">telesthentes</span>\] are of
course unable to learn of the vision \[théā\] what they are prevented
from seeing. Some say that the hero
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōs</span>\] Eleusis, after
whom the city is named, is a son of Hermes and of Daeira, daughter of
Okeanos; It has been said-poetically \[poieîn\] by others, however, that
Ogygos is the father of Eleusis. Ancient stories
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\], not backed up
by poetry \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\], have
given rise to many things that people make-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">plasasthai</span>\],
especially with regard to the genealogies
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genē</span>\] of heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.8">

When you have turned from Eleusis to Boeotia you come to the Plataean
land, which borders on Attica. Formerly Eleutherai formed the boundary
on the side towards Attica, but when it came over to the Athenians
henceforth the boundary of Boeotia was Kithairon. The reason why the
people of Eleutherai came over was not because they were reduced by war,
but because they desired to share Athenian citizenship and hated the
Thebans. In this plain is a temple of Dionysus, from which the old
wooden image was carried off to Athens. The image at Eleutherai at the
present day is a copy of the old one.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.38.9">

A little farther on is a small cave, and beside it is a spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\] of cold water.
It is said about the cave that Antiope, after her labor, placed her
babies into it; as to the spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\], it is said that
the shepherd who found the babies washed them there for the first time,
taking off their swaddling clothes. Of Eleutherai there were still left
the ruins of the wall and of the houses. From these it is clear that the
city was built a little above the plain close to Kithairon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.39.1">

There is another road from Eleusis, which leads to Megara. As you go
along this road you come to a well called Anthium (Flowery Well).
Pamphos in his poems describes how Demeter in the likeness of an old
woman sat at this well after the abduction of her daughter, how the
daughters of Keleos thence took her as an Argive woman to their mother,
and how Metaneira thereupon entrusted to her the rearing of her son.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.39.2">

A little farther on from the well is a sanctuary of Metaneira, and after
it are tombs of those who went against Thebes. For Creon, who at that
time ruled in Thebes as guardian of Laodamas the son of Eteokles,
refused to allow the relatives to take up and bury their dead. But
Adrastos having supplicated Theseus, the Athenians fought with the
Boeotians, and Theseus being victorious in the fight carried the dead to
the Eleusinian territory and buried them here. The Thebans, however, say
that they voluntarily gave up the dead for burial and deny that they
engaged in battle.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.39.3">

After the tombs of the Argives is the tomb of Alope, who, they say,
after she was made pregnant by Poseidon and became mother of Hippothoön,
was at this very place put to death by her father Kerkyon. He is said to
have treated strangers wickedly, especially in wrestling with them
against their will. So even to my day this place is called the Wrestling
Ground of Kerkyon, being a little way from the tomb of Alope. Kerkyon is
said to have killed all those who tried a bout with him except Theseus,
who outmatched him mainly by his skill. For Theseus was the first to
discover the art of wrestling, and through him afterwards was
established the teaching of the art. Before him men used in wrestling
only size and strength of body. Such in my opinion are the best-known
stories \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\] and
sights \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theõrēmata</span>\]
that the Athenians possess, and from the beginning my own narrative
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] has picked out,
from such many things, those that stand out as worth writing-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-graphein</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.39.4">

Next to Eleusis is the district called Megaris. This too belonged to
Athens in ancient times, Pylas the king having left it to Pandion. My
evidence is this; in the land is the tomb of Pandion, and Nisos, while
giving up the rule over the Athenians to Aigeus, the eldest of all the
family, was himself made king of Megara and of the territory as far as
Corinth. Even at the present day the port of the Megarians is called
Nisaia after him. Subsequently in the reign of Kodros the Peloponnesians
made an expedition against Athens. Having accomplished nothing
brilliant, on their way home they took Megara from the Athenians, and
gave it as a dwelling-place to such of the Corinthians and of their
other allies as wished to go there.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.39.5">

In this way the Megarians changed their customs and dialect and became
Dorians, and they say that the city received its name when Kar the son
of Phoroneus was king in this land. It was then they say that
sanctuaries of Demeter were first made by them, and then that men used
the name Megara (Chambers). This is their history according to the
Megarians themselves. But the Boeotians declare that Megareus, son of
Poseidon, who dwelled in Onkhestos, came with an army of Boeotians to
help Nisos wage the war against Minos; that falling in the battle he was
buried on the spot, and the city was named Megara from him, having
previously been called Nisa.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.39.6">

In the twelfth generation after Kar the son of Phoroneus the Megarians
say that Lelex arrived from Egypt and became king, and that in his reign
the tribe Leleges received its name. Lelex they say fathered Kleson,
Kleson Pylas and Pylas Skiron, who married the daughter of Pandion and
afterwards disputed with Nisos, the son of Pandion, about the throne,
the dispute being settled by Aiakos, who gave the kingship to Nisos and
his descendants, and to Skīrōn the leadership in war. They say further
that Nisos was succeeded by Megareus, the son of Poseidon, who married
Iphinoe, the daughter of Nisos, but they ignore altogether the Cretan
war and the capture of the city in the reign of Nisos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.40.1">

There is in the city a fountain, which was built for the citizens by
Theagenes,[^143] whom I have mentioned previously as having given his
daughter in marriage to Kylon the Athenian. This Theagenes upon becoming
tyrant built the fountain, which is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] for its size,
beauty and the number of its pillars. Water flows into it called the
water of the Sithnid nymphs. The Megarians say that the Sithnid nymphs
are native, and that one of them mated with Zeus; that Megaros, a son of
Zeus and of this nymph, escaped the flood in the time of Deukalion, and
made his escape to the heights of Gerania. The mountain had not yet
received this name, but was then named Gerania (Crane Heights) because
cranes were flying and Megaros swam towards the cry of the birds.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.40.2">

Not far from this fountain is an ancient sanctuary, and in our day
likenesses \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikónes</span>\]
stand in it of Roman emperors, and a bronze statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is there of
Artemis surnamed Savior. There is a story that a detachment of the army
of Mardonios, having overrun Megaris,[^144] wished to return to
Mardonios at Thebes, but that by the will of Artemis night came on them
as they marched, and missing their way they turned into the hilly
region. Trying to find out whether there was a hostile force near they
shot some missiles. The rock near groaned when struck, and they shot
again with greater eagerness,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.40.3">

until at last they used up all their arrows thinking that they were
shooting at the enemy. When the day broke, the Megarians attacked, and
being men in armor fighting against men without armor who no longer had
even a supply of missiles, they killed the greater number of their
opponents. For this reason they had an image made of Artemis Savior.
Here are also statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of the gods
named the Twelve, said to be the work of Praxiteles. But the image of
Artemis herself was made by Strongylion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.40.4">

After this, as one enters the precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] of Zeus
called the Olympieion, there is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of his there
that is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\]. But the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Zeus was
not finished, for the work was interrupted by the war of the
Peloponnesians against the Athenians, in which the Athenians every year
ravaged the land of the Megarians with a fleet and an army, damaging
public revenues and bringing private families to dire distress. The face
of the statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]
of Zeus is of ivory and gold, the other parts are of clay and gypsum.
The artist is said to have been Theokosmos, a native, helped by
Pheidias. Above the head of Zeus are the Seasons and Fates, and all may
see that he is the only god obeyed by Destiny, and that he apportions
the seasons as is due. Behind the temple lie half-worked pieces of wood,
which Theokosmos intended to overlay with ivory and gold in order a
complete the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Zeus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.40.5">

In the temple itself is dedicated a bronze ram of a galley. This ship
they say that they captured off Salamis in a naval action with the
Athenians. The Athenians too admit that for a time they evacuated the
island before the Megarians, saying that afterwards Solon[^145] wrote
elegiac poems and encouraged them, and that thereupon the Athenians
challenged their enemies, won the war and recovered Salamis. But the
Megarians say that exiles from themselves, whom they call Dorycleans,
reached the colonists in Salamis and betrayed the island to the
Athenians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.40.6">

After the precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] of Zeus, as
one goes up to the acropolis, which even at the present day is called
Karia from Kar, son of Phoroneus, there is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Dionysus
Nyktelios \[of the night\], also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] for Aphrodite
Epistrophiā \[‘she-who-turns-(humans-)to-love’\], also an oracle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteîon</span>\] called ‘of
the Night’, also a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Zeus Konios
\[‘of the dust’\], which does not have a roof. The statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Asklepios
and also that of Hygieia were made by Bryaxis. Here too is what is
called the Chamber
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">megaron</span>\] of Demeter,
which was made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\], they say, by
Kar when he was king.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.1">

As one comes down from the acropolis, where the ground turns northwards,
is the tomb of Alkmene, near the Olympieion. They say that as she was
walking from Argos to Thebes she died on the way at Megara, and that the
Herakleidai got into a dispute, some wishing to convey
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] the corpse
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nekros</span>\] of Alkmene
back to Argos, others wishing to take it to Thebes, as in Thebes were
buried Amphitryon and the children of Hēraklēs that were mothered by
Megara. But the god in Delphi gave them an oracle that it was better for
them to bury Alkmene in Megara.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.2">

From this place the local guide took us to a place which he said was
named Rhous (Stream), for that water once flowed here from the mountains
above the city. But Theagenes, who was tyrant at that time, turned the
water into another direction and made here an altar to Akhelōos. Close
by is the tomb of Hyllos, son of Hēraklēs, who fought a duel with an
Arcadian, Ekhemos the son of Aeropos. Who the Ekhemos was who killed
Hyllos I will tell in another part of my narrative, but Hyllos also is
buried at Megara. These events might correctly be called an expedition
of the Herakleidai into the Peloponnesus in the reign of Orestes.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.3">

Not far from the tomb of Hyllos is a temple of Isis, and beside it one
of Apollo and of Artemis. They say that Alkathoos made it after killing
the lion from Kithairon, as he is called. By this lion they say many
were killed, including Euhippos, the son of Megareus their king, whose
elder son Timalkos had before this been killed by Theseus while on a
campaign with the Dioskouroi against Aphidna. Megareus they say promised
that he who killed the lion of Kithairon should marry his daughter and
succeed him in the kingdom. Alkathoos therefore, son of Pelops, attacked
the beast and overcame it, and when he came to the throne he built this
sanctuary, surnaming Artemis as Agrotera \[‘Huntress’\] and Apollo
Agraios \[‘Hunter’\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.4">

Such is the account of the Megarians; but although I wish my account to
agree with theirs, yet I cannot accept everything they say. I am ready
to believe that a lion was killed by Alkathoos on Kithairon, but what
historian has recorded that Timalkos the son of Megareus came with the
Dioskouroi to Aphidna? And supposing he had gone there, how could one
hold that he had been killed by Theseus, when Alcman wrote a poem on the
Dioskouroi,[^146] in which he says that they captured Athens and carried
into captivity the mother of Theseus, but Theseus himself was absent?

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.5">

Pindar in his poems agrees with this account, saying that Theseus,
wishing to be related to the Dioskouroi, carried off Helen and kept her
until he departed to carry out with Peirithoös the marriage that they
tell of. Whoever has studied genealogy finds the Megarians guilty of
great silliness, since Theseus was a descendant of Pelops. The fact is
that the Megarians know the true story but conceal it, not wishing it to
be thought that their city was captured in the reign of Nisos, but that
both Megareus, the son-in-law of Nisos, and Alkathoos, the son-in-law of
Megareus, succeeded their respective fathers-in-law as king.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.6">

It is evident that Alkathoos arrived from Elis just at the time when
Nisos had died and the people of Megara had lost everything.
Witness-to-the-truth
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">marturion</span>\] of what I
say is that he built the wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\] all over
again, from the start, since the old enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] \[round the
city\] had been destroyed by the Cretans. Let so much suffice for memory
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] about Alkathoos
and the lion, whether it was on Kithairon or elsewhere that the killing
took place that caused him to make a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] to Artemis
Agrotera and Apollo Agraios. As one goes down from this sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] there is the
hero-shrine \[hērōion\] of Pandion. My narrative
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] has already
told how Pandion was buried on what is called the Rock
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skopelos</span>\] of Athena
Aithuia \[‘Gannet’\]. He receives honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] from the people
of Megara in the city as well.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.7">

Near the hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] of Pandion is
the tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of
Hippolyte. I will write down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] the kinds of
things that the people of Megara say with regard to her. When the
Amazons, having made war against the Athenians because of Antiope, were
defeated by Theseus, most of them met their death in the fighting, but
Hippolyte, the sister of Antiope and on this occasion the leader of the
women, escaped with a few others to Megara. Having failed so badly with
her army and feeling disheartened
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">athumōs ekhein</span>\] at her
present situation, given that she felt-there-was-no-way-out
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aporeîn</span>\] with regard
to getting back home in safety
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōtēriā</span>\] to
Themiskyra, she died in her sorrow
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lupē</span>\]. And, now that
she was dead, the people of Megara buried her. The shape
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\] of her tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] is like an
Amazonian shield
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aspis</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.8">

Not far from this is the tomb of Tereus, who married Procne the daughter
of Pandion. The Megarians say that Tereus was king of the region around
what is called Pagai \[‘springs’\] of Megaris, but my opinion, which is
confirmed by extant evidence, is that he ruled over Daulis beyond
Khairōneia, for in ancient times the greater part of what is now called
Greece \[Hellas\] was inhabited by barbarians. When Tereus did what he
did to Philomela and Itys suffered at the hands of the women, Tereus
found himself unable to seize them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.41.9">

He committed suicide in Megara, and the Megarians forthwith raised him a
barrow, and every year sacrifice to him, using in the sacrifice gravel
instead of barley meal; they say that the bird called the hoopoe
appeared here for the first time. The women came to Athens, and while
lamenting their sufferings and their revenge, perished through their
tears; their reported metamorphosis into a nightingale and a swallow is
due, I think, to the fact that the note of these birds is plaintive and
like a lamentation.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.1">

The Megarians have another citadel, which is named after Alkathoos. As
you ascend this citadel you see on the right the tomb of Megareus, who
at the time of the Cretan invasion came as an ally from Onkhestos. There
is also shown a hearth of the gods called Prodomeis (Builders before).
They say that Alkathoos was the first to sacrifice to them, at the time
when he was about to begin the building of the wall.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.2">

Near this hearth is a stone, on which they say Apollo laid his lyre when
he was helping Alkathoos in the building. I am confirmed in my view that
the Megarians used to be tributary to the Athenians by the fact that
Alkathoos appears to have sent his daughter Periboia with Theseus to
Crete in payment of the tribute. On the occasion of his building the
wall, the Megarians say, Apollo helped him and placed his lyre on the
stone; and if you happen to hit it with a pebble it sounds just as a
lyre does when struck.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.3">

This made me marvel, but the colossus in Egypt made me marvel far more
than anything else. In Egyptian Thebes, on crossing the Nile to the
so-called Pipes, I saw a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], still
sitting, which gave out a sound. The many call it Memnon, who they say
from Aethiopia overran Egypt and as far as Susa. The Thebans, however,
say that it is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], not of
Memnon, but of a native named Phamenoph, and I have heard some say that
it is Sesostris. This statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] was broken in
two by Cambyses, and at the present day from head to middle it is thrown
down; but the rest is seated, and every day at the rising of the sun it
makes a noise, and the sound one could best liken to that of a harp or
lyre when a string has been broken.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.4">

The Megarians have a council chamber which once, they say, was the tomb
of Timalkos, who just now I said was not killed by Theseus. On the top
of the citadel is built a temple of Athena, with a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] gilded except
the hands and feet; these and the face are of ivory. There is another
sanctuary built here, of Athena Nike, and yet a third of Athena Aiantis.
About the last the Megarian guides have omitted to record anything, but
