I will write what I take to be the facts. Telamon the son of Aiakos
married Periboia the daughter of Alkathoos; so my opinion is that Ajax,
who succeeded to the throne of Alkathoos, made the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Athena.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.5">

The ancient temple of Apollo was of brick, but ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] Hadrian
afterwards built it of white marble. The Apollo called Pythian and the
one called Dekatephoros \[’he who wins Tithes as a prize’\] are very
like the Egyptian wooden-statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\] , but the one
surnamed Arkhegetes \[‘Founder’\] resembles Aeginetan works. They are
all alike made of ebony. I have heard a man of Cyprus, who was skilled
at sorting herbs for medicinal purposes, say that the ebony does not
grow leaves or bear fruit, or even appear in the sunlight at all, but
consists of underground roots which are dug up by the Aethiopians, who
have men skilled at finding ebony.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.6">

There is also a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Demeter
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Thesmophoros</span>. As one goes
down from it there is the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Kallipolis,
son of Alkathoos. Alkathoos had also an elder son, Iskhepolis, whom his
father sent to help Meleagros to destroy the wild-beast
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thērion</span>\] in Aetolia.
There he died, and Kallipolis was the first to hear of his death.
Running up to the acropolis, at the moment when his father was lighting
a fire for Apollo, he flung the logs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xula</span>\] from the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\]. Alkathoos, who
had not yet heard of the fate of Iskhepolis, judged that Kallipolis was
guilty of impiety, and forthwith, angry as he was, killed him by
striking his head with one of the logs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xula</span>\] that had been
flung from the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.42.7">

On the road to the Prytaneion \[‘City Hall’\] \[of Megara\] is the
hero-shrine \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\]
of Ino, around which is a fencing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thrinkos</span>\] of stones.
Olive trees grow there. The people of Megara are the only Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] who say that
the corpse \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nekros</span>\] of
Ino had washed ashore on their coast; more, they say that Klēsō and
Tauropolis, the daughters of Klēsōn son of Lelex, found and buried it;
even more, they say that it was in their locale \[= Megara\] that Ino
was for the first time named White Goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Leukotheā</span>\], and every
year a sacrificial-feast
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\] is celebrated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] in her honor.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.1">

They say that there is also at that place a hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] of
Iphigeneia, since, according to them, she died in Megara. Now I have
heard another account of Iphigeneia that is given by Arcadians and I
know that Hesiod, in the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Catalogue of Women</span>,
makes-it-happen-in-his poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] that Iphigenia
does not die, but, by the will of Artemis, is Hekate. With this agrees
Herodotus, who writes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">graphein</span>\] that the
Tauroi near Scythia sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] those who are
shipwrecked to a maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\], and they
say that this maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\] is
Iphigeneia, the daughter of Agamemnon. Adrastos also has honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] \[of hero
cult\] among the people of Megara, who say that he too died among them
when he was leading back his army after capturing Thebes, and that his
death was caused by old age and by the death of Aigialeus. A sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Artemis was
made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] by
Agamemnon when he came to persuade Calchas, who dwelled
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in Megara, to
accompany him to Troy.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.2">

In the Prytaneion \[‘City Hall’\] are buried, they say, Euhippos the son
of Megareus and Iskhepolis the son of Alkathoos. Near the Prytaneion
\[‘City Hall’\] is a rock
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">petrā</span>\]. They name it
Anaklēthris \[‘calling-to-come-back’\], because Demeter—if this is
credible to anyone—in this place too \[= Megara, not only in other
places\] was-calling-back
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-kaleîn</span>\] her
daughter while wandering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">planâsthai</span>\] in search
of her. Even in our day the women of Megara sacrally-perform
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\]
actions-that-look-like
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eoikóta</span>\]
what-the-words-of-the-story-say
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.3">

In the city are tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] of Megarians.
They made one for those who died in the invasion of the Medes
\[Persians\], and what is called the Aisymnion \[‘Shrine of Aisymnos’\]
was also a tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\]
of heroes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\].
When Agamemnon’s son Hyperion, the last who ruled-as-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\] over the
people of Megara, was killed by Sandion for his greed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pleonexiā</span>\] and
violence \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">biā</span>\], they
resolved no longer to be ruled-by-kings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuesthai</span>\] by way
of one-man rule, but to have elected
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hairetoi</span>\] magistrates
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhontes</span>\] and to obey
one another by-taking-turns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana meros</span>\]. Then
Aisymnos, who had a reputation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">doxa</span>\] second to none
among the Megarians, came to the god
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\] in Delphi and
asked in what way they could be-fortunate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eudaimoneîn</span>\]. The god
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]
said-in-oracular-reply
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrêsai</span>\] that they
would fare well if they took-counsel
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleuein</span>\] with the
majority. This poetic-utterance
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epos</span>\] they took to
refer to the dead, and built a council-chamber
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleutērion</span>\] in this
place in order that the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of their
heroes \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\] might
be inside the council-chamber
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bouleutērion</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.4">

Proceeding from there to the hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] of Alkathoos,
which in my day the people of Megara used as a place for the
safe-keeping \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phulakē</span>\]
of written-records
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">grammata</span>\], was the
tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\], they
said, of Pyrgo, the wife of Alkathoos before he married Euaikhme, the
daughter of Megareus, and the tomb of Iphinoe, the daughter of
Alkathoos; she died, they say, a still a virgin
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\]. It is
customary for the girls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">korai</span>\] to bring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pros-pherein</span>\]
libations \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khoai</span>\] to
the tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of
Iphinoe and to make-an-offering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ap-arkhesthai</span>\] of
their \[cut\] hair before their wedding
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gamos</span>\], just as the
daughters of the people of Delos once cut their hair for Hekaerge and
Opis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.5">

Beside the entrance
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">esodos</span>\] to the
sanctuary-of-Dionysus
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Dionusion</span>\] is the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Astykrateia
and Manto. They were daughters of Polyidos, son of Koiranos, son of
Abas, son of Melampous, who came to Megara to purify
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kathairein</span>\] Alkathoos
in-compensation-for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> + dative case\] his
killing \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phonos</span>\] of his
son Kallipolis. Polyidus also built the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Dionysus,
and dedicated a wooden-image
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\] that in our
day is covered up except for the face
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prosōpon</span>\], which alone
is exposed. By the side of it is a Satyr of Parian marble made by
Praxiteles. This Dionysus they call Patrōos \[‘Ancestral’\]; but the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
another, which they surname Dasyllios, they say was dedicated by
Eukhenor, son of Koiranos, son of Polyidos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.6">

After the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Dionysus is
a temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Aphrodite, with an ivory statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Aphrodite
surnamed Praxis \[‘Fulfilled Action’\]. This is the oldest object in the
temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]. There is
also Peithō \[‘Persuasion’\] and another goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine) \],
whom they name Parēgoros \[‘consoler’\]—works of Praxiteles. By the
workmanship of Scopas are Erōs \[‘passionate-love’\] and Himeros
\[‘desire’\] and Pothos \[‘yearning’\], if indeed their functions
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\] are as different
as their names. Near the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Aphrodite is
a sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Tukhē \[‘Fortune’\], the workmanship
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekhnē</span>\] of Praxiteles.
In the temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\]
close by are Muses and a bronze Zeus by Lysippos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.7">

The people of Megara have also the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Koroibos.
The poetic-verses \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\]
about him, although they are shared
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koina</span>\] by the people
of Argos, I will make clear here. They say that in the reign of Krotopos
at Argos, Psamathe, the daughter of Krotopos, bore a son to Apollo, and
being in dire terror of her father, exposed the child. He was found and
destroyed by sheepdogs of Krotopos, and Apollo sent Poinē
\[‘vengeance’\] to the city to punish the people of Argos. They say that
she used to snatch
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harpazein</span>\] children
from their mothers, until Koroibos to please the the people of Argos
killed Poinē. At which point, as a second punishment, a plague fell upon
them and did not let up. So Koroibos of his own accord went to Delphi to
submit to the punishment of the god for having slain Poinē.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.43.8">

The Pythia would not allow Koroibos to return to Argos, but ordered him
to take up a tripod and carry it out of the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\], and where the
tripod should fall from his hands, there he was to build a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Apollo and to
dwell \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] there
himself. At Mount Gerania the tripod slipped and fell unawares. Here he
dwelled \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in the
district \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kōmê</span>\] called
the Little-Tripods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Tripodiskoi</span>\]. The tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Koroibos is
in the marketplace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agorā</span>\] of the people
of Megara. Elegiac
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">elegeia</span>\] verses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] about Psamathe
and of himself are written there \[on the tomb\], and further, as an
emplacement on top of the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] is represented
Koroibos slaying Poinē. These are the oldest stone statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] I am aware
of having seen among the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.1">

Near Koroibos is buried Orsippos who won the foot-race at Olympia by
running naked when all his competitors wore waistbands according to
ancient custom.[^147] They say also that Orsippos when general
afterwards annexed some of the neighboring territory. My own opinion is
that at Olympia he intentionally let the waistband slip off him,
realizing that a naked man can run more easily than one who is wearing a
waistband.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.2">

As one goes down from the marketplace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agorā</span>\] there is on the
right of the street called Eutheia \[‘Straight’\] a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Apollo
Prostaterios \[‘Protecting’\]. One must turn a little aside from the
road to discover it. In it is an Apollo worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], and there is an
Artemis also, and Leto, and other statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\], made by
Praxiteles. In the old gymnasium near the gate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pulai</span>\] called the
Nymphades is a stone
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">lithos</span>\] of the shape
of a small pyramid. This they name Apollo Karinos, and at this place
there is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of the
Eileithuiai. Such are the sights that the city had for the showing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epideixis</span>.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.3">

When one has gone down to the port
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epineion</span>\], which to
the present day is called Nisaia, there is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Demeter
Mālophoros. One of the accounts given of the surname
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\] is that
those who first raised sheep
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">probata</span>, =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">māla</span> in the local
dialect\] in the land named Demeter Mālophoros \[‘she who brings
sheep’\]. The roof of the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] one might
conclude has fallen in through age. There is an acropolis here, which
also is called Nisaia. Below the acropolis near the sea is the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Lelex, who
they say arrived from Egypt and became-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileusai</span>\], being the
son of Poseidon and of Libya, daughter of Epaphos. Parallel to Nisaia
lies the small island of Minoa, where in the war against Nisos anchored
the fleet of the Cretans.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.4">

The mountainous part of the region of Megara borders upon Boeotia, and
in it the people of Megara have built the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] Pagai and
another one called Aigosthena. As one goes to Pagai, on turning a little
aside from the highway
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">leōphoros</span>\], one is
shown a rock \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">petrā</span>\]
with arrows stuck all over it, into which the Persians
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mēdoi</span>\] once shot in
the night. In Pagai a relic worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] is a bronze
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Artemis surnamed Sōteira \[‘Savior’\], in size equal to that at Megara
and exactly like it in pose
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\]. There is also
a hero-shrine \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\]
of Aigialeus, son of Adrastos. When the men of Argos made their second
assault on Thebes he died at Glisas early in the first battle, and his
near-and-dear carried
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizein</span>\] him to Pagai
in the territory of Megara and buried him there. The hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\] is still now
called the Aigialeion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.5">

In Aigosthena is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Melampous,
son of Amythaon, and a small figure of a man carved upon a stele
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stēlē</span>\]. To Melampous
they sacrifice \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\]
and celebrate \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] a
festival \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\] every
year. They say that he divines neither by dreams nor in any other way.
Here is something else that I heard in Ereneia, a district
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kōmē</span>\] of the people of
Megara. Autonoe, daughter of Kadmos, left Thebes to live here owing to
her great grief at the death of Aktaion, as the story-is-told
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legesthai</span>\], and at the
general misfortune of her father’s house. The tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Autonoe is
in this district
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kōmē</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.6">

As one proceeds from Megara to Corinth, there are tombs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\], including
that of the <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aulos</span>-player
Telephanes of Samos.[^148] The tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] is said to
have been made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\]
by Kleopatra, daughter of Philip son of Amyntas. There is also the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Kar, son of
Phoroneus, which was originally a piled-up-mound
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōma</span>\] of earth, but
afterwards, in accordance with what the god
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]
said-in-an-oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsai</span>\], it was
adorned \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kosmeîn</span>\] with
a kind of stone known as
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">konkhītēs</span>
\[‘in-which-seashells
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">konkhoi</span>\]-are-embedded’\].
The people of Megara are the only Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\] to possess
this kind of <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">konkhītēs</span>
stone, and in the city also they have made
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] many things
out of it. It is very white, and softer than other stone; embedded in it
through and through are seashells
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">konkhoi</span>\]. Such, then,
is the stone itself. \[As for rock formations that are also white...\]
There is a road called Skīrōnis—that is what it is called even to this
day—and it is named after Skīrōn \[= ‘he of the White Rock’\]. This
Skīrōn, when he was the military leader of the people of Megara, was the
first, they say, to make
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] it \[=
Skīrōnis\] a road usable enough for men who outfit themselves for
travel. But then ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] Hadrian
broadened it, and made it more usable—so much so that even chariots
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harmata</span>\] could pass
each other going in opposite directions.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.7">

There are tales told with regard to those \[white\] rocks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">petrai</span>\] that become
ever more elevated as the road narrows. One of these \[elevated white
rock formations\] is a rock called Molouris, and it is from here, they
say, that Ino threw
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">rhiptein</span>\] herself into
the sea while holding Melikertes, the younger of her children. Learkhos,
the elder of them, had been killed by his father. It is said by some
that Athamas did \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\]
this in-a-state-of-madness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manēnai</span>\]; but others
say that he vented on Ino and her children his uncontrollable rage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thūmos</span>\] when he
learned about the famine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">līmos</span>\] that befell the
people of Orkhomenos and about the death—as he supposed—of Phrixos. He
\[= Athamas\] supposed that all the things happened not because of
divine power \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò
theion</span>\] but because of plotting by Ino, the stepmother.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.8">

Then it was that she \[= Ino\] fled to the sea and precipitated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphiénai</span>\] herself and
her son from the Rock
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Petrā</span>\] that is
Molouris. The son, they say, was brought to land on the Isthmus of
Corinth by a dolphin, and honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] were given to
Melikertes, thereafter renamed Palaimon. One of these honors,
in-compensation-for
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi</span> + dative case\]
him, was the celebrating
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] of the
competition \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōn</span>\]
called the Isthmia. The Rock
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Petrā</span>\] that is
Molouris has been considered to be sacred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierā</span>\] to the White
Goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Leukotheā</span>\] and
Palaimon. But the other rocks, as one travels further, are
customarily-thought
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] to be
polluted \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">en-ageis</span>\], in
that Skīrōn \[= ‘he of the White Rock’\], dwelling there
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">par-oikeîn</span>\], used to
cast into the sea all the strangers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenoi</span>\] he met. A
turtle used to swim under the rocks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">petrai</span>\] to seize those
that fell in. Sea turtles are like land turtles except for their size
and for the shape of their feet, which are like those of seals.
Retribution \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikē</span>\] for
these things overtook Skīrōn, for he was precipitated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphiénai</span>\] into the
same sea by Theseus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.9">

\[Digression...\] On the top of a mountain \[in Aegina\] that is called
The Mountain \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Oros</span>\] is
a shrine \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Zeus
surnamed the Precipitator
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Aphésios</span>, derived from
the verb <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphiénai</span>
‘precipitate’\]. It is said that, on the occasion of the drought
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aukhmos</span>\] that once
afflicted the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\], Aiakos in
obedience to an oracular-instruction
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logion</span>\] made-sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] in Aegina to
Zeus Pan-Hellēnios, and that Zeus made-precipitation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphiénai</span>\], saving
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizen</span>\] them \[from
the drought\] and thus getting the name
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Aphésios</span> \[derived from
the verb <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphiénai</span>
‘release’\]. \[Back from the digression, to Megara ...\] There are also
statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of
Aphrodite, Apollo, and Pan.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:1.44.10">

Farther on is the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Eurystheus.
They say that he fled from Attica after the battle with the Herakleidai
and was killed here by Iolaos. Further down from this road is a
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Apollo Lātōios, and then, after that, there are the limits
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">horoi</span>\] between Megara
and Corinth, where they say that Hyllos, son of Hēraklēs,
fought-in-single-combat
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">monomakheîn</span>\] with
Ekhemos of Arcadia.

</div>

## Scroll II. Corinth

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.1">

The Corinthian land is a portion of the Argive, and is named after
Korinthos. That Korinthos was a son of Zeus I have never known anybody
say seriously except the majority of the Corinthians. Eumēlos, the son
of Amphilytos,[^149] of the family called Bakkhidai, who is said to have
composed the epic poem, says in his Corinthian History (if indeed the
history be his) that Ephyra, the daughter of Okeanos, dwelled first in
this land; that afterwards Marathon, the son of Epopeus, the son of
Aloeus, the son of Hēlios \[Sun\], fleeing from the lawless violence of
his father, migrated to the sea coast of Attica; that on the death of
Epopeus he came to Peloponnesus, divided his kingdom among his sons, and
returned to Attica; and that Asopia was renamed after Sikyon, and
Ephyraia after Korinthos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.2">

Corinth is no longer inhabited by any of the old Corinthians, but by
colonists sent out by the Romans. This change is due to the Achaean
League.[^150] The Corinthians, being members of it, joined in the war
against the Romans, which Kritolaos, when appointed general of the
Achaeans, brought about by persuading to revolt both the Achaeans and
the majority \[of the Greeks outside the Peloponnesus. When the Romans
won the war, they carried out a general disarmament of the Greeks
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hellēnes</span>\][^151] and
dismantled the walls of such cities as were fortified. Corinth was laid
waste by Mummius, who at that time commanded the Romans in the field,
and it is said that it was afterwards refounded by Caesar,[^152] who was
the author of the present constitution of Rome. Carthage, too, they say,
was refounded in his reign.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.3">

In the Corinthian territory is also the place called Cromyon from Cromus
the son of Poseidon. Here they say that Phaia was bred; overcoming this
sow was one of the traditional achievements of Theseus. Farther on the
pine still grew by the shore at the time of my visit, and there was an
altar of Melikertes. At this place, they say, the boy was brought ashore
by a dolphin; Sisyphus found him lying and gave him burial on the
Isthmus, establishing the Isthmian games in his honor.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.4">

At the beginning of the Isthmus is the place where the brigand Sinis
used to take hold of pine trees and draw them down. All those whom he
overcame in fight he used to tie to the trees, and then allow them to
swing up again. Thereupon each of the pines used to drag to itself the
bound man, and as the bond gave way in neither direction but was
stretched equally in both, he was torn in two. This was the way in which
Sinis himself was slain by Theseus. For Theseus rid of evildoers the
road from Troizen to Athens, killing those whom I have enumerated and,
in sacred Epidaurus, Periphetes, thought to be the son of Hephaistos,
who used to fight with a bronze club.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.5">

The Corinthian Isthmus stretches on the one hand to the sea at
Kenkhreai, and on the other to the sea at Lekhaion. For this is what
makes the region to the south mainland. He who tried to make the
Peloponnesus an island gave up before digging through the Isthmus. Where
they began to dig is still to be seen, but into the rock they did not
advance at all. So it still is mainland as its nature is to be.
Alexander the son of Philip wished to dig through Mimas, and his attempt
to do this was his only unsuccessful project. The people of Knidos began
to dig through their isthmus, but the Pythian priestess stopped them. So
difficult it is for man to alter by violence the things that belong to
the gods \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tà theia</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.6">

What is said by the Corinthians about their land is not peculiar to
them, for I believe that the Athenians were the first to relate a
similar story to glorify Attica. The Corinthians too say that Poseidon
had a dispute with Hēlios \[Sun\] about the land, and that Briareos
arbitrated between them, assigning to Poseidon the Isthmus and the parts
adjoining, and giving to Hēlios the height above the city. Ever since,
they say, the Isthmus has belonged to Poseidon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.7">

Worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\] here are a
theater and a white-marble race-course. Within the sanctuary of the god
stand on the one side portrait statues of athletes who have won
victories at the Isthmian games, on the other side pine trees growing in
a row, the greater number of them rising up straight. On the temple,
which is not very large, stand bronze Tritons. In the front part of the
temple are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\], two of
Poseidon, a third of Amphitrite, and a Sea, which also is of bronze. The
offerings inside were dedicated in our time by Herodes the Athenian,
four horses, gilded except for the hoofs, which are of ivory,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.8">

and two gold Tritons beside the horses, with the parts below the waist
of ivory. On the car stand Amphitrite and Poseidon, and there is the boy
Palaimon upright upon a dolphin. These too are made of ivory and gold.
On the middle of the base on which the car is has been crafted a Sea
holding up the young Aphrodite, and on either side are the nymphs called
Nereids. I know that there are altars to these in other parts of Greece,
and that some Greeks have even dedicated to them precincts by shores,
where honors are also paid to Achilles. In Gabala is a holy sanctuary of
Doto, where there was still remaining the robe by which the Greeks say
that Eriphyle was bribed to wrong her son Alkmaion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.1.9">

Among the reliefs on the base of the statue of Poseidon are the sons of
Tyndareus, because these too are saviors of ships and of sea-faring men.
The other offerings are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Calm and
of Sea, a horse like a whale from the breast onward, Ino and
Bellerophontes, and the horse Pegasus \[Pegasos\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.1">

Within the enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] is on the
left a temple \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of
Palaimon, with statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] in it of
Poseidon, Leukothea, and Palaimon himself. There is also what is called
his Holy-of-Holies
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Aduton</span>
‘impenetrable’\], and an underground-descent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kathodos</span>\] to it, where
they say that Palaimon is concealed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kruptesthai</span>\].
Whosoever, whether Corinthian or stranger
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenos</span>\], swears falsely
here, will find no way
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēkhanē</span>\] to escape
from his oath. There is also an ancient
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhaion</span>\] sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] called the
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of the
Cyclopes, and they sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] to the
Cyclopes upon it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.2">

The tombs \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphoi</span>\] of
Sisyphus and of Neleus—for they say that Neleus came to Corinth, died of
disease, and was buried near the Isthmus—I do not think that anyone
would look for after reading Eumēlos. For he says that not even to
Nestor did Sisyphus show the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Neleus,
because it must
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēnai</span>\] be kept
unknown to everybody alike, and that Sisyphus is indeed buried on the
Isthmus, but that few Corinthians, even those of his own day, knew where
the tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] was.
The Isthmian Competition
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agōn</span>\] was not
interrupted even when Corinth had been destroyed by Mummius, but so long
as it \[= Corinth\] was depopulated the celebrating
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] of the Contest
was entrusted to the people of Sikyon, and when it was repopulated the
honor \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmē</span>\] was
restored to the present population.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.3">

The names of the Corinthian harbors were given them by Lekhes and
Cenchrias, said to be the children of Poseidon and Peirene the daughter
of Akhelōos, though in the poem called The Great
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Ehoiai</span> Peirene is said to
be a daughter of Oibalos. In Lechaion are a sanctuary and a bronze
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Poseidon, and on the road leading from the Isthmus to Cenchreae a temple
and ancient wooden-statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\]of Artemis. In
Kenkhreai are a temple and a stone statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Aphrodite,
after it on the mole running into the sea a bronze statue of Poseidon,
and at the other end of the harbor sanctuaries of Asklepios and of Isis.
Right opposite Kenkhreai is Helen’s Bath. It is a large stream of salt,
tepid water, flowing from a rock into the sea.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.4">

As one goes up to Corinth are tombs, and by the gate is buried Diogenes
of Sinope, whom the Greeks surname the Dog. Before the city is a grove
of cypresses called Craneum. Here are a precinct of Bellerophontes, a
temple of Aphrodite Melainis and the tomb of Lais, upon which is set a
lioness holding a ram in her fore-paws.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.5">

There is in Thessaly another tomb which claims to be that of Lais, for
she went to that country also when she fell in love with Hippostratos.
The story is that originally she was of Hycara in Sicily. Taken captive
while yet a girl by Nikias and the Athenians, she was sold and brought
to Corinth, where she surpassed in beauty the courtesans of her time,
and so won the admiration of the Corinthians that even now they claim
Lais as their own.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.6">

The things worthy of mention in the city include the extant remains of
antiquity, but the greater number of them belong to the period of its
second ascendancy. On the marketplace, where most of the sanctuaries
are, stand Artemis surnamed Ephesian and wooden images of Dionysus,
which are covered with gold with the exception of their faces; these are
ornamented with red paint. They are called Lysius and Baccheus,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.7">

and I too give the story told about them. They say that Pentheus treated
Dionysus despitefully, his crowning outrage being that he went to
Kithairon, to spy upon the women, and climbing up a tree beheld what was
done. When the women detected Pentheus, they immediately dragged him
down, and joined in tearing him, living as he was, limb from limb.
Afterwards, as the Corinthians say, the Pythian priestess commanded them
by an oracle to discover that tree and to worship it equally with the
god. For this reason they have made these images from the tree.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.2.8">

There is also a temple of Fortune, with a standing statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Parian
marble. Beside it is a sanctuary for all the gods. Hard by is built a
fountain, on which is a bronze Poseidon; under the feet of Poseidon is a
dolphin spouting water. There is also a bronze Apollo surnamed Clarius
and a statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]
of Aphrodite made by Hermogenes of Cythera. There are two bronze,
standing statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Hermes,
for one of which a temple has been made. The images of Zeus also are in
the open; one had not a surname, another they call Khthonios (of the
Lower World) and the third Most High.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.1">

In the middle of the marketplace is a bronze Athena, on the pedestal of
which are made-in-relief-figures
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of the
Muses. Above the marketplace is a temple of Octavia the sister of
Augustus, who was emperor of the Romans after Caesar, the founder of the
modern Corinth.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.2">

On leaving the marketplace along the road to Lekhaion you come to a
gateway, on which are two gilded chariots, one carrying Phaethon the son
of Hēlios \[Sun\], the other Hēlios himself. A little farther away from
the gateway, on the right as you go in, is a bronze Hēraklēs. After this
is the entrance to the water of Peirene. They say about Peirene that she
was a woman who became a spring because of her tears shed in lamentation
for her son Kenkhrias, who was unintentionally killed by Artemis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.3">

The spring is ornamented with white marble, and there have been made
chambers like caves, out of which the water flows into an open-air well.
It Is pleasant to drink, and they say that the Corinthian bronze, when
red-hot, is tempered by this water, since bronze … the Corinthians have
not. Moreover near Peirene are a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] and a sacred
enclosure of Apollo; in the latter is a painting of the exploit of
Odysseus against the suitors.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.4">

Proceeding on the direct road to Lekhaion we see a bronze statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of a seated
Hermes. By him stands a ram, for Hermes is the god who is thought most
to care for and to increase flocks, as Homer puts it in the
<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Iliad</span>:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Son was he of Phorbas, the dearest of Trojans to Hermes,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Rich in flocks, for the god vouchsafed him wealth in abundance.

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_source_attrib">

<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Iliad</span> 14.490

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

The story told at the mysteries of the Mother about Hermes and the ram I
know but do not relate. After the image of Hermes come Poseidon,
Leukothea, and Palaimon on a dolphin.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.5">

The Corinthians have baths in many parts of the city, some put up at the
public charge and one by ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] Hadrian. The
most famous of them is near the Poseidon. It was made by the Spartan
Eurykles, who beautified it with various kinds of stone, especially the
one quarried at Krokeai in Laconia. On the left of the entrance stands a
Poseidon, and after him Artemis hunting. Throughout the city are many
springs \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnai</span>\], for
the Corinthians have a copious supply of flowing water, besides the
water that ‘King’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] Hadrian
brought from Lake Stymphalos, but the most noteworthy is the one by the
side of the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Artemis.
Over it is a Bellerophontes, and the water flows through the hoof of the
horse Pegasus \[Pegasos\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.6">

As you go along another road from the marketplace
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agorā</span>\], which leads to
Sikyon, you can see on the right of the road a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Apollo, which
has a bronze statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of him. A
little farther along the way is a well called the Spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\] of Glauke. Into
this well they say she \[= Glauke\] threw herself, thinking that the
water would be a cure for \[the pain that she was suffering from\] the
magical drugs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pharmaka</span>\] of Medea.
Above this spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\] has been built
what is called the Odeum
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ōideion</span>\], beside which
is the tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of
Medea’s children. Their names were Mermeros and Pheres, and they are
said to have been stoned to death by the Corinthians because—as is also
said—they had brought to Glauke the gifts
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dōra</span>\] \[from Medea\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.7">

And, since their death was violent and unjust, the infant offspring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nēpia tekna</span>\] of the
Corinthians kept on being destroyed by them \[= the ghosts of the
children of Medea\] until, in accordance with what the god \[= Apollo\]
said-as-an-oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsai</span>\], yearly
sacrifices \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiai</span>\]
were established in their honor and a figure of Terror
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Deima</span>\] was
set-up-in-compensation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-stēnai</span>\]. This
figure still exists, even in my time: it is the image
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of a woman
rather frightful to look at. After Corinth was destroyed by the Romans
and the old Corinthians were wiped out, the new settlers no longer
observed the custom of offering those sacrifices
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiai</span>\] to the sons
of Medea, nor do their children \[who are initiated into the hero cult
of the children of Medea\] cut their hair for them or wear black
clothes.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.8">

On the occasion referred to Medea went to Athens and lived with Aigeus,
but subsequently she was detected plotting against Theseus and fled from
Athens also; coming to the land then called Aria she caused its
inhabitants to be named after her Medes. The son, whom she brought with
her in her flight to the Arii, they say she had by Aigeus, and that his
name was Mēdos. Hellanicus, however, calls him Polyxenos and says that
his father was Jason.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.9">

The Greeks have an epic poem called Naupactia. In this Jason is
represented as having removed his home after the death of Pelias from
Iolkos to Corcyra, and Mermerus, the elder of his children, to have been
killed by a lioness while hunting on the mainland opposite. Of Pheres is
recorded nothing. But Kinaithon of Lacedaemon, another writer of
pedigrees in verse, said that Jason’s children by Medea were a son
Medeus and a daughter Eriopis; he too, however, gives no further
information about these children.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.10">

Eumēlos said that Hēlios \[Sun\] gave the Asopian land to Aloeus and
Ephyraia to Aietes. When Aietes was departing for Kolkhis he entrusted
his land to Bounos, the son of Hermes and Alkidameiā, and when Bounos
died Epopeus the son of Aloeus extended his kingdom to include the
Ephyraeans. Afterwards, when Korinthos, the son of Marathon, died
childless, the Corinthians sent for Medea from Iolkos and bestowed upon
her the kingdom.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.3.11">

Through her Jason was king in Corinth, and Medea, as her children were
born, carried each to the sanctuary of Hērā and concealed them, doing so
in the belief that so they would be immortal. At last she learned that
her hopes were vain, and at the same time she was detected by Jason.
When she begged for pardon he refused it, and sailed away to Iolkos. For
these reasons Medea too departed, and handed over the kingdom to
Sisyphus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.1">

This is the account that I read, and not far from the tomb is the temple
of Athena Khalinitis (Bridler). For Athena, they say, was the divinity
who gave most help to Bellerophontes, and she delivered to him Pegasus
\[Pegasos\], having herself broken in and bridled him. The statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of hers is of
wood \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\], but
face, hands and feet are of white marble.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.2">

That Bellerophontes was not an absolute king, but was subject to Proitos
and the Argives is the belief of myself and of all who have read
carefully the Homeric poems.[^153] When Bellerophontes migrated to Lycia
it is clear that the Corinthians none the less were subject to the
despots at Argos or Mycenae. By themselves they provided no leader for
the campaign against Troy, but shared in the expedition as part of the
forces, Mycenaean and other, led by Agamemnon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.3">

Sisyphus had other sons besides Glaukos, the father of Bellerophontes a
second was Ornytion, and besides him there were Thersandros and Almus.
Ornytion had a son Phokos, reputed to have been begotten by Poseidon. He
migrated to Tithorea in what is now called Phokis, but Thoas, the
younger son of Ornytion, remained behind in Corinth. Thoas begat
Damophon, Damophon begat Propodas, and Propodas begat Doridas and
Hyanthidas. While these were kings the Dorians took the field against
Corinth, their leader being Aletes, the son of Hippotas, the son of
Phylas, the son of Antiokhos, the son of Hēraklēs. So Doridas and
Hyanthidas gave up the kingship to Aletes and remained in Corinth, but
the Corinthian people were conquered in battle and expelled by the
Dorians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.4">

Aletes himself and his descendants reigned for five generations to
Bacchis, the son of Prumnis, and, named after him, the Bakkhidai reigned
for five more generations to Telestes, the son of Aristodemos. Telestes
was killed in hate by Arieus and Perantas, and there were no more kings,
but Prytaneis (‘Presidents’) taken from the Bakkhidai and ruling for one
year, until Kypselos, the son of Eetion, became tyrant and expelled the
Bakkhidai.[^154] Kypselos was a descendant of Melas, the son of Antasus.
Melas from Gonoussa above Sikyon joined the Dorians in the expedition
against Corinth. When the god expressed disapproval Aletes at first
ordered Melas to withdraw to other Greeks, but afterwards, mistaking the
oracle, he received him as a settler. Such I found to be the history of
the Corinthian kings.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.5">

Now the sanctuary of Athena Khalinitis is by their theater, and near is
a naked wooden image of Hēraklēs, said to be a work of Daidalos. All the
works of this artist, although rather uncouth to look at, are
nevertheless distinguished by a kind of inspiration. Above the theater
is a sanctuary of Zeus surnamed in the Latin tongue Capitolinus, which
might be rendered into Greek, ‘Koruphaios’. Not far from this theater is
the ancient gymnasium, and a spring called Lerna. Pillars stand around
it, and seats have been made to refresh in summer time those who have
entered it. By this gymnasium are temples of Zeus and Asklepios. The
statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of
Asklepios and of Hygieia are of white marble, that of Zeus is of bronze.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.6">

The Acrocorinth is a mountain peak above the city, assigned to Hēlios by
Briareos when he acted as adjudicator, and handed over, the Corinthians
say, by Hēlios to Aphrodite. As you go up this Acrocorinth you see two
precincts of Isis, one if Isis surnamed Pelagian (Marine) and the other
of Egyptian Isis, and two of Serapis, one of them being of Serapis
called ‘Canopus’. After these are altars to Hēlios, and a sanctuary of
Necessity and Force, into which it is not customary to enter.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.4.7">

Above it are a temple of the Mother of the gods and a throne; the image
and the throne are made of stone. The temple of the Fates and that of
Demeter and the Maiden have statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] that are not
exposed to view. Here, too, is the temple of Hērā Bounaia set up by
Bounos the son of Hermes. It is for this reason that the goddess is
called Bounaia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.1">

As you go up to the summit of the Acrocorinth, there is a shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Aphrodite.
The statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\]
there are Aphrodite herself, armed, also Hēlios, also Eros with a bow.
The spring \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\],
which is behind the shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\], they say was
the gift of Asopos to Sisyphus, who knew, so they also say, that Zeus
had abducted Aegina, the daughter of Asopos, but refused to give
information to the seeker before he had some spring-water given him on
the Acrocorinth. When Asopos granted this request, Sisyphus turned
informer, and because of that he receives—if anyone believes
it—punishment in Hādēs. I have heard people say that this spring-water
and Peirene are the same, and that the water in the city flows there
underground all the way from here.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.2">

This Asopos rises in the Phliasian territory, flows through the
Sikyonian, and empties itself into the sea here. His daughters, say the
Phliasians, were Corcyra, Aegina, and Thebe. Corcyra and Aegina gave new
names to the islands called Scheria and Oinone, while from Thebe is
named the city below the Kadmeia. The Thebans do not agree, but say that
Thebe was the daughter of the Boeotian, and not of the Phliasian,
Asopos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.3">

The other stories about the river are current among both the Phliasians
and the Sikyonians, for instance that its water is foreign and not
native, in that the Maeander, descending from Kelainai through Phrygia
and Caria, and emptying itself into the sea at Miletus, goes to the
Peloponnesus and forms the Asopos. I remember hearing a similar story
from the Delians, that the stream which they call Inopus comes to them
from the Nile. Further, there is a story that the Nile itself is the
Euphrates, which disappears into a marsh, rises again beyond Aethiopia
and becomes the Nile.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.4">

Such is the account I heard of the Asopos. When you have turned from the
Acrocorinth into the mountain road you see the Teneatic gate and a
sanctuary of Eileithuia. The town called Tenea is just about sixty
stadium-lengths distant. The inhabitants say that they are Trojans who
were taken prisoners in Tenedos by the Greeks, and were permitted by
Agamemnon to dwell in their present home. For this reason they honor
Apollo more than any other god.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.5">

As you go from Corinth, not into the interior but along the road to
Sikyon, there is on the left not far from the city a burned temple.
There have, of course, been many wars carried on in Corinthian
territory, and naturally houses and sanctuaries outside the wall have
been fired. But this temple, they say, was Apollo’s, and Pyrrhos the son
of Achilles burned it down. Subsequently I heard another account, that
the Corinthians built the temple for Olympian Zeus, and that suddenly
fire from some quarter fell on it and destroyed it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.6">

The Sikyonians, the neighbors of the Corinthians at this part of the
border, say about their own land that Aigialeus was its first and
aboriginal inhabitant, that the district of the Peloponnesus still
called Aigialos was named after him because he reigned over it, and that
he founded the city Aigialeia on the plain. Their citadel, they say, was
where is now their sanctuary of Athena; further, that Aigialeus begat
Europs, Europs Telchis, and Telchis Apis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.7">

This Apis reached such a height of power before Pelops came to Olympia
that all the territory south of the Isthmus was called after him Apia.
Apis begat Thelxion, Thelxion Aigyros, the Thourimakhos, and
Thourimakhos Leukippos. Leukippos had no male issue, only a daughter
Calchinia. There is a story that this Calchinia mated with Poseidon; her
child was reared by Leukippos, who at his death handed over to him the
kingdom. His name was Peratos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.5.8">

What is reported of Plemnaios, the son of Peratos, seemed to me very
wonderful. All the children borne to him by his wife died the very first
time they wailed. At last Demeter took pity on Plemnaios, came to
Aigialeia in the guise of a strange woman, and reared for Plemnaios his
son Orthopolis. Orthopolis had a daughter Khrysorthe, who is thought to
have borne a son named Koronos to Apollo. Koronos had two sons, Korax
and a younger one Lamedon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.1">

Korax died without issue, and at about this time came Epopeus from
Thessaly and took the kingdom. In his reign the first hostile army is
said to have invaded the land, which before this had enjoyed unbroken
peace. The reason was this. Antiope, the daughter of Nykteus, had a name
among the Greeks for beauty, and there was also a report that her father
was not Nykteus but Asopos, the river that separates the territories of
Thebes and Plataea.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.2">

This woman Epopeus carried off but I do not know whether he asked for
her hand or adopted a bolder policy from the beginning. The Thebans came
against him in arms, and in the battle Nykteus was wounded. Epopeus also
was wounded, but won the day. Nykteus they carried back ill to Thebes,
and when he was about to die he appointed to be regent of Thebes his
brother Lykos for Labdacus, the son of Polydoros, the son of Kadmos,
being still a child, was the ward of Nykteus, who on this occasion
entrusted the office of guardian to Lykos. He also besought him to
attack Aigialeia with a larger army and bring vengeance upon Epopeus;
Antiope herself, if taken, was to be punished.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.3">

As to Epopeus, he forthwith offered sacrifice for his victory and began
a temple of Athena, and when this was complete he prayed the goddess to
make known whether the temple was finished to her liking, and after the
prayer they say that olive oil flowed before the temple. Afterwards
Epopeus also died of his wound, which he had neglected at first, so that
Lykos had now no need to wage war. For Lamedon, the son of Koronos, who
became king after Epopeus, gave up Antiope. As she was being taken to
Thebes by way of Eleutherai, she was delivered there on the road.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.4">

On this matter Asios the son of Amphiptolemos[^155] says in his poem:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Zethus and Amphion had Antiope for their mother,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Daughter of Asopos, the swift, deep-eddying river,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Having conceived of Zeus and Epopeus, shepherd of peoples.[^156]

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

Homer traces their descent to the more august side of their family, and
says that they were the first founders of Thebes, in my opinion
distinguishing the lower city from the Kadmeia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.5">

When Lamedon became king he took to wife an Athenian woman, Pheno, the
daughter of Klytios. Afterwards also, when war had arisen between him
and Arkhandros and Arkhiteles, the sons of Achaeus, he brought in as his
ally Sikyon from Attica, and gave him Zeuxippe his daughter to wife.
This man became king, and the land was named after him Sikyonia, and the
city Sikyon instead of Aigiale. But they say that Sikyon was not the son
of Marathon, the son of Epopeus, but of Metion the son of Erekhtheus.
Asios confirms their statement, while Hesiod makes Sikyon the son of
Erekhtheus, and Ibycus says that his father was Pelops.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.6">

Sikyon had a daughter Khthonophyle, and they say that she and Hermes
were the parents of Polybus. Afterwards she married Phlias, the son of
Dionysus, and gave birth to Androdamas. Polybus gave his daughter
Lysianassa to Talaos the son of Bias, king of the Argives; and when
Adrastos fled from Argos he came to Polybus at Sikyon, and afterwards on
the death of Polybus he became king at Sikyon. When Adrastos returned to
Argos, Ianiskos, a descendant of Klytios the father-in-law of Lamedon,
came from Attica and was made king, and when Ianiskos died he was
succeeded by Phaistos, said to have been one of the children of
Hēraklēs.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.6.7">

After Phaistos in obedience to an oracle migrated to Crete, the next
king is said to have been Zeuxippos, the son of Apollo and the nymph
Syllis. On the death of Zeuxippos, Agamemnon led an army against Sikyon
and king Hippolytus, the son of Rhopalus, the son of Phaistos. In terror
of the army that was attacking him, Hippolytus agreed to become subject
to Agamemnon and the Mycenaeans. This Hippolytus was the father of
Lacestades. Phalkes the son of Temenus, with the Dorians, surprised
Sikyon by night, but did Lacestades no harm, because he too was one of
the Herakleidai, and made him partner in the kingdom.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.1">

From that time the Sikyonians became Dorians and their land a part of
the Argive territory. The city built by Aigialeus on the plain was
destroyed by Demetrios the son of Antigonos,[^157] who founded the
modern city near what was once the ancient citadel. The reason why the
Sikyonians grew weak it would be wrong to seek; we must be content with
Homer’s saying about Zeus:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Many, indeed, are the cities of which he has leveled the strongholds.

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_source_attrib">

<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Iliad</span> 2.117 and 9.24

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

When they had lost their power there came upon them an earthquake, which
almost depopulated their city and took from them many of their famous
sights. It damaged also the cities of Caria and Lycia, and the island of
Rhodes was very violently shaken, so that it was thought that the Sibyl
had had her utterance about Rhodes[^158] fulfilled.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.2">

When you have come from the Corinthian to the Sikyonian territory you
see the tomb of Lykos the Messenian, whoever this Lykos may be; for I
can discover no Messenian Lykos who practiced the pentathlon or won a
victory at Olympia. This tomb is a mound of earth, but the Sikyonians
themselves usually bury their dead in a uniform manner. They cover the
body in the ground, and over it they build a basement of stone upon
which they set pillars. Above these they put something very like the
pediment of a temple. They add no inscription, except that they give the
dead man’s name without that of his father and bid him farewell.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.3">

After the tomb of Lykos, but on the other side of the Asopos, there is
on the right the Olympium, and a little farther on, to the left of the
road, the tomb of Eupolis, the Athenian comic poet. Farther on, if you
turn in the direction of the city, you see the tomb of Xenodice, who
died in childbirth. It has not been made after the native fashion, but
so as to harmonize best with the painting, which is very well worth
seeing.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.4">

Farther on from here is the tomb of the Sikyonians who were killed at
Pellene, at Dyme of the Achaeans, in Megalopolis and at Sellasia.[^159]
Their story I will relate more fully presently. By the gate they have a
spring in a cave, the water of which does not rise out of the earth, but
flows down from the roof of the cave. For this reason it is called the
Dripping Spring.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.5">

On the modern citadel is a sanctuary of Fortune of the Height, and after
it one of the Dioskouroi. Their statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] and that of
Fortune are of wood
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>\]. On the stage
of the theater built under the citadel is a statue of a man with a
shield, who they say is Aratos, the son of Kleinias. After the theater
is a temple of Dionysus. The god is of gold and ivory, and by his side
are Bacchic women
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Bakkhai</span>\] of white
marble. These women they say are sacred
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierai</span>\] to Dionysus
and are-maddened
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mainesthai</span>\] by his
inspiration. The Sikyonians have also some statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] that are
kept secret. These one night in each year they carry to the temple of
Dionysus from what they call the Kosmeterion, and they do so with
lighted torches and hymns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">humnoi</span>\] that are local
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrioi</span>\]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.6">

The first is the one named Baccheus, set up by Androdamas, the son of
Phlias, and this is followed by the one called Lysios (Deliverer),
brought from Thebes by the Theban Phanes at the command of the Pythian
priestess. Phanes came to Sikyon when Aristomakhos, the son of
Kleodaios, failed to understand the oracle[^160] given him, and
therefore failed to return to the Peloponnesus. As you walk from the
temple of Dionysus to the marketplace you see on the right a temple of
Artemis of the lake. A look shows that the roof has fallen in, but the
inhabitants cannot tell whether the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] had been saved
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] and taken
elsewhere or whether it was destroyed on the spot.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.7">

Within the marketplace is a sanctuary of Persuasion; this too has no
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]. The
worship of Persuasion was established among them for the following
reason. When Apollo and Artemis had killed Pythō they came to Aigialeia
to obtain purification. Dread coming upon them at the place now named
Fear, they turned aside to Carmanor in Crete, and the people of
Aigialeia were smitten by a plague. When the seers ordered them to
propitiate Apollo and Artemis,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.8">

they sent seven boys and seven girls as suppliants to the river Sythas.
They say that the deities, persuaded by these, came to what was then the
citadel, and the place that they reached first is the sanctuary of
Persuasion. Conformable with this story is the ceremony they perform at
the present day; the children go to the Sythas at the feast of Apollo,
and having brought, as they pretend, the deities to the sanctuary of
Persuasion, they say that they take them back again to the temple of
Apollo. The temple stands in the modern marketplace, and was originally,
it is said, made by Proitos, because in this place his daughters
recovered from their madness.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.7.9">

It is also said that in this temple Meleagros dedicated the spear with
which he slew the boar. There is also a story that the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aulos</span> \[‘double-reed’\]
of Marsyas is dedicated here. When the Silenos met with his disaster,
the river Marsyas carried the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aulos</span> \[‘double-reed’\]
to the Maeander; reappearing in the Asopos it was cast ashore in the
Sikyonian territory and given to Apollo by the shepherd who found them.
I found none of these offerings still in existence, for they were
destroyed by fire when the temple was burned. The temple that I saw, and
its statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\],
were dedicated by Pythokles.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.8.1">

The precinct near the sanctuary of Persuasion that is devoted to Roman
emperors was once the house of the tyrant Kleon. He became tyrant in the
modern city there was another tyranny while the Sikyonians still lived
in the lower city,[^161] that of Cleisthenes, the son of Aristonymos,
the son of Myron. Before this house is a hero-shrine of Aratos,[^162]
whose achievements eclipsed those of all contemporary Greeks. His
history is as follows.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.8.2">

After the despotism of Kleon, many of those in authority were seized
with such an ungovernable passion for tyranny that two actually became
tyrants together, Euthydemos and Timokleidas. These were expelled by the
people, who made Kleinias, the father of Aratos, their champion. A few
years afterwards Abantidas became tyrant. Before this time Kleinias had
met his death, and Aratos went into exile, either of his own accord or
because he was compelled to do so by Abantidas. Now Abantidas was killed
by some natives, and his father Paseas immediately became tyrant.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.8.3">

He was killed by Nikokles, who succeeded him.[^163] This Nikokles was
attacked by Aratos with a force of Sikyonian exiles and Argive
mercenaries. Making his attempt by night, he eluded some of the
defenders in the darkness; the others he overcame, and forced his way
within the wall. Day was now breaking, and taking the populace with him
he hastened to the tyrant’s house. This he easily captured, but Nikokles
himself succeeded in making his escape. Aratos restored equality of
political rights to the Sikyonians, striking a bargain for those in
exile; he restored to them their houses and all their other possessions
which had been sold, compensating the buyers out of his own purse.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.8.4">

Moreover, as all the Greeks were afraid of the Macedonians and of
Antigonos, the guardian of Philip, the son of Demetrios, he induced the
Sikyonians, who were Dorians, to join the Achaean League. He was
immediately elected general by the Achaeans, and leading them against
the the people of Lokris in Amphissa and into the land of the Aetolians,
their enemies, he ravaged their territory. Corinth was held by
Antigonos, and there was a Macedonian garrison in the city, but he threw
them into a panic by the suddenness of his assault, winning a battle and
killing among others Persaios, the commander of the garrison, who had
studied philosophy under Zeno, the son of Mnaseas.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.8.5">

When Aratos had liberated Corinth, the League was joined by the
Epidaurians and Troizenians inhabiting Argolian Acte, and by the
Megarians among those beyond the Isthmus, while Ptolemy made an alliance
with the Achaeans. The Lacedaemonians and king Agis, the son of
Eudamidas, surprised and took Pellene by a sudden onslaught, but when
Aratos and his army arrived they were defeated in an engagement,
evacuated Pellene, and returned home under a truce.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.8.6">

After his success in the Peloponnesus, Aratos thought it a shame to
allow the Macedonians to hold unchallenged Peiraieus, Mounukhia,
Salamis, and Sounion; but not expecting to be able to take them by force
he bribed Diogenes, the commander of the garrisons, to give up the
positions for a hundred and fifty talents, himself helping the Athenians
by contributing a sixth part of the sum. He induced Aristomakhos also,
the tyrant of Argos, to restore to the Argives their democracy and to
join the Achaean League; he captured Mantineia from the Lacedaemonians
who held it. But no man finds all his plans turn out according to his
liking, and even Aratos was compelled to become an ally of the
Macedonians and Antigonos in the following way.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.1">

Kleomenes, the son of Leonidas, the son of Kleonymos, having succeeded
to the kingship at Sparta, resembled Pausanias[^164] in being
dissatisfied with the established constitution and in aiming at a
tyranny. A more fiery man than Pausanias, and no coward, he quickly
succeeded by spirit and daring in accomplishing all his ambition. He
poisoned Eurydamidas, the king of the other royal house, while yet a
boy, raised to the throne by means of the ephors his brother Epikleidas,
destroyed the power of the senate, and appointed in its stead a nominal
Council of Fathers. Ambitious for greater things and for supremacy over
the Greeks, he first attacked the Achaeans, hoping if successful to have
them as allies, and especially wishing that they should not hinder his
activities.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.2">

Engaging them at Dyme beyond Patrai, Aratos being still leader of the
Achaeans, he won the victory.[^165] In fear for the Achaeans and for
Sikyon itself, Aratos was forced by this defeat to bring in Antigonos as
an ally. Kleomenes had violated the peace which he had made with
Antigonos and had openly acted in many ways contrary to treaty,
especially in laying waste Megalopolis. So Antigonos crossed into the
Peloponnesus and the Achaeans met Kleomenes at Sellasia.[^166] The
Achaeans were victorious, the people of Sellasia were sold into slavery,
and Lacedaemon itself was captured. Antigonos and the Achaeans restored
to the Lacedaemonians the constitution of their fathers;

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.3">

but of the children of Leonidas, Epikleidas was killed in the battle,
and Kleomenes fled to Egypt. Held in the highest honor by Ptolemy, he
came to be cast into prison, being convicted of inciting Egyptians to
rebel against their king. He made his escape from prison and began a
riot among the Alexandrians, but at last, on being captured, he fell by
his own hand. The Lacedaemonians, glad to be rid of Kleomenes, refused
to be ruled by kings any longer, but the rest of their ancient
constitution they have kept to the present day. Antigonos remained a
constant friend of Aratos, looking upon him as a benefactor who had
helped him to accomplish brilliant deeds.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.4">

But when Philip succeeded to the throne, since Aratos did not approve of
his violent treatment of his subjects, and in some cases even opposed
the accomplishment of his purposes, he killed Aratos by giving him
secretly a dose of poison. This fate came upon Aratos at Aigion, from
which place he was carried to Sikyon and buried, and there is still in
that city the hero-shrine of Aratos. Philip treated two Athenians,
Eurykleides and Mikon, in a similar way. These men also, who were
orators enjoying the confidence of the people, he killed by poison.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.5">

After all, Philip himself in his turn was fated to suffer disaster
through the fatal cup. Philip’s son, Demetrios, was poisoned by Perseus,
his younger son, and grief at the murder brought the father also to his
tomb. I mention the incident in passing, with my mind turned to the
inspired words of the poet Hesiod, that he who plots mischief against
his neighbor directs it first to himself.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.6">

After the hero-shrine of Aratos is an altar to Isthmian Poseidon, and
also a Zeus Meilichios (Gracious) and an Artemis named Patroa
(Paternal), both of them very inartistic works. The Meilichios is like a
pyramid, the Artemis like a pillar. Here too stand their council-chamber
and a portico called Cleisthenean from the name of him who built it. It
was built from spoils by Cleisthenes, who helped the Amphiktyones in the
war at Cirrha.[^167] In the marketplace under the open sky is a bronze
Zeus, a work of Lysippos, and by the side of it a gilded Artemis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.7">

Hard by is a sanctuary of Apollo Lykios (wolf-god), now fallen into
ruins and not worth any attention. For wolves once so preyed upon their
flocks that there was no longer any profit therefrom, and the god,
mentioning a certain place where lay a dry log, gave an oracle that the
bark of this log mixed with meat was to be set out for the beasts to
eat. As soon as they tasted it the bark killed them, and that log lay in
my time in the sanctuary of the Wolf-god, but not even the guides of the
Sikyonians knew what kind of tree it was.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.9.8">

Next after this are bronze portrait statues, said to be the daughters of
Proitos, but the inscription I found referred to other women. Here there
is a bronze Hēraklēs, made by Lysippos the Sikyonian, and hard by stands
Hermes of the Marketplace.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.1">

In the gymnasium not far from the marketplace is dedicated a stone
Hēraklēs made by Scopas. There is also in another place a sanctuary of
Hēraklēs. The whole of the enclosure here they name Paidizē; in the
middle of the enclosure is the sanctuary, and in it is an old wooden
figure carved by Laphaēs the Phliasian. I will now describe the ritual
at the festival. The story is that on coming to the Sikyonian land
Phaistos found the people giving offerings to Hēraklēs as to a hero.
Phaistos then refused to do anything of the kind, but insisted on
sacrificing to him as to a god. Even at the present day the Sikyonians,
after slaying a lamb and burning the thighs upon the altar, eat some of
the meat as part of a victim given to a god, while the rest they offer
as to a hero. The first day of the festival in honor of Hēraklēs they
name …; the second they call Herakleia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.2">

From here is a way to a sanctuary of Asklepios. On passing into the
enclosure you see on the left a building with two rooms. In the outer
room lies a figure of Sleep, of which nothing remains now except the
head. The inner room is given over to the Carnean Apollo; into it none
may enter except the priests. In the portico lies a huge bone of a
sea-monster, and after it a statue
