\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the
Dream-god and \[a statue of\] Sleep, surnamed Epidotes (Bountiful),
lulling to sleep a lion. Within the sanctuary on either side of the
entrance is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Pan seated,
and, on the other side, \[a statue of\] Artemis standing.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.3">

When you have entered you see the god, a beardless figure of gold and
ivory made by Kalamis. He holds a staff in one hand, and a cone of the
cultivated pine in the other. The Sikyonians say that the god was
carried to them from Epidaurus on a carriage drawn by two mules, that he
was in the likeness of a serpent, and that he was brought by Nicagora of
Sikyon, the mother of Agasikles and the wife of Ekhetīmos. Here are
small figures
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] hanging from
the roof. She who is on the serpent they say is Aristodama, the mother
of Aratos, whom they hold to be a son of Asklepios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.4">

Such are the noteworthy things that this enclosure presented to me, and
opposite is another enclosure, sacred to Aphrodite. The first thing
inside is a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Antiope.
They say that her sons were Sikyonians, and because of them the
Sikyonians will have it that Antiope herself is related to themselves.
After this is the sanctuary of Aphrodite, into which enter only a female
verger, who after her appointment may not have intercourse with a man,
and a virgin, called the Bath-bearer, holding her sacred office for a
year. All others are accustomed to behold the goddess from the entrance,
and to pray from that place.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.5">

The statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\],
which is seated, was made by the Sikyonian Kanakhos, who also fashioned
the Apollo at Didyma of the Milesians, and the Ismenian Apollo for the
Thebans. It is made of gold and ivory, having on its head a polos,[^168]
and carrying in one hand a poppy and in the other an apple. They offer
the thighs of the victims, excepting pigs; the other parts they burn for
the goddess with juniper wood, but as the thighs are burning they add to
the offering a leaf of the paideros.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.6">

This is a plant in the open parts of the enclosure, and it grows nowhere
else either in Sikyonia or in any other land. Its leaves are smaller
than those of the esculent oak, but larger than those of the holm; the
shape is similar to that of the oak-leaf. One side is of a dark color,
the other is white. You might best compare the color to that of
white-poplar leaves.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.10.7">

Ascending from here to the gymnasium you see in the right a sanctuary of
Artemis Pheraia. It is said that the wooden image was brought from
Pherai. This gymnasium was built for the Sikyonians by Kleinias, and
they still train the youths here. White marble images are here, an
Artemis crafted only to the waist, and a Hēraklēs whose lower parts are
similar to the square Hermai.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.1">

Turning away from here towards the gate called Holy you see, not far
from the gate, a temple of Athena. Dedicated long ago by Epopeus, it
surpassed all its contemporaries in size and splendor. Yet the memory of
even this was doomed to perish through lapse of time—it was burned down
by lightning—but the altar there, which escaped injury, remains down to
the present day as Epopeus made it. Before the altar a barrow has been
raised for Epopeus himself, and near the tomb are the gods Averters of
evil. Near them the Greeks perform such rites as they are accustomed to
do in order to avert misfortunes. They say that the neighboring
sanctuary of Artemis and Apollo was also made by Epopeus, and that of
Hērā after it by Adrastos. I found no statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] remaining in
either. Behind the sanctuary of Hērā he built an altar to Pan, and one
to Hēlios \[Sun\] made of white marble.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.2">

On the way down to the plain is a sanctuary of Demeter, said to have
been founded by Plemnaios as a thank-offering to the goddess for the
rearing of his son. A little farther away from the sanctuary of Hērā
founded by Adrastos is a temple of Apollo Karneios. Only the pillars are
standing in it; you will no longer find there walls or roof, nor yet in
that of Hērā Pioneer. This temple was founded by Phalkes, son of
Temenus, who asserted that Hērā guided him on the road to Sikyon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.3">

On the direct road from Sikyon to Phleious, on the left of the road and
just about ten stadium-lengths from it, is a grove called Puraiā, and in
it a sanctuary of Hērā Protectress and the Maiden. Here the men
celebrate a festival by themselves, giving up to the women the temple
called Nymphon for the purposes of their festival. In the Nymphon are
statues \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of
Dionysus, Demeter, and the Maiden, with only their faces exposed. The
road to Titane is sixty stadium-lengths long, and too narrow to be used
by carriages drawn by a yoke.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.4">

At a distance along it, in my opinion, of twenty stadium-lengths, to the
left on the other side of the Asopos, is a grove of holm oaks and a
temple of the goddesses named by the Athenians the August, and by the
Sikyonians the Kindly Ones. On one day in each year they celebrate a
festival to them and offer sheep big with young as a burned offering,
and they are accustomed to use a libation of honey and water, and
flowers instead of garlands. They practice similar rites at the altar of
the Fates; it is in an open space in the grove.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.5">

On turning back to the road, and having crossed the Asopos again and
reached the summit of the hill, you come to the place where the natives
say that Titan first dwelled. They add that he was the brother of Hēlios
\[Sun\], and that after him the place got the name Titane. My own view
is that he proved clever at observing the seasons of the year and the
times when the sun increases and ripens seeds and fruits, and for this
reason was held to be the brother of Hēlios. Afterwards Alexanor, the
son of Machaon, the son of Asklepios, came to Sikyonia and built the
sanctuary of Asklepios at Titane.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.6">

The neighbors are chiefly servants of the god, and within the enclosure
are old cypress trees. One cannot learn of what wood or metal the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is, nor do
they know the name of the maker, though one or two attribute it to
Alexanor himself. Of the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] can be seen
only the face, hands, and feet, for it has about it a tunic of white
wool and a cloak. There is a similar statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Hygieia;
this, too, one cannot see easily because it is so surrounded with the
locks of women, who cut them off and offer them to the goddess, and with
strips of Babylonian raiment. With whichever of these a votary here is
willing to make propitiations, the same instructions have been given to
him, to worship this image which they are pleased to call Hygieia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.7">

There are statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] also of
Alexanor and of Euamerion; to the former they give offerings as to a
hero after the setting of the sun; to Euamerion, as being a god, they
give burned sacrifices. If I conjecture aright, the Pergamenes, in
accordance with an oracle, call this Euamerion Telesphoros
(Accomplisher) while the Epidaurians call him Akesis (Cure). There is
also a wooden image of Korōnis, but it has no fixed position anywhere in
the temple. While to the god are being sacrificed a bull, a lamb, and a
pig, they remove Korōnisto the sanctuary of Athena and honor her there.
The parts of the victims which they offer as a burned sacrifice, and
they are not content with cutting out the thighs, they burn on the
ground, except the birds, which they burn on the altar.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.11.8">

In the gable at the ends are figures of Hēraklēs and of Victories. In
the portico are dedicated statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Dionysus
and Hekate, with Aphrodite, the Mother of the gods, and Fortune. These
are wooden, but Asklepios, surnamed Gortynian, is of stone. They are
unwilling to enter among the sacred serpents through fear, but they
place their food before the entrance and take no further trouble. Within
the enclosure is a bronze statue of a Sikyonian named Granianus, who won
the following victories at Olympia: the pentathlon twice, the foot-race,
the double-course foot-race twice, once without and once with the
shield.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.12.1">

In Titane there is also a sanctuary of Athena, into which they bring up
the image of Korōnis. In it is an old wooden figure of Athena, and I was
told that it, too, was struck by lightning. The sanctuary is built upon
a hill, at the bottom of which is an Altar of the Winds, and on it the
priest sacrifices to the winds one night in every year. He also performs
other secret rites at four pits, taming the fierceness of the blasts,
and he is said to chant as well charms of Medea.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.12.2">

On reaching Sikyon from Titane, as you go down to the shore you see on
the left of the road a temple of Hērā having now neither statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] nor roof. They
say that its founder was Proitos, the son of Abas. When you have gone
down to the harbor called the Sikyonians’ and turned towards
Aristonautai, the Port of Pellene, you see a little above the road on
the left hand a sanctuary of Poseidon. Farther along the highway is a
river called the Helisson, and after it the Sythas, both emptying
themselves into the sea.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.12.3">

Phliasia borders on Sikyonia. The city is just about forty
stadium-lengths distant from Titane, and there is a straight road to it
from Sikyon. That the Phliasians are in no way related to the Arcadians
is shown by the passage in Homer that deals with the list of the
Arcadians, in which the Sikyonians are not included among the Arcadian
confederates. As my narrative progresses it will become clear that they
were Argive originally, and became Dorian later after the return of the
Herakleidai to the Peloponnesus. I know that most of the traditions
concerning the Phliasians are contradictory, but I shall make use of
those which have been most generally accepted.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.12.4">

They say that the first man in this land was Aras, who sprang from the
soil. He founded a city around that hillock which even down to our day
is called the Arantine Hill, not far distant from a second hill on which
the Phliasians have their citadel and their sanctuary of Hebe. Here,
then, he founded a city, and after him in ancient times both the land
and the city were called Arantia. While he was king, Asopos, said to be
the son of Celusa and Poseidon, discovered for him the water of the
river which the present inhabitants call after him Asopos. The tomb of
Aras is in the place called Celeae, where they say is also buried
Dysaules of Eleusis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.12.5">

Aras had a son Aoris and a daughter Araethyrea, who, the Phliasians say,
were experienced hunters and brave warriors. Araethyrea died first, and
Aoris, in memory of his sister, changed the name of the land to
Araethyrea. This is why Homer, in making a list of Agamemnon’s subjects,
has the verse: Orneaiwas their home and Araethyrea the delightful.[^169]
The tombs of the children of Aras are, in my opinion, on the Arantine
Hill and not in any other part of the land. On the top of them are
far-seen tombstones, and before the celebration of the mysteries of
Demeter the people look at these tombs and call Aras and his children to
the libations.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.12.6">

The Argives say that Phlias, who has given the land its third name, was
the son of Ceisus, the son of Temenus. This account I can by no means
accept, but I know that he is called a son of Dionysus, and that he is
said to have been one of those who sailed on the Argo. The verses of the
Rhodian poet confirm me in my opinion:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Came after these Phlias from Araethyrea to the muster;

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Here did he dwell and prosper, because Dionysus his father

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Cared for him well, and his home was near to the springs of Asopos.

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

The account goes on to say that the mother of Phlias was Araethyrea and
not Khthonophyle. The latter was his wife and bore him Androdamas.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.1">

On the return of the Herakleidai disturbances took place throughout the
whole of the Peloponnesus except Arcadia, so that many of the cities
received additional settlers from the Dorian lineage, and their
inhabitants suffered yet more revolutions. The history of Phleious is as
follows. The Dorian Rhegnidas, the son of Phalkes, the son of Temenus,
attacked it from Argos and Sikyonia. Some of the Phliasians were
inclined to accept the offer of Rhegnidas, which was that they should
remain on their own estates and receive Rhegnidas as their king, giving
the Dorians with him a share in the land.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.2">

Hippasus and his party, on the other hand, urged the citizens to defend
themselves, and not to give up many advantages to the Dorians without
striking a blow. The people, however, accepted the opposite policy, and
so Hippasus and any others who wished fled to Samos. Great-grandson of
this Hippasus was Pythagoras, the celebrated sage. For Pythagoras was
the son of Mnesarkhos, the son of Euphranor, the son of Hippasus. This
is the account the Phliasians give about themselves, and the Sikyonians
in general agree with them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.3">

I will now add an account of the most remarkable of their famous sights.
On the Phliasian citadel is a grove of cypress trees and a sanctuary
which from ancient times has been held to be peculiarly holy. The
earliest Phliasians named the goddess to whom the sanctuary belongs
Ganymeda; but later authorities call her Hebe, whom Homer[^170] mentions
in the duel between Menelaos and Alexander, saying that she was the
cup-bearer of the gods; and again he says, in the descent of Odysseus to
Hades,[^171] that she was the wife of Hēraklēs. Olen,[^172] in his hymn
to Hērā, says that Hērā was reared by the Seasons, and that her children
were Ares and Hebe. Of the honors that the Phliasians pay to this
goddess the greatest is the pardoning of suppliants.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.4">

All those who seek sanctuary here receive full forgiveness, and
prisoners, when set free, dedicate their fetters on the trees in the
grove. The Phliasians also celebrate a yearly festival which they call
Ivy-cutters. There is no statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], either kept
in secret or openly displayed, and the reason for this is set forth in a
sacred discourse \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieros
logos</span>\] of theirs though on the left as you go out is a temple of
Hērā with a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Parian
marble.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.5">

On the citadel is another enclosure, which is sacred to Demeter, and in
it are a temple and statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Demeter and
\[one of\] her daughter. Here there is also a bronze statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Artemis,
which appeared to me to be ancient. As you go down from the citadel you
see on the right a temple of Asklepios with a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the god as
a beardless youth. Below this temple is built a theater. Not far from it
is a sanctuary of Demeter and old, seated statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.6">

On the marketplace is a votive offering, a bronze she-goat for the most
part covered with gold. The following is the reason why it has received
honors among the Phliasians. The constellation which they call the Goat
on its rising causes continual damage to the vines. In order that they
may suffer nothing unpleasant from it, the Phliasians pay honors to the
bronze goat on the marketplace and adorn the image with gold. Here also
is the tomb of Aristias, the son of Pratinas.[^173] This Aristias and
his father Pratinas composed satyric plays more popular than any save
those of Aeschylus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.7">

Behind the marketplace is a building which the Phliasians name the House
of Divination. Into it Amphiaraos entered, slept the night there, and
then first, say the Phliasians, began to divine. According to their
account Amphiaraos was for a time an ordinary person and no diviner.
Ever since that time the building has been shut up. Not far away is what
is called the Omphalos (Navel), the center of all the Peloponnesus, if
they speak the truth about it. Farther on from the Omphalos they have an
old sanctuary of Dionysus, a sanctuary of Apollo, and one of Isis. The
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Dionysus is visible to all, and so also is that of Apollo, but the image
of Isis only the priests may behold.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.13.8">

There is also a tale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] told by
Phliasians, and it goes like this. When Hēraklēs came back safe from
Libya, bringing the apples of the Hesperides, as they were called, he
visited Phleious on some private matter. While he was staying there
Oineus came to him from Aetolia. He had already allied himself to the
lineage of Hēraklēs, and after his arrival on this occasion either he
entertained Hēraklēs or Hēraklēs entertained him. Be this as it may,
displeased with the drink given him Hēraklēs struck on the head with one
of his fingers the boy Cyathus, the cup-bearer of Oineus, who died on
the spot from the blow. A chapel keeps the memory of the deed fresh
among the Phliasians; it is built by the side of the sanctuary of
Apollo, and it contains statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] made of
stone representing Cyathus holding out a cup to Hēraklēs.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.14.1">

Celeae is some five stadium-lengths distant from the city, and here they
celebrate the mysteries in honor of Demeter, not every year but every
fourth year. The initiating priest is not appointed for life, but at
each celebration they elect a fresh one, who takes, if he cares to do
so, a wife. In this respect their custom differs from that at Eleusis,
but the actual celebration is modeled on the Eleusinian rites. The
Phliasians themselves admit that they copy the ‘performance’ at Eleusis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.14.2">

They say that it was Dysaules, the brother of Keleus, who came to their
land and established the mysteries, and that he had been expelled from
Eleusis by Ion, when Ion, the son of Xuthus, was chosen by the Athenians
to be commander-in-chief in the Eleusinian war. Now I cannot possibly
agree with the Phliasians in supposing that an Eleusinian was conquered
in battle and driven away into exile, for the war terminated in a treaty
before it was fought out, and Eumolpos himself remained at Eleusis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.14.3">

But it is possible that Dysaules came to Phleious for some other reason
than that given by the Phliasians. I do not believe either that he was
related to Keleus, or that he was in any way distinguished at Eleusis,
otherwise Homer would never have passed him by in his poems. For Homer
is one of those who have written in honor of Demeter, and when he is
making a list of those to whom the goddess taught the mysteries he knows
nothing of an Eleusinian named Dysaules. These are the verses:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

She to Triptolemos taught, and to Diokles, driver of horses,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Also to mighty Eumolpos, to Keleus, leader of peoples,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Cult of the holy rites, to them all her mystery telling.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.14.4">

At all events, this Dysaules, according to the Phliasians, established
the mysteries here, and he it was who gave to the place the name Celeae.
I have already said that the tomb of Dysaules is here. So the tomb of
Aras was made earlier, for according to the account of the Phliasians
Dysaules did not arrive in the reign of Aras, but later. For Aras, they
say, was a contemporary of Prometheus, the son of Iapetos, and three
generations of men older than Pelasgus the son of Arkas and those called
in Athens aboriginals. On the roof of what is called the Anactorum they
say is dedicated the chariot of Pelops.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.15.1">

These are the things that I found most worthy of mention among the
Phliasians. On the road from Corinth to Argos is a small city Kleonai.
They say that Kleones was a son of Pelops, though there are some who say
that Kleone was one of the daughters of Asopos, that flows by the side
of Sikyon. Be this as it may, one or other of these two accounts for the
name of the city. Here there is a sanctuary of Athena, and the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is a work of
Skyllis and Dipoinos.[^174] Some hold them to have been the pupils of
Daidalos, but others will have it that Daidalos took a wife from Gortyn,
and that Dipoinos and Skyllis were his sons by this woman. Kleonai
possesses this sanctuary and the tomb of Eurytos and Kteatos. The story
is that as they were going as ambassadors from Elis to the Isthmian
contest they were here shot by Hēraklēs, who charged them with being his
adversaries in the war against Augeias.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.15.2">

From Kleonai to Argos are two roads; one is direct and only for men who
are physically fit, the other goes along the pass called Trētos, is
narrow like the other, being surrounded by mountains, but is
nevertheless more suitable for vehicles. In these mountains is still
shown the cave of the famous lion, and the place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrion</span>\] called Neméā
is distant some fifteen stadium-lengths. In Neméā is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Nemean
\[<span custom-style="chs_foreign_emphasis">Nemeios</span>\] Zeus, which
is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], but I found
that the roof had caved in and that there was no longer any statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] \[of Zeus\]
left. Around the temple is a grove of cypress trees, and here it is,
they say, that Opheltes was placed by his nurse in the grass and killed
by the serpent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drakōn</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.15.3">

The Argives offer-sacrifices
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] to Zeus the
Nemean \[Nemeios\] in Nemeā, and elect a priest of Nemean Zeus; moreover
they offer a prize for a race in armor at the winter celebration of the
Nemean games. In this place is the tomb of Opheltes; around it is a
fence of stones, and within the enclosure are altars. There is also a
mound of earth which is the tomb of Lycurgus \[Lykourgos\] the father of
Opheltes. The spring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pēgē</span>\] they call
Adrasteia for some reason
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] or other,
perhaps because Adrastos found it. The land was named, they say, after
Nemeā, who was another daughter of Asopos. Above Nemeā is Mount Apesas,
where they say that Perseus first made-sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] to Zeus of
Apesas.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.15.4">

Going upland to \[the pass called\] Trētos and then down again along the
road to Argos, you see on the left the ruins
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ereipia</span>\] of Mycenae.
The Greeks are generally aware that the founder
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikistēs</span>\] of Mycenae
was Perseus, but I will also write down the cause
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] of its
foundation \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikismos</span>\]
and the pretext
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">prophasis</span>\] that
theArgives gave when they at a later point destroyed Mycenae. In the
region now called Argolis, some things most ancient are not memorialized
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmoneuein</span>\] while
other things are, and here is one such thing: they say that Inakhos was
once their king and that he named the river Inakhos after himself and
that he sacrificed to Hērā.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.15.5">

There is also another tale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] told
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legesthai</span>\] that goes
like this… that Phoroneus was the first to be born in this land, and
that Inakhos, the father of Phoroneus, was not a man but the river. This
river, with the rivers Kephisos and Asterion, arbitrated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dikazein</span>\] concerning
possession of the land between Poseidon and Hērā. They decided
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krinein</span>\] that the land
belonged to Hērā, and so Poseidon made their waters disappear. For this
reason neither Inakhos nor either of the other rivers I have mentioned
provides any water except whenver the god \[= Zeus\] makes rain. In
summer their streams are dry except for those at Lerna. Phoroneus, the
son of Inakhos, was the first to gather together humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] into a
commonality \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">koinon</span>\],
who up to that time had been scattered and
living-in-settlements\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\]
all by themselves. The place into which they were first gathered was
named the City \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Astu</span>\]
of Phoroneus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.1">

Argos, the maternal grandson of Phoroneus became king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] after
Phoroneus andgave his own name to the land. Argos fathered Peirasos and
Phorbas, Phorbas fathered Triopas, and Triopas fathered Iasos and
Agenor. Io, the daughter of Iasos, went to Egypt, whether the
circumstances be as Herodotus writes or as the Greeks say. After Iasos,
Krotopos the son of Agenor came to power
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] and fathered
Sthenelas, but Danaos sailed from Egypt against Gelanor the son of
Sthenelasand put a stop to the succession of the descendants of Agenor
to kingship. What followed is known to all alike the crime that the
daughters of Danaos committed against their male cousins, and how, after
the death of Danaos, Lynkeus succeeded him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.2">

Then there was Abas the son of Lynkeus, and his own sons Akrisios and
Proitos divided the kingship
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileiā</span>\] between
themselves. Akrisios remained where he was at Argos, and Proitos took
over the Hēraion, Mideiā, Tiryns, and the Argive coastal region. Traces
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeia</span>\] of the
residence \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikēsis</span>\] of
Proitos in Tiryns remain to the present day. Afterwards Akrisios,
learning that Perseus himself was not only alive but accomplishing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apodeiknusthai</span>\] great
deeds, withdrew to Larisa, by \[the river\] Pēneios. And Perseus,
wishing at all costs to see the father of his mother and to greet him
with fair words and deeds, visited him at Larisa. Being in the prime of
life and proud of being the inventor of the discus, he showed off
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apodeiknusthai</span>\] \[his
skill in throwing the discus\] in front of everybody, and Akrisios,
through the agency of some superhuman force
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimōn</span>\], stepped
unnoticed into the path of the discus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.3">

So the prediction of the god to Akrisios found its fulfillment
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">telos</span>\], nor was
the-thing-that-had-been-prophesied
\[t<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ò khreōn</span>\] prevented
by his precautions against his daughter and the son of his daughter.
Perseus felt shame because of what-was-said
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phēmē</span>\] about the
homicide, and so, on his return to Argos, he induced Megapenthes, the
son of Proitos, to make an exchange of kingdoms; taking over for himself
the rule \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhē</span>\] of the
kindom of Megapenthes, he founded
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ktizein</span>\] Mycenae. For
on its site the pommel \[myces =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mukēs</span>\] fell out of his
sword, and he regarded this as a sign
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sēmeion</span>\] to establish
the foundation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikismos</span>\] of a citadel
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\]. I have also
heard the following account. He was thirsty, and the thought occurred to
him to pick up a mushroom \[myces =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mukēs</span>\] from the ground.
Water flowed from that spot, and, taking delight in drinking from it, he
gave to the place the name of Mycenae.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.4">

Homer in the <span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Odyssey</span> \[2.120\]
mentions a woman \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gunē</span>\]
named Mycene \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mukēnē</span>\]
in the following verse:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Τυρώ τ’ Ἀλκμήνη τε ἐϋστέφανός τε Μυκήνη

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Tyro and Alkmēnē and the fair-garlanded lady Mycene \[Mukēnē\],
the-one-with-the-beautiful-garlands
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eu-stephanos</span>\].

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

She is said to have been the daughter of Inakhos and the wife of Arestōr
in the {Hesiodic\] poetry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epē</span>\] that the Greeks
call the <span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Great Ēhoiai</span>. So they
say that the name of the citadel
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\] originated from
her \[= Mycene = Mukēnē\]. But the tradition that is attributed to
Acusilaus (Akousilaos), that Myceneus \[Mukēneus\] was the son of
Sparton \[Spartōn\], and Sparton of Phoroneus, I cannot accept
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-dekhesthai</span>\],
because the Lacedaemonians themselves do not accept it either. I say
this because, although the Lacedaemonians have at Amyklai an image
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of a woman
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gunē</span>\] named Spartē,
even they would be amazed at the mere mention of a Spartōn, son of
Phoroneus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.5">

It was envy that caused the Argives to destroy Mycenae. For at the time
of the Persian invasion the Argives made-no-move
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hēsukhazein</span>\], but the
Mycenaeans sent eighty men to Thermopylae who shared in the achievement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\] of the
Lacedaemonians. This act-of-eagerness-for-distinction
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">philo-tīmēma</span>\] brought
ruin upon them by aggravating the Argives. There still remain, however,
parts of the enclosing-wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\], including
the gate \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pulē</span>\], on top
of which stand lions. These \[walls\], too, are said to be the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erga</span>\] of the Cyclopes,
who made for Proitos the \[circumference-\] wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\] at Tiryns.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.6">

Inside the ruins
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ereipia</span>\] of Mycenae is
a spring \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krēnē</span>\] called
Perseiā; there are also underground chambers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hupo-gaia
oikodomēmata</span>\] of Atreus and his offspring
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paides</span>\], in which were
stored the treasuries
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thēsauroi</span>\] of their
possessions. The tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Atreus is
there, along with the tombs of those who, besides Agamemnon, returned
with him from Troy and were slaughtered by Aigisthos after they had been
wined and dined by him at a banquet. As for the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\][^175] of
Cassandra \[Kassandrā\], there is a rival claim to it by the
Lacedaemonians who dwell
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in the
vicinity of Amyklai. There is \[at Mycenae\] another tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] \[besides the
tombs in the Treasury of Atreus\] that specifically belongs to
Agamemnon, and there is also another tomb belonging to Eurymedon his
charioteer, while still another one is shared by Teledāmos and Pelops,
twin sons, they say, of Cassandra,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.16.7">

whom while they were still infants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nēpioi</span>\] Aigisthos
slaughtered after he slaughtered their parents. As for Electra … Orestes
married her off to Pylades, and Hellanicus adds that the children of
Pylades by Electra were Medon and Strophios. Clytemnestra and Aigisthos
were buried at some little distance from the \[circumference-\]wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\]. They were
thought unworthy of a place inside it \[= the circumference-wall\],
which is where Agamemnon himself and those who were slaughtered with him
had been placed.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.1">

Fifteen stadium-lengths distant from Mycenae is on the left the Hēraion.
Alongside the road flows the rivulet called ‘the-water-that-makes-free’
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Eleutherion</span>\]. The
women who attend the sacred space
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] use it \[= the
water\] in purifications
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katharsia</span>\] and for
sacrifices \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusai</span>\]
that are mystical
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-rrhētoi</span>\]. The
sacred space \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\]
itself is on a lower part of Euboea. Euboea is the name they give to the
hill here, saying that Asterion the river had three daughters, Euboea,
Prosymna, and Akraia, and that they were nurses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">trophoi</span>\] of Hērā.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.2">

The hill opposite the Hēraion they name after Akraia, while the environs
of the sacred space
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] they name
after Euboea, and, further, the land beneath the Hēraion they name after
Prosymna. This on flows above the Hēraion, and falling into a cleft
disappears. On its banks grows a plant, which also is called
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">asterion</span>. They offer the
plant itself to Hēra, and from its leaves they weave garlands
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanoi</span>\] for her.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.3">

It is said that the architect of the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] was Eupolemos,
an Argive. The sculptures carved above the columns
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kiones</span>\] refer not only
to the birth \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genesis</span>\]
of Zeus and the battle between the gods and the giants but also to the
Trojan war and the capture of Ilion. Before the entrance stand statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andriantes</span>\] of women
who have been priestesses
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereiai</span>\] of Hērā and
of various heroes
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōes</span>\], including
Orestes. I say it this way because the statue that has an inscription on
it claiming that it represents the Emperor Augustus is really, they say,
the statue of Orestes. In the front-part-of-the-temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pro-nāos</span>\] are on the
one side ancient statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of the
Graces \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kharites</span>\], and
on the right a couch
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">klinē</span>\] of Hērā and a
votive offering
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēma</span>\], that is,
the shield \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aspis</span>\] that
Menelaos once took from Euphorbos at Troy.[^176]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.4">

The statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Hērā is seated on a throne
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thronos</span>\]; it \[= the
statue\] is huge in size, made of gold and ivory, and is a work of
Polyclitus \[Polykleitos\]. She is wearing \[on her head\] a garland
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanos</span>\] that
features Graces
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Kharites</span>\] and Seasons
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Hōrai</span>\] worked upon it,
and in one hand she holds a pomegranate while in the other a scepter
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skēptron</span>\]. About the
pomegranate … I must let go of this subject, since its story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] is somewhat
mystical \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-rrhētos</span>\].
The presence of a cuckoo seated on the scepter
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skēptron</span>\] they explain
by telling how, when Zeus lusted
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erân</span>\] for Hērā as
virgin \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\], he
changed himself into this bird, and she caught it to be her plaything
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paignion</span>\]. This story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] and similar
things said about the gods I write down without accepting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apodekhesthai</span>\] them,
but I write them down nevertheless.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.5">

By the side of Hērā stands what is said to be a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Hēbē
fashioned by Naukydes; it, too, is of ivory and gold. By its side is an
old statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Hērā on a column
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kiōn</span>\]. The oldest
statue is made of wild-pear wood, and was dedicated in Tiryns by
Peirasos, son of Argos, and when the Argives destroyed Tiryns they
carried it away to the Hēraion. I myself saw it, a small, seated statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.6">

Of the votive offerings
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēmata</span>\] the
following are worth speaking-about
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\]. There is an
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] upon
which is worked in relief the storied
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">legomenon</span>\] wedding of
Hēbē and Hēraklēs. This is of silver, but the peacock dedicated by
‘King’ \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\]
Hadrian is of gold and gleaming stones. He dedicated it because they
hold the bird to be sacred to Hērā. Also deposited here are a golden
garland \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanos</span>\] and
a purple robe \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peplos</span>\],
offerings \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anathēmata</span>\]
of Nero.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.17.7">

Above this temple are the foundations of the earlier temple and such
parts of it as were spared by the flames. It had burned down because
sleep overpowered Khryseis, the priestess of Hērā, when the lamp before
the garlands set fire to them. Khryseis went to Tegea and supplicated
Athena <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Aléā</span>. Although so
great a disaster had befallen them the Argives did not take down the
statue of Khryseis; it is still in position in front of the burned
temple.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.1">

By the side of the road from Mycenae to Argos there is on the left hand
a hero-shrine \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\]
of Perseus. He gets honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\], as I
discovered, from the local-population-nearby
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">proskhōrioi</span>\] here as
well \[as inside the walls of Mycenae\], but the greatest honors are
paid to him in Seriphos and among the Athenians, who have a precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] sacred to
Perseus and an altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Dictys and
Klymene, who are called the saviors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōtēres</span>\] of Perseus.
As one advancxes in the Argive territory from this hero-shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hērōion</span>\], therfe is on
the right the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Thyestes.
On it is a ram \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krios</span>\]
made of stone, because Thyestes obtained a golden lamb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arēn</span>\] after seducing
his brother’s wife. Atreus was not restrained by prudence
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logismos</span>\] from
retaliating, but contrived the slaughter of the children of Thyestes and
the banquet that is sung about in songs.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.2">

But as to what followed, I cannot say for certain whether Aigisthos
began the injustice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">adikiā</span>\] or whether
Agamemnon was first to commit injustice in killing Tantalos the son of
Thyestes. It is said that Tantalos had lived-with
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-oikeîn</span>\]Clytaemnestra,
having received her from Tyndareus when she was still a virgin. I myself
do not wish to condemn them of having been wicked by nature
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">phusis</span>\]; but if the
pollution \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">miasma</span>\] of
Pelops and the avenging spirit of Myrtilos dogged their steps so long,
it was after all only consistent that the Pythian priestess said to the
Spartan Glaukos, the son of Epikydes, who consulted her about breaking
his oath, that the punishment for this also comes upon the descendants.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.3">

A short distance beyond the Rams
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">krioi</span>\]—this is the
name they give to the tomb of Thyestes—there is on the left a place
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khōrion</span>\] called Mysia
and a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Demeter
Mysia, so named after a man Mysios who, say the Argives, was another one
of those who acted as a host
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenos</span>\] to Demeter. In
any case, this sanctuary has no roof, but inside it is another shrine
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\], built of baked
brick, in it are wooden-statues of the Maiden
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Korē</span>\], Pluto
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Ploutōn</span>\], and Demeter.
Farther on is the river called Inakhos, and on the other side of it an
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of Hēlios
\[the Sun\]. After this you will come to a gate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pulē</span>\] named after the
sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] that
is near it. This sanctuary belongs to Eileithuia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.4">

The Argives are the only Greeks that I know of who have been divided
into three kingdoms. For in the reign of Anaxagoras, son of Argeus, son
of Megapenthes, the women were smitten with madness, and straying from
their homes they roamed about the country, until Melampos the son of
Amythaon cured them of the plague on condition that he himself and his
brother Bias had a share of the kingdom equal to that of Anaxagoras. Now
descended from Bias five men, Neleids on their mother’s side, occupied
the throne for four generations down to Kyanippos, son of Aigialeus, and
descended from Melampos six men in six generations down to Amphilokhos,
son of Amphiaraos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.5">

But the native house of the lineage of Anaxagoras ruled longer than the
other two. For Iphis, son of Alector, son of Anaxagoras, left the throne
to Sthenelus, son of Capaneus his brother. After the capture of Troy,
Amphilokhos migrated to the people now called the Amphilochians, and,
Kyanippos having died without issue, Cylarabes, son of Sthenelus, became
sole king. However, he too left no offspring, and Argos was seized by
Orestes, son of Agamemnon, who was a neighbor. Besides his ancestral
dominion, he had extended his rule over the greater part of Arcadia and
had succeeded to the throne of Sparta; he also had a contingent of
allies from Phokis always ready to help him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.6">

When Orestes became king of the Lacedaemonians, they themselves
consented to accept him for they considered that the sons of the
daughter of Tyndareus had a claim to the throne prior to that of
Nikostratos and Megapenthes, who were sons of Menelaos by a slave woman.
On the death of Orestes, there succeeded to the throne Tisamenus, the
son of Orestes and of Hermione, the daughter of Menelaos. The mother of
Penthilos, the bastard son of Orestes, was, according to the poet
Cinaethon, Erigone, the daughter of Aigisthos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.7">

It was in the reign of this Tisamenus that the Herakleidai returned to
the Peloponnesus; they were Temenus and Kresphontes, the sons of
Aristomakhos, together with the sons of the third brother, Aristodemos,
who had died. Their claim to Argos and to the throne of Argos was, in my
opinion, most just, because Tisamenus was descended from Pelops, but the
Herakleidai were descendants of Perseus. Tyndareus himself, they made
out, had been expelled by Hippokoön, and they said that Hēraklēs, having
killed Hippokoön and his sons, had given the land in trust to Tyndareus.
They gave the same kind of account about Messenia also, that it had been
given in trust to Nestor by Hēraklēs after he had taken Pylos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.8">

So they expelled Tisamenus from Lacedaemon and Argos, and the
descendants of Nestor from Messenia, namely Alkmaion, son of Sillus, son
of Thrasymedes, Peisistratos, son of Peisistratos, and the sons of
Paion, son of Antilokhos, and with them Melanthos, son of Andropompus,
son of Borus, son of Penthilos, son of Periclymenus. So Tisamenus and
his sons went with his army to the land that is now Achaea.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.18.9">

To what people Peisistratos retreated I do not know, but the rest of the
Neleidai went to Athens, and the clans of the Painonidai and of the
Alkmaionidai were named after them. Melanthos even came to the throne,
having deposed Thymoetes the son of Oxyntes; for Thymoetes was the last
Athenian king descended from Theseus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.1">

It is not to my purpose that I should set forth here the history of
Kresphontes and of the sons of Aristodemos. But Temenus openly employed,
instead of his sons, Delphontes, son of Antimakhos, son of Thrasyanor,
son of Ktesippos, son of Hēraklēs, as general in war and as adviser on
all occasions. Even before this he had made him his son-in-law, while
Hyrnetho was his favorite daughter; he was accordingly suspected of
intending to divert the throne to her and Delphontes. For this reason
his sons plotted against him, and Ceisus, the eldest of them, seized the
kingdom.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.2">

But from the earliest times the Argives have loved freedom and
self-government, and they limited to the utmost the authority of their
kings, so that to Medon, the son of Ceisus, and to his descendants was
left a kingdom that was such only in name. Meltas, the son of Lacedas,
the tenth descendant of Medon, was condemned by the people and deposed
altogether from the kingship.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.3">

The most famous building in the city of Argos is the sanctuary of Apollo
Lykios (wolf-god). The modern statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] was made by
the Athenian Attalos, but the original temple and wooden-statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\] were the
offering of Danaos. I am of opinion that in those days all statues
called <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoana</span>, especially
Egyptian ones, were made of wood. The reason why Danaos founded a
sanctuary of Apollo Lykios was this. On coming to Argos he claimed the
kingdom against Gelanor, the son of Sthenelas. Many plausible arguments
were brought forward by both parties, and those of Sthenelas were
considered as fair as those of his opponent; so the people, who were
sitting in judgment, put off, they say, the decision to the following
day.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.4">

At dawn a wolf fell upon a herd of oxen that was pasturing before the
wall, and attacked and fought with the bull that was the leader of the
herd. It occurred to the Argives that Gelanor was like the bull and
Danaos like the wolf, for as the wolf will not live with men, so Danaos
up to that time had not lived with them. It was because the wolf
overcame the bull that Danaos won the kingdom. Accordingly, believing
that Apollo had brought the wolf on the herd, he founded a sanctuary of
Apollo Lykios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.5">

Here is dedicated the throne of Danaos, and here Is placed a statue of
Biton, in the form of a man carrying a bull on his shoulders. According
to the poet Lykeas, when the Argives were holding a sacrifice to Zeus at
Nemeā, Biton by sheer physical strength took up a bull and carried it
there. Next to this statue is a fire which they keep burning, calling it
the fire of Phoroneus. For they do not admit that fire was given to
mankind by Prometheus, but insist in assigning the discovery of fire to
Phoroneus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.6">

As to the wooden images of Aphrodite and Hermes, the one they say was
made by Epeios, while the other is a votive offering of Hypermnestra.
She was the only one of the daughters of Danaos who neglected his
command,[^177] and was accordingly brought to justice by him, because be
considered that his life was in danger so long as Lynkeus was at large,
and that the refusal to share in the crime of her sisters increased the
disgrace of the contriver of the deed. On her trial she was acquitted by
the Argives, and to commemorate her escape she dedicated an image of
Aphrodite, the Bringer of Nike.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.7">

Within the temple is a statue of Ladas, the swiftest runner of his time,
and one of Hermes with a tortoise which he has caught to make a lyre.
Before the temple is a pit with a relief representing a fight between a
bull and a wolf, and with them a maiden throwing a rock at the bull. The
maiden is thought to be Artemis. Danaos dedicated these, and some
pillars hard by and wooden images of Zeus and Artemis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.19.8">

Here are tombs; one is that of Linos, the son of Apollo by Psamathe, the
daughter of Krotopos; the other, they say, is that of Linos the poet.
The story of the latter Linos is more appropriate to another part of my
narrative, and so I omit it here, while I have already given the history
of the son of Psamathe in my account of Megara. After these is an image
of Apollo, God of Streets, and an altar of Zeus, God of Rain, where
those who were helping Polyneikes in his efforts to be restored to
Thebes swore an oath together that they would either capture Thebes or
die. As to the tomb of Prometheus, their account seems to me to be less
probable than that of the Opuntians, but they hold to it nevertheless.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.1">

Passing over a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of Creugas, a
boxer, and a trophy that was set up to celebrate a victory over the
Corinthians, you come to a seated statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Zeus
Meilikhios \[‘benign’\], made of white marble by Polyclitus
\[Polykleitos\].[^178] I discovered that it was made for the following
reason. Ever since the Lacedaemonians began to make war upon the Argives
there was no cessation of hostilities until Philip, the son of Amyntas,
forced them to stay within the original boundaries of their territories.
Before this, if the Lacedaemonians were not engaged on some business
outside the Peloponnesus, they were always trying to annex a piece of
Argive territory; or if they were busied with a war beyond their borders
it was the turn of the Argives to retaliate.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.2">

When the hatred of both sides was at its height, the Argives resolved to
maintain a thousand picked men. The commander appointed over them was
the Argive Bryas. His general behavior to the men of the people was
violent, and a girl who was being taken to the bridegroom he seized from
those who were escorting her and ravished. When night came on, the girl
waited until he was asleep and put out his eyes. Detected in the
morning, she took refuge as a suppliant with the people. When they did
not give her up to the Thousand for punishment both sides took up arms;
the people won the day, and in their anger left none of their opponents
alive.[^179] Subsequently they had recourse to purifications for
shedding kindred blood; among other things they dedicated a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Zeus
Meilikhios \[‘benign’\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.3">

Hard by are Kleobis and Biton carved in relief on stone, themselves
drawing the carriage and taking in it their mother to the sanctuary of
Hērā. Opposite them is a sanctuary of Nemean Zeus, and an upright bronze
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the
god made by Lysippos. Going forward from this you see on the right the
tomb of Phoroneus, to whom even in our time they bring offerings as to a
hero. Over against the Nemean Zeus is a temple of Fortune, which must be
very old if it be the one in which Palamedes dedicated the dice that he
had invented.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.4">

The tomb near this they call that of the maenad Chorea, saying that she
was one of the women who joined Dionysus in his expedition against
Argos, and that Perseus, being victorious in the battle, put most of the
women to the sword. To the rest they gave a common grave, but to Chorea
they gave burial apart because of her high rank.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.5">

A little farther on is a sanctuary of the Seasons. On coming back from
here you see statues of Polyneikes, the son of Oedipus, and of all the
chieftains who with him were killed in battle at the wall of Thebes.
These men Aeschylus has reduced to the number of seven only, although
there were more chiefs than this in the expedition, from Argos, from
Messene, with some even from Arcadia. But the Argives have adopted the
number seven from the drama of Aeschylus, and near to their statues are
the statues of those who took Thebes: Aigialeus, son of Adrastos;
Promakhos, son of Parthenopaeus, son of Talaos; Polydoros, son of
Hippomedon; Thersandros; Alkmaion and Amphilokhos, the sons of
Amphiaraos; Diomedes, and Sthenelus. Among their company were also
Euryalus, son of Mecisteus, and Adrastos and Timeas, sons of Polyneikes.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.6">

Not far from the statues are shown the tomb of Danaos and a cenotaph of
the Argives who met their death at Troy or on the journey home. Here
there is also a sanctuary of Zeus the Savior. Beyond it is a building
where the Argive women bewail Adonis. On the right of the entrance is
the sanctuary of Kephisos. It is said that the water of this river was
not utterly destroyed by Poseidon, but that just in this place, where
the sanctuary is, it can be heard flowing under the earth.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.7">

Beside the sanctuary of Kephisos is a head of Medusa made of stone,
which is said to be another of the works of the Cyclopes. The ground
behind it is called even at the present time the Place of Judgment,
because it was here that they say Hypermnestra was brought to judgment
by Danaos. Not far from this is a theater. In it are some noteworthy
sights, including a representation of a man killing another, namely the
Argive Perilaos, the son of Alcenor, killing the Spartan Othryadas.
Before this, Perilaos had succeeded in winning the prize for wrestling
at the Nemean games.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.8">

Above the theater is a sanctuary of Aphrodite, and before the image is a
slab with a representation crafted on it in relief of Telesilla, the
lyric poetess. Her books lie scattered at her feet, and she herself
holds in her hand an helmet, which she is looking at and is about to
place on her head. Telesilla was a distinguished woman who was
especially renowned for her poetry. It happened that the Argives had
suffered an awful defeat at the hands of Kleomenes, the son of
Anaxandrides, and the Lacedaemonians. Some fell in the actual fighting;
others, who had fled to the grove of Argos, also perished. At first they
left sanctuary under an agreement, which was treacherously broken, and
the survivors, when they realized this, were burned to death in the
grove. So when Kleomenes led his troops to Argos there were no men to
defend it.[^180]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.9">

But Telesilla mounted on the wall all the slaves and such as were
incapable of bearing arms through youth or old age, and she herself,
collecting the arms in the sanctuaries and those that were left in the
houses, armed the women of vigorous age, and then posted them where she
knew the enemy would attack. When the Lacedaemonians came on, the women
were not dismayed at their battlecry, but stood their ground and fought
valiantly. Then the Lacedaemonians, realizing that to destroy the women
would be an invidious success while defeat would mean a shameful
disaster, gave way before the women.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.20.10">

This fight had been foretold by the Pythian priestess in the oracle
quoted by Herodotus, who perhaps understood to what it referred and
perhaps did not:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

But when the time shall come that the female conquers in battle,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Driving away the male, and wins great glory in Argos,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Many an Argive woman will tear both cheeks in her sorrow.

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Such are the words of the oracle referring to the exploit of the women.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.1">

Having descended thence, and having turned again to the marketplace, we
come to the tomb of Cerdo, the wife of Phoroneus, and to a temple of
Asklepios. The sanctuary of Artemis, surnamed Persuasion, is another
offering of Hypermnestra after winning the trial to which she was
brought by her father because of Lynkeus. Here there is also a bronze
statue of Aeneas, and a place called Delta. I intentionally do not
discuss the origin of the name, because I could not accept the
traditional accounts.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.2">

In front of it stands an altar of Zeus Phyxios, and near is the tomb of
Hypermnestra, the mother of Amphiaraos, the other tomb being that of
Hypermnestra, the daughter of Danaos, with whom is also buried Lynkeus.
Opposite these is the tomb of Talaos, the son of Bias; the history of
Bias and his descendants I have already given.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.3">

A sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of
Athena <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Salpinx</span>
\[‘Trumpet’\], they say, was founded by Hēgeleōs. This Hēgeleōs, they
also say, was the son of Tyrsenos, and Tyrsenos was the son of Hēraklēs
and the Lydian woman; Tyrsenos invented the trumpet
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">salpinx</span>\], and
Hēgeleōs, the son of Tyrsenos , taught the Dorians who were with Tēmenos
the sound \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">psophos</span>\] of
the instrument
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">organon</span>\]. It is for
this reason that he made-an-additional-name
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ep-onomazein</span>\] for
Athena, <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Salpinx</span>
\[‘Trumpet’\]. In front of the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāós</span>\] of Athena is,
they say, the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Epimenides.
They also say that the Spartans \[Lakedaimonioi\] made war upon the
people of Knossos and took Epimenides alive; they then put him to death
for not prophesying
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteuesthai</span>\] for them
things that were fitting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aisia</span>\], and they \[=
the people of Argos\], taking him \[= his body\], buried
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thaptein</span>\] him here.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.4">

The building of white marble in just about the middle of the marketplace
is not, as the Argives declare, a trophy in honor of a victory over
Pyrrhos of Epeiros, but it can be shown that his body was burned here,
and that this is his monument, on which are carved in relief the
elephants and his other instruments of warfare. This building then was
set up where the pyre stood, but the bones of Pyrrhos lie in the
sanctuary of Demeter, beside which, as I have shown in my account of
Attica, his death occurred. At the entrance to this sanctuary of Demeter
you can see a bronze shield of Pyrrhos hanging dedicated over the door.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.5">

Not far from the building in the marketplace of Argos is a mound of
earth, in which they say lies the head of the Gorgon Medusa. I omit the
miraculous, but give the rational parts of the story about her. After
the death of her father, Phorcus, she reigned over those living around
Lake Tritonis, going out hunting and leading the Libyans to battle. On
one such occasion, when she was encamped with an army over against the
forces of Perseus, who was followed by picked troops from the
Peloponnesus, she was assassinated by night. Perseus, admiring her
beauty even in death, cut off her head and carried it to show the
Greeks.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.6">

But Prokles, the son of Eucrates, a Carthaginian, thought a different
account more plausible than the preceding. It is as follows. Among the
incredible monsters to be found in the Libyan desert are wild men and
wild women. Prokles affirmed that he had seen a man from them who had
been brought to Rome. So he guessed that a woman wandered from them,
reached Lake Tritonis, and harried the neighbors until Perseus killed
her; Athena was supposed to have helped him in this exploit, because the
people who live around Lake Tritonis are sacred to her.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.7">

In Argos, by the side of this monument of the Gorgon, is the tomb of
Gorgophone (Gorgon-kilIer), the daughter of Perseus. As soon as you hear
the name you can understand the reason why it was given her. On the
death of her husband, Perieres, the son of Aeolus, whom she married when
a virgin, she married Oibalos, being the first woman, they say, to marry
a second time; for before this wives were accustomed, on the death of
their husbands, to live as widows.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.8">

In front of the tomb is a trophy of stone made to commemorate a victory
over an Argive Laphaes. When this man was tyrant I write what the
Argives themselves say concerning themselves—the people rose up against
him and cast him out. He fled to Sparta, and the Lacedaemonians tried to
restore him to power, but were defeated by the Argives, who killed the
greater part of them and Laphaes as well. Not far from the trophy is the
sanctuary of Leto; the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is a work of
Praxiteles.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.9">

The statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikōn</span>\] of
the maiden beside the goddess they call Chloris (Pale), saying that she
was a daughter of Niobe, and that she was called Meliboea at the first.
When the children of Amphion were destroyed by Apollo and Artemis, she
alone of her sisters, along with Amyclas, escaped; their escape was due
to their prayers to Leto. Meliboea was struck so pale by her fright, not
only at the time but also for the rest of her life, that even her name
was accordingly changed from Meliboea to Chloris.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.21.10">

Now the Argives say that these two built originally the temple to Leto,
but I think that none of Niobe’s children survived, for I place more
reliance than others on the poetry of Homer, one of whose verses bears
out my view:Though they were only two, yet they gave all to
destruction.[^181] So Homer knows that the house of Amphion was utterly
overthrown.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.1">

The temple of Hērā Anthea (Flowery) is on the right of the sanctuary of
Leto, and before it is a tomb of women. They were killed in a battle
against the Argives under Perseus, having come from the Aegean Islands
to help Dionysus in war; for which reason they are surnamed Haliai
(Women of the Sea). Facing the tomb of the women is a sanctuary of
Demeter, surnamed Pelasgian from Pelasgus, son of Triopas, its founder,
and not far from the sanctuary is the tomb of Pelasgus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.2">

Opposite the tomb is a small bronze vessel supporting ancient images
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] of Artemis,
Zeus, and Athena. Now Lykeas in his poem says that the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is of Zeus
Mekhaneus (Contriver), and that here the Argives who set out against
Troy swore to persist in the war until they either took Troy or met
their end fighting. Others have said that in the bronze vessel lie the
bones of Tantalos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.3">

Now that the Tantalos is buried here who was the son of Thyestes or
Broteas (both accounts are given) and married Clytaemnestra before
Agamemnon did, I will not gainsay; but the tomb of him who is said to be
the son of Zeus and Pluto \[Ploutō feminine\]—it is worthy of viewing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\]—is on Mount
Sipylos. I know because I saw it. Moreover, no constraint came upon him
to flee from Sipylos, such as afterwards forced Pelops to run away when
Ilus the Phrygian launched an army against him. But I must pursue the
inquiry no further. The ritual performed at the pit hard by they say was
instituted by Nikostratos, a native. Even at the present day they throw
into the pit burning torches in honor of the Maiden who is daughter of
Demeter.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.4">

Here is a sanctuary of Poseidon, surnamed Prosklystios (Flooder), for
they say that Poseidon inundated the greater part of the country because
Inakhos and his assessors decided that the land belonged to Hērā and not
to him. Now it was Hērā who induced Poseidon to send the sea back, but
the Argives made a sanctuary to Poseidon Prosklystios at the spot where
the tide ebbed.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.5">

Going on a little further you see the tomb of Argos, reputed to be the
son of Zeus and Niobe, daughter of Phoroneus. After these comes a temple
of the Dioskouroi. The statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] represent
the Dioskouroi themselves and their sons, Anaxis and Mnasinous, and with
them are their mothers, Hilaeira and Phoebe. They are of ebony wood, and
were made by Dipoinos and Skyllis. The horses, too, are mostly of ebony,
but there is a little ivory also in their construction.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.6">

Near the Lords is a sanctuary of Eilethyia, dedicated by Helen when,
Theseus having gone away with Peirithoös to Thesprotia, Aphidna had been
captured by the Dioskouroi and Helen was being brought to Lacedaemon.
For it is said that she was with child, was delivered In Argos, and
founded there the sanctuary of Eilethyia, giving the daughter she bore
to Clytaemnestra, who was already wedded to Agamemnon, while she herself
subsequently married Menelaos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.7">

And on this matter the poets Euphorion of Khalkis and Alexander of
Pleuron, and even before them, Stesichorus of Himera, agree with the
Argives in asserting that Iphigeneia was the daughter of Theseus.[^182]
Over against the sanctuary of Eilethyia is a temple of Hekate, and the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is a
work of Scopas. This one is of stone, while the bronze statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] opposite,
also of Hekate, were made respectively by Polyclitus \[Polykleitos\] and
his brother Naukydes, son of Mothon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.8">

As you go along a straight road to a gymnasium, called Cylarabis after
the son of Sthenelus, you come to the tomb of Licymnius, the son of
Electryon, who, Homer says, was killed by Tleptolemos, the son of
Hēraklēs for which homicide Tleptolemos was banished from Argos. On
turning a little aside from the road to Cylarabis and to the gate there,
you come to the tomb of Sacadas, who was the first to play at Delphi the
Pythian tune of the <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aulos</span>
\[‘double-reed’\];

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.22.9">

the hostility of Apollo to players of the
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aulos</span> \[‘double-reed’\],
which had lasted ever since the rivalry of Marsyas the Silenos, is
supposed to have stayed because of this Sacadas. In the gymnasium of
Cylarabes is an Athena called Pania; they show also the tombs of
Sthenelus and of Cylarabes himself. Not far from the gymnasium has been
built a common grave of those Argives who sailed with the Athenians to
enslave Syracuse and Sicily.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.23.1">

As one goes from here along a road
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hodos</span>\] called Hollow
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Koilē</span>\], there is on
the right a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Dionysus; the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], they
say, is from Euboea. For when the Greeks, as they were returning
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] from
Troy, met with the shipwreck at Caphereus, those of the Argives who were
able to escape to land suffered from cold and hunger. Having prayed that
someone of the gods should prove himself a savior
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sōtēr</span>\] in their
present distress, straightway as they advanced they came upon a cave of
Dionysus; in the cave was a statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the god,
and on this occasion wild she-goats had gathered there to escape from
the storm. These the Argives killed, using the flesh as food and the
skins as clothing. When the storm was over and the Argives, having
refitted their ships, were returning
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] homeward,
they took with them the wooden-image
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xoanon</span>\] from the cave,
and continue to honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmân</span>\] it to the
present day.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.23.2">

Very near to the temple of Dionysus you will see the house
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikiā</span>\][^183] of
Adrastos, and, further on from there, a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Amphiaraos,
and, beyond the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Eriphyle.
Next to these is a precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] of Asklepios,
and, after them, a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Baton. Now
Baton belonged to the same lineage
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">genos</span>\] as Amphiaraos,
to the Melampodidai, and was-charioteer
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hēniokheîn</span>\] for him
\[=Amphiaraos\] when that one went forth to battle. When the rout
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropē</span>\] took place at
the wall of Thebes, an opening-up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khasma</span>\] of the earth
happened, receiving Amphiaraos and his chariot, and the opening made him
disappear \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aphanizein</span>\]
together with this Baton.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.23.3">

As one comes back from Hollow-Road \[Koilē\], one sees what they say is
the tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of
Hyrnetho. If it is merely empty
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kenos</span>, = a cenotaph\],
serving no other purpose than a memorializing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] of the woman,
then the things they say are likely
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eikóta</span>\] but if they
think \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] that
the corpse \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nekros</span>\]
lies here, then I cannot believe it. If there is anyone who has not
learned \[as I have\] the things thought by the people of Epidauros, let
someone like that go on and believe it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.23.4">

The most famous sanctuary of Asklepios at Argos contains at the present
day a white-marble statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the god
seated, and by his side stands Hygieia. There are also seated figures of
Xenophilus and Straton, who made the statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\]. The
original founder of the sanctuary was Sphyrus, son of Makhaon and
brother of the Alexanor who is honored among the Sikyonians in Titane.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:2.23.5">

The Argives, like the Athenians and Sikyonians, worship Artemis Pheraia,
and they, too, assert that the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of the goddess
was brought from Pherai in Thessaly. But I cannot agree with them when
they say that in Argos are the tombs of Deianeira, the daughter of
