city, and to stay the advance of Metellus and the Romans, should they
march that way.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.15.9">

When the picked Arcadian troops had been overthrown near Khaironeia,
Metellus moved his army and marched against Thebes, for the Thebans had
joined the Achaeans in investing Herakleia, and had taken part in the
engagement of Skarpheia. Then the inhabitants, of both sexes and of all
ages, abandoned the city and wandered about Boeotia, or took refuge on
the tops of the mountains.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.15.10">

But Metellus would not allow either the burning of sanctuaries of the
gods or the destruction of buildings, and he forbade his men to kill any
Theban or take prisoner any fugitive. If, however, Pytheas should be
caught, he was to be brought before him. Pytheas was discovered
immediately, brought before Metellus and punished. When the army
approached Megara, Alkamenes and his men did not face it, but
straightway fled to the camp of the Achaeans in Corinth.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.15.11">

The Megarians surrendered their city to the Romans without a blow, and
when Metellus came to the Isthmus he again made overtures to the
Achaeans for an agreed peace. For he was possessed of a strong desire to
settle by himself the affairs of both Macedonia and Achaea. His efforts,
however, were thwarted by the senselessness of Diaios.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.1">

Mummius, bringing with him Orestes, the commissioner sent earlier to
deal with the dispute between the Lacedaemonians and the Achaeans,
reached the Roman army at early dawn, and sending Metellus and his
forces to Macedonia, himself waited at the Isthmus for his whole force
to assemble. There came three thousand five hundred cavalry, while the
infantry amounted to twenty-three thousand. They were joined by a
company of Cretan archers and by Philopoimen, at the head of some troops
sent by Attalus from Pergamon on the Kaïkos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.2">

Certain of the Italian troops along with the auxiliaries were stationed
by Mummius twelve stadium-lengths away, to be an outpost for the whole
army. The contempt of the Romans made them keep a careless look-out, and
the Achaeans, attacking them in the first watch, killed some, drove yet
more back to the camp, and took some five hundred shields. Puffed up
with this success the Achaeans marched out to battle before the Romans
began their attack.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.3">

But when Mummius advanced to meet them, the Achaean horse at once took
to flight, without waiting for even the first charge of the Roman
cavalry. The infantry were depressed at the rout of their horse, but
nevertheless received the onslaught of the Roman men-at-arms;
overwhelmed by numbers and faint with their wounds they offered a
spirited resistance, until a thousand picked Romans fell upon their
flank and utterly routed them.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.4">

If after the battle Diaios had boldly thrown himself into Corinth and
received the fugitives within the walls, the Achaeans might have been
able to get favorable terms from Mummius, by putting him to the trouble
of a protracted siege. As it was, when the Achaeans were but beginning
to yield, Diaios fled straight for Megalopolis, his conduct towards the
Achaeans showing a marked contrast to that of Kallistratos, the son of
Empedus, towards the Athenians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.5">

This man commanded some cavalry in Sicily, and when the Athenians and
their partners in the expedition were being massacred at the river
Asinarus, he courageously cut a way through the enemy at the head of his
horsemen. He brought most of them safe to Catana, and then returned by
the same way back to Syracuse. Finding the enemy still plundering the
Athenian camp, he cut down some five of them, and then both he and his
horse received mortal wounds and died.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.6">

So he won glory for the Athenians and for himself, by saving the men
under his command and seeking his own death. But Diaios having ruined
the Achaeans came to tell the tidings of disaster to the people of
Megalopolis, killed his wife with his own hand, just to save her from
being taken prisoner, and then committed suicide by drinking poison. He
may be compared to Menalkidas for his avarice, and proved equally like
him in the cowardice of his death.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.7">

As soon as night fell, the Achaeans who had escaped to Corinth after the
battle fled from the city, and there fled with them most of the
Corinthians themselves. At first Mummius hesitated to enter Corinth,
although the gates were open, as he suspected that an ambush had been
laid within the walls. But on the third day after the battle he
proceeded to storm Corinth and to set it on fire.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.8">

The majority of those found in it were put to the sword by the Romans,
but the women and children Mummius sold into slavery. He also sold all
the slaves who had been set free, had fought on the side of the
Achaeans, and had not fallen at once on the field of battle. The most
admired votive offerings and works of art were carried off by Mummius;
those of less account he gave to Philopoimen, the general sent by
Attalus; even in my day there were Corinthian spoils at Pergamon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.9">

The walls of all the cities that had made war against Rome Mummius
demolished, disarming the inhabitants, even before assistant
commissioners were despatched from Rome, and when these did arrive, he
proceeded to put down democracies and to establish governments based on
a property qualification. Tribute was imposed on Greece, and those with
property were forbidden to acquire possessions in a foreign country.
Racial confederacies, whether of Achaeans, or of the people of Phokis,
or of Boeotians, or of any other Greek people, were one and all put
down.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.16.10">

A few years later the Romans took pity on Greece, restored the various
old racial confederacies, with the right to acquire property in a
foreign country, and remitted the fines imposed by Mummius. For he had
ordered the Boeotians to pay a hundred talents to the people of
Herakleia and Euboea, and the Achaeans to pay two hundred to the
Lacedaemonians. Although the Romans granted the Greeks remission of
these payments, yet down to my day a Roman governor has been sent to the
country. The Romans call him the Governor, not of Greece, but of Achaea,
because the cause of the subjection of Greece was the Achaeans, at that
time at the head of the Greek nation.[^443] This war came to an end when
Antitheus was archon
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn</span>\] in Athens, in
the hundred and sixtieth Olympiad,[^444] at which Diodoros of Sikyon was
victorious.[^445]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.1">

It was at this time that Greece was struck with universal and utter
prostration, although parts of it from the beginning had suffered ruin
and devastation through the agency of the superhuman power
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimōn</span>\]. Argos, a city
that reached the zenith of its power in the days of the heroes, as they
are called, was deserted by the good will
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tò eumenes</span>\] of fortune
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tukhē</span>\] on the occasion
of the shift \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">metabolē</span>\]
in favor of the Dorians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.2">

The people of Attica, reviving after the Peloponnesian war and the
plague, raised themselves again only to be struck down a few years later
by the ascendancy of Macedonia. From Macedonia the wrath of Alexander
swooped like a thunderbolt on Thebes of Boeotia. The Lacedaemonians
suffered injury through Epameinondas of Thebes and again through the war
with the Achaeans. And when painfully, like a shoot from a mutilated and
mostly withered trunk, the Achaean power sprang up, it was cut short,
while still growing, by the cowardice[^446] of its generals.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.3">

At a later time, when the Roman imperial power devolved upon Nero, he
gave to the Roman people the very prosperous island of Sardinia in
exchange for Greece, and then bestowed upon the latter complete freedom.
When I considered this act of Nero it struck me how true is the remark
of Plato, the son of Ariston, who says that the greatest and most daring
crimes are committed, not by ordinary men, but by a noble soul ruined by
a perverted education.[^447]

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.4">

The Greeks, however, were not to profit by the gift. For in the reign of
Vespasian, the next emperor after Nero, they became embroiled in a civil
war; Vespasian ordered that they should again pay tribute and be subject
to a governor, saying that the Greek people had forgotten how to be
free.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.5">

To resume after my researches into Achaean history. The boundary between
Achaea and Elis is the river Larisus, and by the river is a temple of
Larisaean Athena; about thirty stadium-lengths distant from the Larisus
is Dyme, an Achaean city. This was the only Achaean city that in his
wars Philip the son of Demetrios made subject to him, and for this
reason Sulpicius, another Roman governor, handed over Dyme to be sacked
by his soldiery. Afterwards Augustus annexed it to Patrai.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.6">

Its more ancient name was Paleia, but the Ionians changed this to its
modern name while they still occupied the city; I am uncertain whether
they named it after Dyme, a native woman, or after Dymas, the son of
Aigimios. But nobody is likely to be led into a fallacy by the
inscription on the statue of Oibotas at Olympia. Oibotas was a man of
Dyme, who won the foot-race at the sixth Festival[^448] and was honored,
because of a Delphic oracle, with a statue erected in the eightieth
Olympiad.[^449] On it is an inscription which says:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.7">

“This Oibotas, an Achaean, the son of Oinias, by winning the foot-race,

</div>

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Added to the renown of his fatherland Paleia.”

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

This inscription should mislead nobody, although it calls the city
Paleia and not Dyme. For it is the custom of Greek poets to use ancient
names instead of more modern ones, just as they surname Amphiaraos and
Adrastos Phoronids, and Theseus an Erechthid.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.8">

A little before the city of Dyme there is, on the right of the road, the
tomb of Sostratos. He was a native youth, loved they say by Hēraklēs,
who outliving Sostratos made him his tomb and gave him some hair from
his head as a primal offering. Even today there is a slab on the top of
the mound, with a figure of Hēraklēs in relief. I was told that the
natives also sacrifice to Sostratos as to a hero.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.9">

The people of Dyme have a temple of Athena with an extremely ancient
image; they have as well a sanctuary built for the Dindymenian mother
and Attis. As to Attis, I could learn no secret
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aporrhēton</span>\] about
him,[^450] but Hermesianax, the elegiac poet, says in a poem that he was
the son of Galaos the Phrygian, and that he was a eunuch from birth. The
account of Hermesianax goes on to say that, on growing up, Attis
migrated to Lydia and celebrated for the Lydians the orgies of the
Mother; that he rose to such honor with her that Zeus, being angry at
it,[^451] sent a boar to destroy the tillage of the Lydians.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.10">

Then certain Lydians, with Attis himself, were killed by the boar, and
it is consistent with this that the Gauls who inhabit Pessinus abstain
from pork. But the current view about Attis is different, the local
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrios</span>\] story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] about him being
this. Zeus, it is said, let fall in his sleep seed upon the ground,
which in course of time sent up a superhuman force
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimōn</span>\], with two
sexual organs, male and female, who was called Agdistis. But the gods,
fearing[^452] Agdistis, cut off the male organ.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.11">

There grew up from it an almond tree with its fruit ripe, and a daughter
of the river Sangarios, they say, took of the fruit and put it in her
insides \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kolpos</span>\], when
it at once disappeared, but she was with child. A boy was born, and
exposed, but was tended by a he-goat. As he grew up his beauty was more
than human, and Agdistis fell in love with him. When he had grown up,
Attis was sent by his relatives to Pessinus, that he might wed the
king’s daughter.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.12">

The marriage-song was being sung, when Agdistis appeared, and Attis went
mad and cut off his genitals, as also did he who was giving him his
daughter in marriage. But Agdistis repented of what he had done to
Attis, and persuaded Zeus to grant that the body of Attis should neither
rot at all nor decay.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.13">

These are the things that are best known about Attis. In the territory
of Dyme is also the tomb of Oibotas the runner. Although this Oibotas
was the first Achaean to win an Olympic victory, he yet received from
them no special prize. Wherefore Oibotas pronounced a curse that no
Achaean in future should win an Olympic victory. There must have been
some god who was careful that the curse of Oibotas should be fulfilled,
but the Achaeans by sending to Delphi at last learned why it was that
they had been failing to win the Olympic garland.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.17.14">

So they dedicated the statue of Oibotas at Olympia and honored him in
other ways, and then Sostratos of Pellene won the foot-race for boys. It
is still today a custom for the Achaeans who are going to compete at
Olympia to sacrifice to Oibotas as to a hero, and, if they are
successful, to place a wreath on the statue of Oibotas at Olympia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.1">

Some forty stadium-lengths from Dyme the river Peirus flows down into
the sea; on the Peirus once stood the Achaean city of Olenos. The poets
who have sung of Hēraklēs and his labors have found a favorite subject
in Dexamenos, king of Olenοs, and the entertainment Hēraklēs received at
his court. That Olenοs was from the beginning a small town I find
confirmed in an elegiac poem composed by Hermesianax about Eurytion the
Centaur. In course of time, it is said, the inhabitants, owing to their
weakness, left Olenus and migrated to Peiraiand Euryteiae.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.2">

About eighty stadium-lengths from the river Peiros is the city of
Patrai. Not far from Patrai the river Glaukos flows into the sea. Those
who memorialize
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmoneuein</span>\]
the-ancient-lore \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tà
arkhaia</span>\] of the people-of-Patrai
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Patreîs</span>\] say that it
was an aboriginal earthborn
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">autokhthōn</span>\], Eumēlos,
who first made-a-home
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in the land,
and that he was-king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileuein</span>\] of only a
few humans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\].
But when Triptolemos came from Attica, he \[= Eumelos\] received from
him \[= Triptolemos\] cultivated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hēmeros</span>\]
seed-for-harvesting
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpos</span>\], and, learning
how to establish
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikizein</span>\] a city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\], he named it
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Aroē</span> from the ploughing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aroûn</span>\] of the land.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.3">

It is said that Triptolemos once fell asleep, and that then Antheias,
the son of Eumēlos, yoked the dragons to the chariot
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harma</span>\] of Triptolemos
and tried to sow-seed
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">speirein</span>\] himself. But
Antheias, undertaking the task, fell off the chariot and was killed, and
so Triptolemos and Eumēlos in common
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">en koinōi</span>\] established
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikizein</span>\] a city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\], and called it
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Antheia</span> after the son of
Eumēlos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.4">

Between Antheia and Aroe was established
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikizein</span>\] a third city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\], called
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Mesátis</span>. As for all the
things that the people-of-Patrai \[Patreîs\] say about Dionysus, how he
was raised in Mesatis and incurred there all sorts of dangers
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kindunoi</span>\] through the
plots of the Titans, I will not contradict, but will leave it to the
people-of-Patrai \[Patreîs\] to explicate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ex(h)ēgeîsthai</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.5">

When, at a later point, the Achaeans had driven out the Ionians,
Patreus, the son of Preugenes, the son of Agenor, forbade the Achaeans
to settle in Antheia and Mesatis, but built at Aroe a wall
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">teikhos</span>\] of greater
circumference
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\] so as to
include Aroe within the enclosure
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\], and he
named the city \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\]
Patrai after himself. Agenor, the father of Preugenes, was the son of
Areus, the son of Ampyx, and Ampyx was a son of Pelias, the son of
Aiginetes, the son of Dereites, the son of Harpalos, the son of Amyklas,
the son of Lacedaemon.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.6">

These were the ancestors of Patreus. With the passage of time the people
of Patrai by their own choice crossed into Aetolia; they did this out of
friendship for the Aetolians, to help them in their war with the Gauls,
and no other Achaeans joined them. But suffering unspeakable disasters
in the fighting, and most of them being also crushed by poverty, all
with the exception of a few left Patrai, and scattered, owing to their
love of agriculture, up and down the countryside, dwelling
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] in, besides
Patrai, the following municipalities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polismata</span>\]: Mesatis,
Antheia, Boline, Argyrâ, and Arba.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.7">

But Augustus, for some reason
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\], perhaps
because he thought that Patrai was a convenient port of call, brought
back again to Patrai the men
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">andres</span>\] from the other
municipalities
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polismata</span>\], and he
consolidated-as-a-city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sunoikizein</span>\] not only
these populations but also
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pros</span>-\] the Achaeans
from Rhypai, which place he demolished all the way down to its
foundations. He granted that the people-of-Patrai \[Patreîs\] should be
free \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">eleutheroi</span>\]. He
granted this only to them, of all the Achaeans. And he granted to them
also all the other privileges
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">gera</span>\] that the Romans
have-the-custom-of bestowing on their colonists
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apoikoi</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.8">

On their acropolis the people of Patrai have a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Artemis
Laphria. The name
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">onoma</span>\] of the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]
Laphria is not-native
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenikon</span>\], and her
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] was
brought in likewise from elsewhere. Here is why I say this. After
Calydon along with the rest of Aetolia had been depopulated by Augustus
the <span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span> \[‘king’\]
so that the Aetolian people might be incorporated
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sunoikizesthai</span>\] into
Nikopolis near Actium, the people of Patrai in this way got to have the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Laphria.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.9">

Most of the statues
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalmata</span>\] originating
from Aetolia and from Acarnania were brought
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">komizesthai</span>\] by order
of Augustus to Nikopolis, but to Patrai he gave, along with other
confiscated-things
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">laphura</span>\] from Calydon,
the statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of
Laphria, which even in my time was still receiving honors
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\] on the
acropolis of Patrai. It is said that the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\] got
the surname \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\]
Laphria after a man from Phokis, because the ancient statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] of Artemis had
been set up
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hidrusasthai</span>\] at
Calydon by Laphrios, the son of Kastalios, the son of Delphos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.10">

Others say that the anger
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēnīma</span>\] of Artemis
against Oineus, as time went on, weighed more lightly
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">elaphroteron</span>\] on the
Calydonians, and they wishfully-think
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ethelein</span>\] that this
was the reason \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\]
for the surname
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\] of the
goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>
(feminine)\]. The pose
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">skhēma</span>\] of the statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is a Huntress
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thēreuousa</span>\]; it is
made \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">poieîn</span>\] of ivory
and gold. Those who worked on it were Menaikhmos and Soidas, both from
Naupaktos, and both of these two, it is inferred-from-the-evidence
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tekmairesthai</span>\], lived
not much later than Kanakhos of Sikyon and Kallon of Aegina.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.11">

The people-of-Patrai \[Patreîs\] celebrate every year a festival
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\] called
Laphria, which is likewise intended for their \[special kind of\]
Artemis, and, at this festival, there is a \[special\] way
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tropos</span>\] of sacrificing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\] that is
peculiar-to-the-locale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrios</span>\]. Around
the altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] in a
circle \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kuklos</span>\] they
set logs-of-wood \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xula</span>\]
still green \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khlōra</span>\],
each of them sixteen cubits in length. On the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] within the
circle \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kuklos</span>\] are
placed the driest of the logs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xula</span>\]. Just before the
right-time \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kairos</span>\] of
the festival \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\]
they create a smooth ascent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anodos</span> =
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-hodos</span>\] to the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\], piling earth
upon the ascending-steps
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anabasmoi</span>\] \[to form a
ramp\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.12">

The first thing that happens is the processing-of-a-procession
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pompēn pompeuein</span>\]—a
most magnificent
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">megaloprepestatē</span>\]
procession—for Artemis, and the girl
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\] who
officiates-as-priestess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierâsthai</span>\], coming up
last in \[the sequence of\] the procession
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pompē</span>\], rides
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">okheîtai</span>\] in a chariot
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">harma</span>\] yoked to deer.
It is, however, not till the next day—yes, this is the day—when they do
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\] the \[special\]
things that they have-the-custom
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomizein</span>\] of doing for
the sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\]—both the city
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">polis</span>\],
by-way-of-its-public-support
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmosiāi</span>\], and no less
so the people, each-one-of-them-as-private-individuals
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">idiōtai</span>\],
being-ambitiously-aware-of-the-honor
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">philotīmōs ekhein</span>\]
with regard to the festival
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\]. Here is what
I mean. The people throw alive upon the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] edible birds
and all kinds of sacrificial-animals
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereîa</span>\] as well;
there are wild boars, deer, and gazelles; some even bring wolf-cubs or
bear-cubs, others bring the full-grown beasts. They also place upon the
altar \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] fruit
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpos</span>\] of cultivated
trees.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.18.13">

Next they set fire to the logs
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xula</span>\]. At this point I
saw \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theâsthai</span>\] some of
the animals, including a bear, trying to force-their-way
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">biazesthai</span>\] out, at
the first rush of the fire—some of them actually escaping by brute
force. But those who threw them in would drag them back again to the
pyre \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">purā</span>\]. It is not
remembered that anybody has ever been wounded by the animals.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.1">

Between the temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of \[Artemis\]
Laphria and the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] has been built
the tomb \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of
Eurypylos. Before my narrative
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] about who he
was and for what reason
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">aitiā</span>\] he came to this
land I will first tell about the existing state of affairs at the time
of his arrival. The Ionians who inhabited
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\] Aroe, Antheia,
and Mesatis had in-common \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">en
koinōi</span>\] a precinct
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">temenos</span>\] and a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Artemis with
the surname \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\]
Triklaria, and for her the Ionians used to celebrate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] every year a
festival \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\] and
an all-night-festivity
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pannukhis</span>\]. The
sacred-title-of-priest(ess)
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierōsunē</span>\] of the
goddess \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>
(feminine)\] was to be held by someone who was to be a virgin
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\] until the
time came for her to be sent to a husband.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.2">

Now they say that once upon a time it happened that the one who was
serving-as-priestess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hierâsthai</span>\] for the
goddess was Komaitho, a most-beautiful
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kallistē</span>\] virgin
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\].
Melanippos—that was his name—was-passionately-in-love
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erân</span>\] with her. He was
far better in good looks than others of his age. When Melanippos led the
girl \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\] to a
degree of passionate-love
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\] that reached the
point of being equal to his own
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">es tò ison</span>\], he
approached her father, seeking-permission-to-marry
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnâsthai</span>\] her. Somehow
old age has a way of opposing the young in very many things, and, most
of all, it has a way of being insensitive-to-the-pain
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">an-algēton</span>\] with
regard to those who are-passionately-in-love
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erân</span>\]. That is how it
was for Melanippos. Even though Komaitho was ready and willing to get
married off just as he was ready and willing to marry her, the response
he got even from his own parents, not only from the parents of Komaitho,
was anything but gentle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hēmeron</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.3">

The passionate-experiences
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pathēmata</span>\] of
Melanippos, like those of many others, gave-proof
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epi-deixai</span>\] that
passionate-love \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\]
has a way of confusing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sun-kheai</span>\] the
customary-laws \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nomima</span>\]
of humans \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\]
and of turning-upside-down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ana-trepsai</span>\] the
acts-of-honor \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">tīmai</span>\]
that are due to the gods
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theoi</span>\]. That is what
happened back then in this case as well. Right inside the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Artemis,
Komaitho and Melanippos had their fill of passionate-love
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erōs</span>\] in full swing.
And, after that, they even got into the habit of using the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] as a
bridal-chamber
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thalamos</span>\]. In due
time, the anger
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mēnīma</span>\] of Artemis
began to destroy the humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\]. The earth
yielded no harvest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">karpos</span>\], and there
were diseases \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nosoi</span>\]
quite out of the ordinary, since they resulted in an unaccountable
number of deaths.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.4">

The people appealed to the oracle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēstērion</span>\] at
Delphi, and the Pythian-priestess \[Puthia\] accused Melanippos and
Komaitho. The oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteuma</span>\], reaching
the people, ordered that they must sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] those two \[=
Melanippos and Komaitho\] to Artemis, and that every year \[thereafter\]
they must sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] to the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\]
whoever was the most beautiful girl
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\] and boy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pais</span>\]. Because of this
sacrifice \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\], the
river flowing by the sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of \[Artemis\]
Triklaria was named Ameilikhos \[‘not-benign’\]. Previously it had no
name.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.5">

None of the boys
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paides</span>\] and girls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénoi</span>\] who
perished because of Melanippos and Komaitho had done anything wrong
against the goddesss
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\], and
yet they still suffered
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paskhein</span>\] in a most
pitiful way, as did also those who were near-and-dear
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pros-(h)ēkontes</span>\] to
them, but those two \[= Melanippos and Komaitho\], I propose, escaped
from misfortune
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sumphorā</span>\]. I say this
because the only thing there is for a human
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpos</span>\] that is
worth one’s own life in exchange is this: achieving-success
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">katorthōsai</span>\] in
loving-passionately
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">erân</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.6">

It is said that their practice of sacrificing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] was put to
an end for them \[= the people of Patrai\] in the following way. Before
all this, there-had-been-an-oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsthai</span>\] for them
from Delphi, saying that a king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] who is alien
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenos</span>\] will come to
the land, bringing with him a superhuman-power
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">daimōn</span>\] who is
likewise alien
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenikos</span>\], and that
this king will put an end to the things having to do with the sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\] to \[Artemis\]
Triklaria. When Troy \[Ilion\] was captured, and the Greeks divided the
spoils, Eurypylos the son of Euaimon got a chest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\]. In the chest
was a statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\]
of Dionysus, the work
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ergon</span>\], so they say,
of Hephaistos, and given as a gift by Zeus to Dardanos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.7">

But there are two other narratives
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logoi</span>\] with regard to
this \[= the chest\]. One is that this chest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\] was left
behind by Aeneas when he fled \[from Troy\]; the other, that it was
thrown away by Cassandra to become a misfortune
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">sumphorā</span>\] for the one
among the Greeks who finds it. Be that as it may, Eurypylos opened the
chest \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\], saw the
statue \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\], and,
right after the vision
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">théā</span>\], he went
out-of-his-mind
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">ek-phrōn</span>\]. He went on
being-in-a-mental state
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mainesthai</span>\] for the
greater part of the time, though occasionally he would get back inside
himself. Being in this state, he did not proceed on his sea voyage to
Thessaly, but headed for Kirrha and the gulf there. Going uphill to
Delphi, he consulted-the-oracle
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrâsthai</span>\] about his
illness \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nosos</span>\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.8">

They say that an oracular-pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">manteuma</span>\] was given to
him: at whatever place he finds humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] who
are-sacrificing
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] a sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\] that is alien
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">xenē</span>\], at that place
he should set down the chest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\] and be-at-home
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">oikeîn</span>\]. Now the ships
of Eurypylos were carried down by the wind to the sea off Aroe. On
landing he came across a boy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pais</span>\] and a girl
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">parthénos</span>\] who had
just been brought to the altar
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">bōmos</span>\] of \[Artemis\]
Triklaria. So Eurypylos found it easy to understand the things having to
do with the sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\], while the
local-people
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrioi</span>\] got
themselves back to a remembrance
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] of the oracular
pronouncement
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">khrēsmos</span>\] now that
they saw a king
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">basileus</span>\] whom they
had never seen before. And they suspected
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hupo-noeîn</span>\] that the
chest \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\] had some
god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\] inside it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.9">

So it was, then, that the illness
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nosos</span>\] of Eurypylos
and the things having to do with the sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thusiā</span>\] practiced by
these humans
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">anthrōpoi</span>\] came to an
end. Also, the river was now given its present name Meilikhos
\[‘benign’\]. Some have written, concerning the things I have just said,
that these things happened not to the Thessalian Eurypylos but to
Eurypylos the son of Dexamenos who was king in Olenos. They want to have
it the following way: that this one \[= the other Eurypylos\] joined
Hēraklēs in his campaign against Troy \[Ilion\] and received the chest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\] from Hēraklēs.
The rest of what they say corresponds to what I have said.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.19.10">

The thing is, though, that I cannot be persuaded to believe that
Hēraklēs did not know the things to be known about the chest, if these
things really were such as they were said to be, nor, if he was aware of
them, do I think that he would ever have given it to an ally as a gift.
Further, the people of Patrai have in their memory
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēmē</span>\] no Eurypylos
other than the son of Euaimon, and to him every year they make-sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enagizein</span>\] \[as to a
hero\] when they celebrate
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] the festival
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\] in honor of
Dionysus.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.1">

The surname \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\]
of the god \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span>\]
inside the chest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\] is Aisymnetes
\[‘apportioner’\], and his chief attendants
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">therapeuontes</span>\] are
nine men, elected by the people
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">dēmos</span>\] on the basis of
their reputation
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">axiōma</span>\], and there are
also \[attendants who are\] women, equal in number to the men. On one
night of the festival
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">heortē</span>\] the priest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hiereus</span>\]
carries-in-procession
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">pherein</span>\] the chest
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">larnax</span>\], heading
outside. Now this is a special privilege
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">geras</span>\] assigned to
this night. Going-down
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kata-bainein</span>\] to the
river Meilikhos are a certain number of the local
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrioi</span>\]
boys-and-girls
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">paides</span>\], garlanded
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanoûsthai</span>\] with
garlands of wheat-ears
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">astakhues</span>\] on their
heads. It was in this way that they used to adorn
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kosmeîn</span>\] in the old
times those whom they were leading
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agein</span>\] \[in
procession\] so as to sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">thuein</span>\] them to
Artemis.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.2">

As for our own era, they lay-aside
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">apo-tithenai</span>\] garlands
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanoi</span>\] of
wheat-ears \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">astakhues</span>\]
next to the goddess
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">theos</span> (feminine)\],
and, after bathing in the river and putting on garlands
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">stephanoi</span>\] all over
again, this time made of ivy
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kissos</span>\], they go to
the sanctuary \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\]
of the Aisymnetes \[= Dionysus\]. This then is the established way for
them to-do-the-ritual
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">drân</span>\], and within the
enclosure \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">peribolos</span>\]
of Laphria is a temple
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">nāos</span>\] of Athena having
the surname \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epiklēsis</span>\]
<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">Pan-akhaiïs</span>. The statue
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">agalma</span>\] is of ivory
and gold.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.3">

On the way to the lower city there is a sanctuary of the Dindymenian
Mother, and in it Attis too is worshipped. Of him they have no image to
show; that of the Mother is of stone. In the marketplace is a temple of
Olympian Zeus; the god himself is on a throne with Athena standing by
it. Beyond the Olympian is an image of Hērā and a sanctuary of Apollo.
The god is of bronze, and naked. On his feet are sandals, and one foot
stands upon the skull of an ox.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.4">

That Apollo takes great pleasure in oxen is shown by Alcaeus[^453] in
his hymn to Hermes, who writes how Hermes stole cows of Apollo, and even
before Alcaeus was born Homer made Apollo tend cows of Laomedon for a
wage. In the <span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Iliad</span> he puts
these verses in the mouth of Poseidon:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.5">

“Verily I built a wall for the Trojans about their city,

</div>

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

A wide wall and very beautiful, that the city might be impregnable;

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

And thou, Phoebus, didst tend the shambling cows with crumpled horns.”

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_source_attrib">

<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Iliad</span> 21.446–448

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

This, it may be conjectured, is the reason for the ox skull. On the
marketplace, in the open, is an image of Athena with the tomb of Patreus
in front of it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.6">

Next to the marketplace is the Music Hall, where has been dedicated an
Apollo well worth seeing. It was made from the spoils taken when alone
of the Achaeans the people of Patrai helped the Aetolians against the
army of the Gauls. The Music Hall is in every way the finest in Greece,
except, of course, the one in Athens. This is unrivalled in size and
magnificence, and was built by Herodes, an Athenian,in memory of his
dead wife. The reason why I omitted to mention this Music Hall in my
history of Attica is that my account of the Athenians was finished
before Herodes began the building.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.7">

As you leave the marketplace of Patrai, where the sanctuary of Apollo
is, at this exit is a gate, upon which stand gilded statues, Patreus,
Preugenes, and Atherion; the two latter are represented as boys, because
Patreus is a boy in age. Opposite the marketplace by this exit is a
precinct and temple of Artemis, the Lady of the Lake.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.8">

When the Dorians were now in possession of Lacedaemon and Argos, it is
said that Preugenes, in obedience to a dream, stole from Sparta the
image of our Lady of the Lake, and that he had as partner in his exploit
the most devoted of his slaves. The image from Lacedaemon is usually
kept at Mesoa, because it was to this place that it was originally
brought by Preugenes. But when the festival of our Lady is being held,
one of the slaves of the goddess comes from Mesoa bringing the ancient
wooden image to the precinct in the city.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.20.9">

Near this precinct the people of Patrai have other sanctuaries. These
are not in the open, but there is an entrance to them through the
porticoes. The image of Asklepios, save for the drapery, is of stone;
Athena is made of ivory and gold. Before the sanctuary of Athena is the
tomb of Preugenes. Every year they sacrifice to Preugenes as to a hero,
and likewise to Patreus also, when the festival of our Lady is being
held. Not far from the theater is a temple of Nemesis, and another of
Aphrodite. The images are colossal and of white marble.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.1">

In this part of the city is also a sanctuary of Dionysus surnamed
Calydonian, for the image of Dionysus too was brought from Calydon. When
Calydon was still inhabited, among the Calydonians who became priests of
the god was Koresos, who more than any other man suffered cruel wrongs
because of love. He was in love with Kallirhoe, a virgin. But the love
of Koresos for Kallirhoe was equalled by the maiden's hatred of him.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.2">

When the maiden refused to change her mind, in spite of the many prayers
and promises of Koresos, he then went as a suppliant to the image of
Dionysus. The god listened to the prayer of his priest, and the
Calydonians at once became raving as though through drink, and they were
still out of their minds when death overtook them. So they appealed to
the oracle at Dodona. For the inhabitants of this part of the mainland,
the Aetolians and their neighbors in Akarnania and Epeiros, considered
that the truest oracles were the doves and the responses from the oak.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.3">

On this occasion the oracles from Dodona declared that it was the wrath
of Dionysus that caused the plague, which would not cease until Koresos
sacrificed to Dionysus either Kallirhoe herself or one who had the
courage to die in her stead. When the girl could find no means of
escape, she next appealed to her foster parents. These too failing her,
there was no other way except for her to be put to the sword.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.4">

When everything had been prepared for the sacrifice according to the
oracle from Dodona, the girl was led like a victim to the altar. Koresos
stood ready to sacrifice, when, his resentment giving way to love, he
slew himself in place of Kallirhoe. He thus proved in deed that his love
was more genuine than that of any other man we know.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.5">

When Kallirhoe saw Koresos lying dead, the girl repented. Overcome by
pity for Koresos, and by shame at her conduct towards him, she cut her
throat at the spring in Calydon not far from the harbor, and later
generations call the spring Kallirhoe after her.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.6">

Near to the theater there is a precinct sacred to a native lady. Here
are images of Dionysus, equal in number to the ancient cities, and named
after them Mesateus, Antheus and Aroeus. These images at the festival of
Dionysus they bring into the sanctuary of \[Dionysus surnamed\] the
Aisymnetes. This sanctuary is on the right of the road from the
marketplace to the sea-quarter of the city.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.7">

As you go lower down from the Dictator there is another sanctuary with
an image of stone. It is called the sanctuary of Recovery, and the story
is that it was originally founded by Eurypylos on being cured of his
madness. At the harbor is a temple of Poseidon with a standing image of
stone. Besides the names given by poets to Poseidon to adorn their
verses, and in addition to his local names, all men give him the
following surnames—Marine, Giver of Safety, God of Horses.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.8">

Various reasons could be plausibly assigned for the last of these
surnames having been given to the god, but my own conjecture is that he
got this name as the inventor of horsemanship. Homer, at any rate, when
describing the chariot-race, puts into the mouth of Menelaos a challenge
to swear an oath by this god:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

“Touch the horses, and swear by the earth-holder, earth-shaker,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

That thou didst not intentionally, through guile, obstruct my chariot.”

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_source_attrib">

<span custom-style="chs_citetitle">Iliad</span> 23.584–585

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.9">

Pamphos also, who composed for the Athenians the most ancient of their
hymns, says that Poseidon is

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

“Giver of horses and of ships with sails set.”

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_source_attrib">

Pamphos, work unknown

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_normal_continue">

So it is from horsemanship that he has acquired his name, and not for
any other reason.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.10">

In Patrai, not far from that of Poseidon, are sanctuaries of Aphrodite.
One of the two images was drawn up by fishermen in a net a generation
before my time. There are also quite near to the harbor two images of
bronze, one of Ares and the other of Poseidon. The image of Aphrodite,
whose precinct too is by the harbor, has its face, hands and feet of
stone, while the rest of the figure is made of wood.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.11">

They have also a grove by the sea, affording in summer weather very
agreeable walks and a pleasant means generally of passing the time. In
this grove are also two temples of divinities, one of Apollo, the other
of Aphrodite. The images of these too are made of stone. Next to the
grove is a sanctuary of Demeter; she and her daughter are standing, but
the image of Earth is seated.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.12">

Before the sanctuary of Demeter is a spring. On the side of this towards
the temple stands a wall of stones, while on the outer side has been
made a descent to the spring. Here there is an infallible oracle, not
indeed for everything, but only in the case of sick folk. They tie a
mirror to a fine cord and let it down, judging the distance so that it
does not sink deep into the spring, but just far enough to touch the
water with its rim.[^454] Then they pray to the goddess and burn
incense, after which they look into the mirror, which shows them the
patient either alive or dead.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.13">

This water partakes to this extent of truth, but close to Cyaneae by
Lycia, where there is an oracle of Apollo Thyrxeus, the water shows to
him who looks into the spring all the things that he wants to behold. By
the grove in Patrai are also two sanctuaries of Serapis. In one is the
tomb of Aigyptos, the son of Belus. He is said by the people of Patrai
to have fled to Aroe because of the misfortunes of his children and
because he shuddered at the mere name of Argos, and even more through
dread of Danaos.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.21.14">

There is also at Patrai a sanctuary of Asklepios. This sanctuary is
beyond the acropolis near the gate leading to Mesatis.The women of
Patrai outnumber the men by two to one. These women are amongst the most
charming in the world. Most of them gain a livelihood from the fine flax
that grows in Elis, weaving from it nets for the head as well as
dresses.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.1">

Pharai, a city of the Achaeans, belongs to Patrai, having been given to
it by Augustus. The road from the city of Patrai to Pharai is a hundred
and fifty stadium-lengths, while Pharai is about seventy stadium-lengths
inland from the coast. Near to Pharai runs the river Pierus, which in my
opinion is the same as the one flowing past the ruins of Olenos, called
by the men of the coast the Peirus. Near the river is a grove of plane
trees, most of which are hollow through age, and so huge that they
actually feast in the holes, and those who have a mind to do so sleep
there as well.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.2">

The marketplace of Pharai is of wide extent after the ancient fashion,
and in the middle of it is an image of Hermes, made of stone and
bearded. Standing right on the earth, it is of square shape, and of no
great size. On it is an inscription, saying that it was dedicated by
Simylus the Messenian. It is called Hermes of the Market, and by it is
established an oracle. In front of the image is placed a hearth, which
also is of stone, and to the hearth bronze lamps are fastened with lead.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.3">

Coming at eventide, the inquirer of the god, having burned incense upon
the hearth, filled the lamps with oil and lighted them, puts on the
altar on the right of the image a local coin, called a “copper,” and
asks in the ear of the god the particular question he wishes to put to
him. After that he stops his ears and leaves the marketplace. On coming
outside he takes his hands from his ears, and whatever utterance he
hears he considers oracular.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.4">

There is a similar method of divination practiced at the sanctuary of
Apis in Egypt. At Pharai there is also a water sacred to Hermes. The
name of the spring is Hermes’ stream, and the fish in it are not caught,
being considered sacred to the god. Quite close to the image stand
square stones, about thirty in number. These the people of Pharai adore,
calling each by the name of some god. At a more remote period all the
Greeks alike worshipped uncarved stones instead of images of the gods.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.5">

About fifteen stadium-lengths from Pharai is a grove of the Dioskouroi.
The trees in it are chiefly laurels; I saw in it neither temple nor
images, the latter, according to the natives, having been carried away
to Rome. In the grove at Pharai is an altar of unshaped stones. I could
not discover whether the founder of Pharai was Phares, son of
Phylodameia, daughter of Danais, or someone else with the same name.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.6">

Triteia, also a city of Achaea, is situated inland, but like Pharai
belongs to Patrai, having been annexed by the emperor. The distance to
Triteia from Pharai is a hundred and twenty stadium-lengths. Before you
enter the city is a tomb of white marble, well worth seeing, especially
for the paintings on the tomb, the work of Nikias. There is an ivory
chair on which is a young and beautiful woman, by whose side is a
handmaid carrying a sunshade. There is also a young man, who is
standing.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.7">

He is too young for a beard, and wears a tunic with a purple cloak over
it. By his side is a servant carrying javelins and leading hounds. I
could not discover their names, but anyone can conjecture that here man
and wife share a common grave.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.8">

The founder of Triteia is said by some to have been Celbidas, who came
from Cumae in the country of the Opici. Others say that Ares mated with
Triteia the daughter of Triton, that this maiden was priestess to
Athena, and that Melanippos, the son of Ares and Triteia, founded the
city when he grew up, naming it after his mother.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.9">

In Triteia is a sanctuary of the gods called Almighty, and their images
are made of clay. In honor of these every year they celebrate a
festival, exactly the same sort of festival as the Greeks hold in honor
of Dionysus. There is also a temple of Athena, and the modern image is
of stone. The ancient image, as the folk of Triteia say, was carried to
Rome. The people here are accustomed to sacrifice both to Ares and to
Triteia.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.10">

These cities are at some distance from the sea and completely inland. As
you sail to Aigion from Patrai you come first to the cape called Rhium,
fifty stadium-lengths from Patrai, the harbor of Panormos being fifteen
stadium-lengths farther from the cape. It is another fifteen
stadium-lengths from Panormos to what is known as the Fort of Athena.
From the Fort of Athena to the harbor of Erineus is a coastal voyage of
ninety stadium-lengths, and from Erineus to Aigion is sixty. But the
land route is about forty stadium-lengths less than the number here
given.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.22.11">

Not far from the city of Patrai is the river Meilikhos, and the
sanctuary of \[Artemis\] Triklaria, which no longer has an image. This
is on the right. Advancing from the Meilikhos you come to another river,
the name of which is the Kharadros. The flocks and herds that drink of
this river in spring are bound to have male young ones for the most
part, and for this reason the herdsmen remove all except the cows to
another part of the country. The cows they leave behind by the river,
because for sacrifices and for agriculture bulls are more suitable than
cows, but in the case of other cattle the females are preferred.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.1">

After the Kharadros you come to some ruins, not at all remarkable, of
the city Argyra, to the spring Argyra, on the right of the high road,
and to the river Selemnus going down to the sea. There is a tale
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] told by the
locals \[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">epikhōrioi</span>\]
about Selemnus—how he was a handsome boy who used to feed his flocks
here. Argyra, they say, was a sea-nymph, who fell in love with Selemnus
and used to come up out of the sea to visit him, sleeping by his side.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.2">

After no long while Selemnus no longer seemed so handsome, and the nymph
would not visit him. So Selemnus, deserted by Argyra, died of love, and
Aphrodite turned him into a river. I am saying here what the people of
Patrai say. Selemnus continued to love Argyra even when he was turned
into water, just as Alpheios, the story
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">logos</span>\] has it,
continued to love Arethousa. Aphrodite bestowed on him \[Selemnus\] a
further gift, by blotting out the memory of Argyra.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.3">

I heard too another tale about the water, how it is a useful remedy for
both men and women when in love; if they wash in the river they forget
their passion. If there is any truth in the story the water of the
Selemnus is of more value to mankind than great wealth.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.4">

At some distance from Argyra is a river named Bolinaios, and by it once
stood a city Bolina. Apollo, it is said, fell in love with a maiden
called Bolina, who fleeing to the sea here threw herself into it, and by
the favor of Apollo became an immortal. Next to it a cape juts out into
the sea, and of it is told a story how Kronos threw into the sea here
the sickle with which he mutilated his father Uranus. For this reason
they call the cape Drepanum.[^455] Beyond the high road are the ruins of
Rhypes. Aigion is about thirty stadium-lengths distant from Rhypes.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.5">

The territory of Aigion is crossed by a river Phoenix, and by another
called Meiganitas, both of which flow into the sea. A portico near the
city was made for Straton, an athlete who won at Olympia on the same day
victories in the pankration and in wrestling. The portico was built that
this man might exercise himself in it. At Aigion is an ancient sanctuary
of Eileithuia, and her image is covered from head to foot with
finely-woven drapery; it is of wood except the face, hands and feet,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.6">

which are made of Pentelic marble. One hand is stretched out straight;
the other holds up a torch. One might conjecture that torches are an
attribute of Eileithuia because the pangs of women are just like fire.
The torches might also be explained by the fact that it is Eileithuia
who brings children to the light. The image is a work of Damophon the
Messenian.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.7">

Not far from Eileithuia is a precinct of Asklepios, with images of him
and of Hygieia. An iambic line on the pedestal says that the artist was
Damophon the Messenian. In this sanctuary of Asklepios a man of Sidon
entered upon an argument with me. He declared that the Phoenicians had
better notions about the gods than the Greeks, giving as an instance
that to Asklepios they assign Apollo as father, but no mortal woman as
his mother.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.8">

Asklepios, he went on, is air, bringing health to mankind and to all
animals likewise; Apollo is the sun, and most rightly is he named the
father of Asklepios, because the sun, by adapting his course to the
seasons, imparts to the air its healthfulness. I replied that I accepted
his statements, but that the argument was as much Greek as Phoenician
for at Titane in Sikyonia the same image is called both Hygieia and
…[^456] thus clearly showing that it is the course of the sun that
brings health to mankind.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.9">

At Aigion you find a temple of Athena and a grove of Hērā. Of Athena
there are two images of white marble; the image of Hērā may be seen by
nobody except the woman who happens to hold the office of priestess to
the goddess. Near the theater they have a sanctuary of Dionysus with an
image of the god as a beardless youth. There is also in the marketplace
a precinct of Zeus surnamed Savior, with two images, both of bronze, on
the left as you go in; the one without a beard seemed to me the more
ancient.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.10">

In a building right in front of the entrance are images, of bronze like
the others, representing Poseidon, Hēraklēs, Zeus and Athena. They are
called gods from Argos. The Argives say it is because they were made in
Argos; the people of Aigion themselves say that the images were
deposited by the Argives with them on trust.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.23.11">

They say further that they were ordered to sacrifice each day to the
images. But bethinking themselves of a trick they sacrificed a vast
number of animals, but the victims they ate up at public feasts, so that
they were not put to any expense. At last the Argives asked for the
images to be returned, whereupon the people of Aigion asked for the cost
of the sacrifices. As the Argives had not the means to pay, they left
the images at Aigion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.1">

By the marketplace at Aigion is a temple shared by Apollo and Artemis in
common; and in the marketplace there is a sanctuary
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">hieron</span>\] of Artemis,
who is represented in the act of shooting an arrow, and also the tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">taphos</span>\] of Talthybios
the herald \[kērux<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">\].</span>
There is also at Sparta a barrow serving as a tomb
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">mnēma</span>\] of Talthybios,
which is heaped-up-as-a-tumulus
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">kekhōstai</span>\], and both
cities sacrifice
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">enagizein</span>\] to him \[as
to a hero\].

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.2">

By the sea at Aigion is a sanctuary of Aphrodite, and after it one of
Poseidon; there is also one of the Maiden, daughter of Demeter, and one
to Zeus Homagyrios (Assembler). Here are images of Zeus, of Aphrodite
and of Athena. The surname Assembler was given to Zeus because in this
place Agamemnon assembled the most eminent men in Greece, in order that
they might consult together how to make war on the empire of Priam.
Among the claims of Agamemnon to renown is that he destroyed Troy and
the cities around her[^457] with the forces that followed him
originally, without any later reinforcements.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.3">

Adjoining Zeus the Assembler is a sanctuary of Demeter Panachaean. The
beach, on which the people of Aigion have the sanctuaries I have
mentioned, affords a plentiful supply of water from a spring; it is
pleasing both to the eye and to the taste. They have also a sanctuary of
Safety. Her image may be seen by none but the priests, and the following
ritual is performed. They take cakes of the district from the goddess
and throw them into the sea, saying that they send them to Arethousa at
Syracuse.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.4">

There are at Aigion other images made of bronze, Zeus as a boy and
Hēraklēs as a beardless youth, the work of Ageladas of Argos. Priests
are elected for them every year, and each of the two images remains at
the house of the priest. In a more remote age there was chosen to be
priest for Zeus from the boys he who won the prize for beauty. When his
beard began to grow the honor for beauty passed to another boy. Such
were the customs. Even in my time the Achaean assembly still meets at
Aigion, just as the Amphiktyones do at Thermopylae and at Delphi.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.5">

Going on further you come to the river Selinous, and forty
stadium-lengths away from Aigion is a place on the sea called Helike.
Here used to be situated a city Helike, where the Ionians had a very
holy sanctuary of Heliconian Poseidon. Their worship of Heliconian
Poseidon has remained, even after their expulsion by the Achaeans to
Athens, and subsequently from Athens to the coasts of Asia. At Miletus
too on the way to the spring Biblis there is before the city an altar of
Heliconian Poseidon, and in Teos likewise the Heliconian has a precinct
and an altar, well worth seeing.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.6">

There are also passages in Homer[^458] referring to Helike and the
Heliconian Poseidon. But later on the Achaeans of the place removed some
suppliants from the sanctuary and killed them. But the wrath of Poseidon
visited them without delay; an earthquake promptly struck their land and
swallowed up, without leaving a trace for posterity to see, both the
buildings and the very site on which the city stood.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.7">

Warnings, usually the same in all cases, are accustomed to be sent by
the god before violent and far-reaching earthquakes. Either continuous
storms of rain or else continuous droughts occur before earthquakes for
an unusual length of time, and the weather is unseasonable. In winter it
turns too hot, and in summer along with a tendency to haze the orb of
the sun presents an unusual color, slightly inclining to red or else to
black.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.8">

Springs of water generally dry up; blasts of wind sometimes swoop upon
the land and overturn the trees; occasionally great flames dart across
the sky; the shapes of stars too appear such as have never been
witnessed before, producing consternation in those that witness them;
furthermore there is a violent rumbling of winds beneath the earth—these
and many other warnings is the god accustomed to send before violent
earthquakes occur.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.9">

The shock itself is not of one fixed type, but the original inquirers
into such matters and their pupils have been able to discover the
following forms of earthquake. The mildest form—that is, if such a
calamity admits of mitigation—is when there coincides with the original
shock, which levels the buildings with the ground, a shock in the
opposite direction, counteracting the first and raising up the buildings
already knocked over.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.10">

In this form of earthquake pillars may be seen righting themselves which
have been almost entirely uprooted, split walls coming together to their
original position; beams, dislocated by the shock, go back to their
places, and likewise channels, and such-like means of furthering the
flow of water, have their cracks cemented better than they could be by
human craftsmen. Now the second form of earthquake brings destruction to
anything liable to it, and it throws over at once, as it were by a
battering-ram, whatever meets the force of its impact.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.11">

The most destructive kind of earthquake the experts are accustomed to
liken to the symptoms of a man suffering from a non-intermittent fever,
the breathing of such a patient being rapid and labored. There are
symptoms of this to be found in many parts of the body, especially at
each wrist. In the same way, they say, the earthquake dives directly
under buildings and shakes up their foundations, just as molehills come
up from the bowels of the earth. It is this sort of shock alone that
leaves no trace on the ground that men ever dwelled there.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.12">

This was the type of earthquake, they say, that on the occasion referred
to levelled Helike to the ground, and that it was accompanied by another
disaster in the season of winter. The sea flooded a great part of the
land, and covered up the whole of Helike all round. Moreover, the tide
was so deep in the grove of Poseidon that only the tops of the trees
remained visible. What with the sudden earthquake, and the invasion of
the sea that accompanied it, the tidal wave swallowed up Helike and
every man in it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.24.13">

A similar fate, though different in type,[^459] came upon a city on
Mount Sipylos, so that it vanished into a chasm. The mountain split,
water welled up from the fissure, and the chasm became a lake called
Saloe. The ruins of the city were to be seen in the lake, until the
water of the torrent hid them from view. The ruins of Helike too are
visible, but not so plainly now as they were once, because they are
corroded by the salt water.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.1">

The disaster that befell Helike is but one of the many proofs that the
wrath of the God of Suppliants is inexorable. The god at Dodona too
manifestly advises us to respect suppliants. For about the time of
Apheidas the Athenians received from Zeus of Dodona the following
verses:

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

“Consider the Areiopagos, and the smoking altars

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

Of the Eumenides, where the Lacedaemonians are to be thy suppliants,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

When hard-pressed in war. Kill them not with the sword,

</div>

<div custom-style="chs_verse_line">

And wrong not suppliants. For suppliants are sacred and holy.”

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.2">

The Greeks were reminded of these words when Peloponnesians arrived in
Athens at the time when the Athenian king was Kodros, the son of
Melanthos. Now the rest of the Peloponnesian army, on learning of the
death of Kodros and of the manner of it, departed from Attica, the
oracle from Delphi making them despair of success in the future; but
certain Lacedaemonians, who got unnoticed within the walls in the night,
perceived at daybreak that their friends had gone, and when the
Athenians gathered against them, they took refuge in the Areiopagos at
the altars of the goddesses called August.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.3">

On this occasion the Athenians allowed the suppliants to go away
unharmed, but subsequently the magistrates themselves put to death the
suppliants of Athena, when Kylon and his supporters had seized the
Acropolis. So the slayers themselves and also their descendants were
regarded as accursed to the goddess. The Lacedaemonians too put to death
men who had taken refuge in the sanctuary of Poseidon at Taenarum.
Presently their city was shaken by an earthquake so continuous and
violent that no house in Lacedaemon could resist it.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.4">

The destruction of Helike occurred while Asteios was still archon
\[<span custom-style="chs_translit_Greek">arkhōn</span>\] in Athens, in
the fourth year of the hundred and first Olympiad,[^460] whereat Damon
of Thourioi was victorious for the first time. As none of the people of
Helike were left alive, the land is occupied by the people of Aigion.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.5">

After Helike you will turn from the sea to the right and you will come
to the town of Ceryneia. It is built on a mountain above the high road,
and its name was given to it either by a native potentate or by the
river Cerynites, which, flowing from Arcadia and Mount Ceryneia, passes
through this part of Achaea. To this part came as settlers Mycenaeans
from Argolis because of a catastrophe. Though the Argives could not take
the wall of Mycenae by storm,

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.6">

built as it was like the wall of Tiryns by the Cyclopes, as they are
called, yet the Mycenaeans were forced to leave their city through lack
of provisions. Some of them departed for Kleonai, but more than half of
the population took refuge with Alexander in Macedonia, to whom
Mardonios, the son of Gobryas, entrusted the message to be given to the
Athenians.[^461] The rest of the population came to Ceryneia, and the
addition of the Mycenaeans made Ceryneia more powerful, through the
increase of the population, and more renowned for the future.

</div>

<div id="@urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0525.tlg001.aprip-nagy:7.25.7">

In Ceryneia is a sanctuary of the Eumenides, which they say was
established by Orestes. Whosoever enters with the desire to see the
sights, if he be guilty of bloodshed, defilement or impiety, is said at
once to become insane with fright, and for this reason the right to
